(Code 1967, § 22-6; Ord. No. 0-2006-24, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-13-06) 
Sec. 5-111. - Amendments to codes. 
    Amendments to the regulatory codes adopted by reference in this article, which are from time to time adopted and published by the agencies or organizations referred to herein shall be effective in the city at the time such amendments are filed with the city clerk as provided in section 5-113. 
(Code 1967, § 22-7) 
Sec. 5-112. - Compliance with codes. 
(a)  All buildings or structures which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed, erected, altered, extended, enlarged, repaired, demolished or removed shall conform to the requirements, minimum standards and other provisions of either the North Carolina State Building Code, General Construction, or the North Carolina Residential Building Code, whichever is applicable, or both if both are applicable. 
(b)  Every building intended for human habitation, occupancy or use shall have plumbing, plumbing systems or plumbing fixtures installed, constructed, altered, extended, repaired or reconstructed in accordance with the minimum standards, requirements and other provisions of the North Carolina Plumbing Code. 
(c)  All mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air conditioning and refrigeration systems, fuel-burning equipment and appurtenances shall be installed, erected, repaired, used and maintained in accordance with the minimum standards, requirements and other provisions of the North Carolina Mechanical Code and Fuel Gas Code. 
(d)  All electrical wiring, installations and appurtenances shall be erected, altered, repaired, used and maintained in accordance with the minimum standards, requirements and other provisions of the North Carolina Electrical Code. 
(e)  No request for electric service or water service for other than construction purposes shall be granted with respect to any structure including but not limited to dwellings, commercial buildings or mobile homes proposed to be served by the city's distribution systems until the supervisor of inspections finds the structure to be in full compliance with the provisions of this article and until a certificate of occupancy/compliance has been issued with respect to the same; provided, however, that the inspection services administrator may waive the requirements for a certificate of occupancy/compliance. 
(f)  Electric service and water service shall be discontinued to all structures found unfit and/or unsafe for human habitation and/or occupancy under the provisions of this chapter or chapter 11; provided, however, that the owners and occupants are notified in writing in advance of such discontinuance of service. 
(Code 1967, § 22-8; Ord. No. 0-2006-24, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-13-06) 
Sec. 5-113. - Copies of codes and amendments filed with clerk. 
    An official copy of each regulatory code adopted in this article, and official copies of all amendments thereto, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. Such copies shall be the official copies of the codes and amendments. 
(Code 1967, § 22-9) 
Secs. 5-114-5-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT 

Sec. 5-131. - Demolition by neglect established. 
    There are hereby established procedures and requirements for the repair or elimination of decaying and deteriorating buildings in the Central City Local Historic District in the City of Rocky Mount, North Carolina. This article V shall be known as the city's "demolition by neglect ordinance." 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-132. - Exercise of police powers: authority. 
    The city council hereby finds and declares that there exist in the Central City Local Historic District buildings or structures which are decaying or deteriorating, or which by neglect are being demolished. The general statutes authorize the city to exercise its authority to prevent the demolition by neglect of these structures. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-133. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect Rocky Mount's historic architectural resources by intervening when a building or structure in the Central City Local Historic District is undergoing demolition by neglect. Demolition by neglect is defined as a situation in which a property owner or other party in interest allows the condition of a property to suffer such deterioration, potentially beyond the point of repair, as to threaten the structural integrity of the building or structure or its relevant architectural detail to such a degree that the building or structure and its character may potentially be lost to current and future generations. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-134. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central City Local Historic District means that area identified as the Central City Local Historic District on the Official Zoning Map of the City of Rocky Mount, the boundaries of which are shown as an overlay district on the zoning map. 
    Chief building inspector or inspector means the Chief Building Inspector of the City of Rocky Mount or his or her designee. 
    Hardship review committee means a committee composed of the director of development services, city engineer, and finance director of the City of Rocky Mount and the chairperson of the historic preservation commission, established to consider claims of undue economic hardship caused by the enforcement of this article. 
    Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. 
    Parties in interest means all individuals, associations and corporations who have interests of record in a building or structure and any who are in possession thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09; Ord. No. O-2018-79, § 2, 8-13-18) 
Sec. 5-135. - Standards. 
    The exterior features of any building or structure located within the Central City Historic District shall be preserved by the owner and/or parties in interest against decay, deterioration and structural defects. The owner and/or parties in interest shall upon written request of the city repair such exterior features if they are found to be deteriorating, or if their condition is contributing to deterioration, including but not limited to, any of the following defects: 
(1)  Deterioration of exterior walls, foundations, flooring, carpet walls, roofs, beams, chimneys and either horizontal or vertical load-bearing supports that cause leaning, sagging, splitting, listing or buckling; 
(2)  Ineffective waterproofing of exterior walls, roofs and foundations, including broken windows/doors, failed paint, leaking roofing, decayed brickwork or failed siding materials; 
(3)  Rotting, holes and other forms of decay; 
(4)  Damages caused by fire or other calamity; 
(5)  Deterioration of exterior stairs, porches, handrails, window/door frames, cornices, entablatures, wall facings or other architectural details that cause delaminating, instability, loss of shape or crumbling; 
(6)  Deterioration of fences, gates, garden walls or accessory structures; 
(7)  Deterioration of any exterior feature that creates or permits a hazardous or unsafe condition to life, health or other property. 
Boarded up windows and street barricades are allowed if they are painted a similar color to the remaining exterior facade. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-136. - Inspection authority. 
    Authority to assure compliance with the standards set forth in this article is vested in the chief building inspector, who shall have the following duties: 
It shall be the duty of the chief building inspector to periodically examine the buildings and structures in the Central City Local Historic District for the purpose of determining their condition and for the purpose of the enforcement and administration of this article. In exercising this power, the chief building inspector shall, if required to fulfill his or her duties under this article, have the right to enter on any premises within the Central City Local Historic District at all reasonable hours (between 8:30 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and at the convenience of the occupant) for the purposes of inspection or other enforcement action, upon presentation of proper credentials. Upon refusal by the owner or other person in legal possession to permit entry, the chief building inspector, after proper notice, shall have the right to inspect pursuant to an administrative search warrant issued in accordance with the provisions of G.S. § 15-27.2. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or parties in interest to relocate any moveable obstructions (furniture, boxes, appliances and construction material, for example) that would otherwise interfere with a complete inspection. The chief building inspector shall not be expected to detect violations of this article when such violations are concealed behind, under or above walls, floors, ceilings or other fixed components of the building. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-137. - Petition and action. 
    A property owner or any other interested person may file a petition with the chief building inspector listing the specific defects in a building or structure no earlier than six (6) months after the adoption of this article requesting that he or she act to require the correction of the deterioration or the making of repairs. The chief building inspector will use the six-month timeframe to systematically inspect buildings and structures in the Central City Local Historic District and contact property owners to notify them of any violations. Correction or repairs will be required under the following procedures: 
(1)  Whenever a petition is filed with the chief building inspector or whenever it appears to the inspector (on his or her own motion or otherwise) that a building or structure is undergoing demolition by neglect, the inspector shall, if his preliminary investigation discovers a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner and/or parties in interest a complaint stating: 
a.  The charges, including a description of the condition causing the demolition by neglect, and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the chief building inspector in city hall, not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty (30) days after the serving of such complaint; 
b.  That the owner and/or parties of interest shall have the right to answer and give testimony at the hearing; 
c.  That the hardship review committee, as defined in this article, shall also be given notice of the hearing; and 
d.  That the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in the hearing before the inspector. 
(2)  The purpose of the hearing is to receive evidence concerning the charge of demolition by neglect and to consider any claim of undue economic hardship made by the owner and/or parties in interest. 
(3)  If, after such notice and hearing, the chief building inspector determines that the building or structure is undergoing demolition by neglect according to the standards listed in this article, the inspector shall state in writing the findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and/or parties in interest an order to repair within a stated time period, which time period shall be reasonable in terms of the amount of work required, those elements of the building or structure that are deteriorating, contributing to deterioration or deteriorated. 
(4)  Complaints or orders issued by the chief building inspector shall be served upon persons either personally, or by registered or certified mail. When service is made by registered or certified mail, a copy of the complaint or order may also be sent by regular mail. Service shall be deemed sufficient if the registered or certified mail is unclaimed or refused, but the regular mail is not returned by the post office within ten (10) days after the mailing. 
(5)  If the identities of any owners or the whereabouts of persons are unknown and cannot be ascertained by the chief building inspector in the exercise of reasonable diligence, or if the owners and or parties in interest are known but have refused to accept service by registered or certified mail, and the chief building inspector makes an affidavit to that effect, then the service of the complaint or order upon the owners and/or parties in interest may be made by publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the city at least once no later than the time at which personal service would be required under the provisions of this article. When service is made by publication, a notice of the pending proceedings shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the building or structure thereby affected. 
(6)  Failure on the part of any owner and/or parties of interest to receive or have served upon them any complaint, notice or order herein provided for, shall not affect or invalidate the proceedings with respect to any other owner or party in interest or any other person. 
(7)  In the event that the owner and/or other parties in interest wish to petition for a claim of undue economic hardship, the chief building inspector's order shall be stayed until after the hardship review committee's determination of such hardship. All claims of undue economic hardship shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the issuance of the order to repair the building or structure by filing such claim with the chief building inspector. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-138. - Safeguards from undue economic hardship. 
    When a claim of undue economic hardship is made, the chief building inspector shall notify the hardship review committee within ten (10) days following the receipt of such claim. The committee shall schedule a hearing on the claim within fifteen (15) days of receiving notice that a hearing is requested. Enforcement proceedings shall be stayed until the committee makes a decision. 
    When a claim of undue economic hardship is made owing to the effects of demolition by neglect, the burden of proof shall be upon the owner and/or parties in interest to provide evidence during the hearing upon the claim, describing the circumstances of the hardship, which shall include: 
(1)  Nature of ownership (individual, business or nonprofit) or legal possession, custody, control, residency and a description of the building or structure; 
(2)  Financial resources of the owner and/or parties of interest; 
(3)  Cost of repairs; 
(4)  Assessed value of the land and improvements; 
(5)  Real estate taxes for the previous two (2) years; 
(6)  Amount paid for the property, date of purchase and party from whom purchased, including a description of the relationship between the owner and the person from whom the property was purchased or other means of acquisition of title, such as by gift or inheritance; 
(7)  Annual debt service, if any, for previous two (2) years; 
(8)  Any listing of the property for sale or rent, price asked and offers received, if any; 
(9)  Proof of application status for historic tax credits as filed with the State of North Carolina; 
(10)  If the property is income producing: 
a.  Annual gross income from the property for last two (2) years; 
b.  Itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two (2) years, including proof that adequate and competent management procedures were followed; 
c.  Annual cash flow, if any, for the previous two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-139. - Committee's action on claim of undue hardship. 
    Within fifteen (15) days of the committee's hearing on a claim of undue economic hardship, the committee shall make a finding of undue or no undue hardship and shall enter the reasons for such finding into the record. In the event of a finding of no undue hardship, the committee shall report such a finding to the chief building inspector and the chief building inspector shall issue an order for such property to be repaired within the time recommended by the committee, if any, but not a shorter time than specified in the order originally issued by the inspector. 
    In the event of a finding of economic or other hardship, the finding may be accompanied by a recommendation to relieve the hardship. This plan may include, but is not limited to, loans or grants from the city or other public, private or nonprofit sources, acquisition by purchase, changes in applicable zoning regulations or relaxation of the provisions of this article sufficient to mitigate the hardship. The committee shall report the finding and plan to the chief building inspector. The inspector shall issue an order for such property to be repaired within a specified time and according to the provisions of the recommended plan. The hardship review committee may extend the deadline specified by the chief building inspector if substantial progress to remedy the situation is demonstrated. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-140. - Appeals. 
    Orders made by the chief building inspector or decisions of the hardship review committee may be appealed to the board of adjustment in accordance with the procedures found in the Land Development Code of the City of Rocky Mount. The aggrieved party must file the application for an appeal within thirty (30) days following the receipt of an order for repair of the building or structure or a determination by the committee on a claim for undue economic hardship. Decisions of the board of adjustment shall be subject to review by the superior court by proceedings in the nature of certiorari. Any petition for review by the superior court shall be filed with the clerk of superior court within thirty (30) days after the decision of the board of adjustment is filed or delivered as provided by the rules and procedures of the board. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-141. - Penalties and remedies. 
    Enforcement of this article may be by any one (1) or more of the following methods, and the institution of any such action shall not relieve any party from any other civil or criminal proceeding prescribed for herein. 
(1)  Equitable remedy. The city may apply to the court for any appropriate remedy to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Order of abatement. The city may apply for and the court may enter an order of abatement. An order of abatement may direct that improvements or repairs be made, within a time period therein specified, and that any other action be taken that is necessary to bring the property into compliance with this article. When the order of court so provides, and the city executes the order of abatement, the city shall have a lien against the real property upon which the cost of improvements or repairs were incurred to execute the order of abatement, which lien shall have the same priority and be collected as the lien for special assessments provided in G.S. ch. 160A, art. 10. 
(3)  Civil penalty. No civil penalty shall be levied unless and until the chief building inspector has delivered a written notice by personal service or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the person responsible for a violation stating the nature of the violation and ordering corrective action. The notice shall also set forth the time period when corrective measures must be completed. The notice shall state that the failure to correct the violation within the specified time period will result in the assessment of civil penalties and other enforcement action. If after the allotted time period has expired and after the hearing of an appeal, if any, by the board of adjustment, corrective action has not been completed, a civil penalty shall be assessed in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day of the continuing violation. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 5-142. - Other powers. 
    Nothing in this article shall diminish the city's power to declare a building unsafe or in violation of the minimum housing ordinance under the General Statutes of North Carolina or other public safety ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-126, § 1, 12-14-09) 
Secs. 5-143-5-160. - Reserved.

Chapter 6 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Cemeteries, G.S. § 65-37 et seq.; § 160A-341 et seq. 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cemeteries means the city's burial parks or cemeteries. 
    Cemetery lot means a numbered division as shown on the record plat. 
    Cemetery plot means a space of sufficient size to accommodate one (1) adult interment approximately five (5) by ten (10) feet. 
    Cemetery plot plan means the plot plan dated August 15, 1962, and its amendments. 
    Marker means a memorial flush with the ground. 
    Monument means a tombstone or memorial of granite or marble which extends above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1967, § 7-1; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-2. - Cemetery supervisor-Appointment. 
    The city manager shall appoint a competent person who shall have charge of the upkeep, protection and preservation of the cemeteries of the city, whose job title shall be cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1967, § 7-2; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1a., 9-9-02; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-3. - Same-General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the cemetery supervisor to supervise the digging of all graves and to supervise the laying out, posting and cleaning of all burial plots. In addition thereto, he shall see that all laws and regulations concerning the cemeteries are duly observed and enforced, and in case of any violation thereof, shall report the same in accordance with departmental policy. 
(Code 1967, § 7-3; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-4. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of the cemetery supervisor to report to the city clerk a record of all interments, disinterments, and lots sold in the cemeteries. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep such record. 
(Code 1967, § 7-5; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-5. - Map; contents. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep diagrams of all cemetery lots. The names of the owners and the individual names of all burials shall be recorded on the diagrams of lots that have been purchased. 
(Code 1967, § 7-6; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-6. - Purchase price of lots. 
    The purchase price of lots in the cemeteries shall be determined from time to time by the city council and published in the Administrative Policy Manual. 
(Code 1967, § 7-7; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1b., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-7. - Deeds to lots. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to deliver a deed to the purchaser of any lot in any of the city's cemeteries upon payment of the full purchase price. However, no person shall purchase more than eight (8) burial plots in the cemeteries unless approved by the city council. Such deed shall incorporate therein the provisions of sections 6-8 and 6-11 through 6-23. 
(Code 1967, § 7-8; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-8. - Transfer of lots. 
    No transfer or assignment shall be made of any cemetery lot without the written consent of the city manager. All such transfers or assignments shall be recorded in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 7-9; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-9. - Indigent burials; stillborn babies. 
    The city shall maintain a section, in one (1) or more of the city's cemeteries for the burial of indigent persons and stillborn babies or babies less than one (1) week old at the time of death. 
(1)  Indigent burials. To qualify for indigent burial, the deceased must meet the city's definition of indigent (See Administrative Policy No. X.4.2) and be certified as indigent by the appropriate department of social services. Charges for the burial plot and opening and closing of the grave shall be waived in the case of authorized indigent burials. 
(2)  Stillborn babies. Stillborn babies and babies less than one (1) week old at the time of death shall be eligible for burial in any section the city's cemeteries reserved for the burial of indigent persons. There shall be no charge for the burial plot, however, fees for opening and closing graves shall be applicable as set forth in Policy No. X.4.2 of the city's administrative policy manual. An exception shall be made if the parents qualify as indigent and fees for opening and closing shall not be charged. 
(3)  Residency required. To qualify for indigent burial the deceased must be a resident of the City of Rocky Mount at the time of death, or, in the case of stillborn babies, or babies less than one (1) week old at the time of death, the parents or guardians must be city residents. Notwithstanding the above, applicants who were residents of the city but relocated to an assisted living, retirement or nursing facility outside the city limits within three (3) years prior to death shall be considered residents for the purposes of this policy. There shall be no residency exceptions for burial of stillborn babies or babies less than one (1) week old at the time of death. 
(4)  Application required. Applications for the burial of indigent persons or stillborn babies or babies less than one (1) week old at the time of death shall be submitted to the city clerk's office. Applications must be made by next of kin or someone who has authority to act on behalf of the deceased and accompanied by certification from the appropriate department of social services that the deceased meets the city's criteria for indigence. Applications will be considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the criteria set forth in Administrative Policy No. X.4.2, taking into consideration such factors, as the ability of family members to pay the burial costs, the amount of the bill from the funeral home and how the charges are expected to be paid, or expected financial assistance. 
(5)  Markers and monuments. Markers and monuments shall not be permitted on graves in the areas of the city's cemeteries reserved for indigent burials. A burial space will be assigned and the city will keep a record of such including the name of the deceased, the burial location and the date of burial. 
(6)  Scheduling burials. The final decision on scheduling burials under this section shall rest with the cemetery supervisor or designee. Funeral directors scheduling such burials shall contact the cemetery supervisor or designee at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to scheduling any burials under this section. No burial time shall be promised, nor assumed without the consent of the cemetery supervisor or designee. 
(7)  Weekend/holiday burials restricted. No burials under this section shall be scheduled for weekends or official holidays. All burials shall be scheduled at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance and no burial shall be scheduled to begin later than 2:30 p.m. There shall be no exception to this rule. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-92, § 1, 10-31-11; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2011-92, § 1, adopted Oct. 31, 2011, amended § 6-9 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 6-9 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1967, § 7-10; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1c., adopted Sept. 9, 2002; Ord. No. O-08-117, § 1, adopted Sept. 22, 2008. 
Sec. 6-10. - Opening and closing of graves; fees. 
    The opening and closing of graves for all interments and disinterments in the cemeteries shall be done by the city under the supervision of the cemetery supervisor unless under a court order. The fees for opening and closing a grave in the cemeteries shall be determined from time to time by the city council and published in the Administrative Policy Manual. 
(Code 1967, § 7-11; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1d., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-11. - Submission of burial permit prior to interment or disinterment. 
    A burial permit shall be submitted to the cemetery supervisor by a licensed funeral director at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to any interment. Notice shall be given at least one (1) week prior to any disinterment. 
(Code 1967, § 7-12; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1e., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-12. - Cremations. 
    The cemetery supervisor must be notified of cremation burials in accordance with the provisions of section 6-11. The burial of cremated remains shall be done by the city and the standard fee for the opening and closing of graves shall be charged. The scattering of ashes across the cemetery plot is prohibited. 
    One (1) cremated body may be buried on a cemetery plot with the exception that the cremated remains of any two (2) members of the same family may be buried on a single plot. 
    For the purposes of this section, family members shall be defined as wife, husband, mother, father daughter, son, sister, brother, grandmother, grandfather, granddaughter and grandson. 
(Ord. No. 0-92-96, § 1, 12-14-92; Ord. No. 0-93-8, § 1, 1-25-93) 
Sec. 6-13. - Grave liners. 
(a)  Concrete or steel grave liners shall be used for all burials in city-owned cemeteries except in the areas designated for indigent burials and except for the burial of cremation urns. The minimum requirements for concrete vaults shall be one and one-half-inch average sidewall thickness, two-inch top thickness, two-inch bottom thickness with four thousand five hundred (4,500) psi. The minimum requirement for a steel vault shall be twelve-gauge thickness top, sides and bottom. Concrete or steel grave liners may be installed with bottoms left open upon request by the family of the deceased. 
(b)  If not already in compliance, all disinterments that are to be relocated to another area of the city's cemeteries shall be placed in a vault or liner as described in subsection (a) above. If any old vault or liner exists, it must be physically solid enough to withstand the disinterment. It shall be the responsibility of the cemetery supervisor to make this determination. If the supervisor deems the vault or liner unacceptable, it shall be replaced at the expense of the property owner, the property owner's estate or duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 0-88-25, § 1, 3-14-88; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1f., 9-9-02; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-14. - Application of rules, regulations. 
    All cemetery lots shall be held subject to all rules and regulations governing the cemeteries, either now in force or that may be hereafter prescribed by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 7-15; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1g., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-15. - Monuments-Location. 
(a)  Monuments shall be allowed or permitted only in those sections or portions of sections of the cemeteries as approved by the city council and as shown on the cemetery map. 
(b)  Monuments shall not be permitted within the areas in the cemeteries designated for indigent burials. 
(c)  Monuments shall not be allowed or permitted in Section Thirteen of Northeastern Cemetery. 
(Code 1967, § 7-17; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1h., 9-9-02; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-16. - Same-Number. 
    Only one (1) central family monument shall be allowed on a family lot in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1967, § 7-18) 
Sec. 6-17. - Same-Dimensions. 
    The face area of any monument shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the superficial area of the lot, its base length shall not exceed sixty (60) percent of the average width of the lot and its base width shall not exceed two (2) feet. Where there are four (4) or more graves, the base width may be a maximum of two (2) feet ten (10) inches. 
(Code 1967, § 7-19) 
Sec. 6-18. - Same-Materials. 
    Monuments of concrete, artificial stone, composition, wood, tin, iron or similar materials shall not be permitted within the cemeteries. 
(Code 1967, § 7-20) 
Sec. 6-19. - Same-Foundation. 
    Monuments shall be placed only on foundations approved by the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1967, § 7-21) 
Sec. 6-20. - Grave markers. 
(a)  Grave markers shall not exceed one (1) foot in width and two (2) feet in length and shall have a minimum of four-inch thickness and shall be placed at the end of the grave farthest from the monument or as specified in the cemetery plot plan. 
(b)  Grave markers must be set flush with the ground. 
(Code 1967, § 7-22; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1i., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-21. - Mausoleums and tombs. 
(a)  Mausoleums or tombs may be constructed only on lots designated for that purpose as shown on the cemetery map. 
(b)  Specifications and the locations of the mausoleums or tombs on the lot shall be approved by the city manager or other such officers as the city council may designate. 
(c)  Mausoleums or tombs shall be erected so as to leave at least two (2) feet clearance from all lot boundary lines. 
(Code 1967, § 7-23; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-22. - Care and upkeep. 
(a)  The general care and upkeep of the cemeteries including all grading, landscaping and improvements is assumed by the city; however, the general care assumed by the city shall in no case mean the maintenance, repair or replacement of any memorial, tomb or mausoleum placed or erected upon lots; nor the doing of any special or unusual work in the cemetery, nor does it mean the reconstruction of any marble or granite work on any section of the plot, or any portion thereof in the cemetery caused by the elements, an act of nature, enemy, thieves, vandals, strikes, malicious mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions, insurrections, riots or by order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage is direct or collateral, other than as herein provided. 
(b)  If any monument, mausoleum, tomb or marker or ornament becomes unsafe, unsightly or in need of repair or resetting, the city, after giving notice to the owner of such condition and upon the failure of the owner to correct the condition within thirty (30) days after receiving the notice, reserves the right to correct or remove the same at the expense of the owner. 
(Code 1967, § 7-24; Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1j., 9-9-02; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-23. - Shrubs and plants. 
(a)  No shrubs, plants or ornaments shall be planted upon any cemetery lot except as the same may be permitted by any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation. 
(b)  No copings, curb fencing, hedges, grave mounds or borders of any kind shall be allowed on any cemetery lot. 
(c)  The cemetery supervisor or his duly authorized agent shall have the authority to remove all floral designs, flowers, weeds, trees, shrubs, plants or herbage of any kind from the cemetery as soon as in the judgment of the cemetery supervisor they become unsightly, dangerous, detrimental or diseased, or when they do not conform to the standards maintained for the cemeteries. 
(Code 1967, § 7-25; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-24. - Use as playground. 
    No person shall use any part of any cemetery within the city as a playground. 
(Code 1967, § 7-26) 
Sec. 6-25. - Discharge of firearms. 
    No person shall discharge any firearm within any cemetery within the city except as a lawful part of any recognized funeral service. 
(Code 1967, § 7-27) 
Sec. 6-26. - Use of motor vehicles, animals. 
    No person shall drive or ride any motor vehicle in the cemeteries at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour or lead any animal or drive any motor vehicle over, upon or across any burial plot in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1967, § 7-28; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Sec. 6-27. - Defacing monuments, burial plots. 
    No person shall dig up, remove, injure or destroy any stake or grave stone or other monument placed or erected on a grave, or any burial plot without the permission of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1967, § 7-29) 
Sec. 6-28. - Unauthorized removal or damage to flowers, ornaments, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the cemetery supervisor or his duly authorized agent, or a member of the owner's family or their duly authorized agent, to cut down, pluck or otherwise remove, injure or destroy any flowers, bulbs, vines, shrubbery or trees planted in the cemetery except under the supervision or with the approval of the cemetery supervisor, or to remove any flowers or other ornaments or any vase, basket or receptacle from any lot except under the supervision and with the approval of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1967, § 7-30) 
Sec. 6-29. - Litter. 
    No person shall deposit any rubbish, filth, waste or other unclean or unsightly substance in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1967, § 7-31) 
Sec. 6-30. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Any firm that performs a service of any type in any city owned cemetery such as installing vaults; installing monuments, mausoleums, or grave markers; setting up or taking down tents; directing funerals; or other work and services shall furnish the cemetery supervisor a current certificate of insurance for the following types of insurance coverage: 
(1)  Workers compensation as required by law; 
(2)  Comprehensive automobile liability insurance coverage with a combined single limit of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per accident for bodily injury and property damage; 
(3)  Standard comprehensive general liability insurance providing coverage for operations, products, and completed operations coverage with a combined single limit of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) at any city owned cemetery. 
(Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1k., 9-9-02) 
Sec. 6-31. - Installation of monuments, grave markers, mausoleums or tombs. 
(a)  A monument permit shall be submitted to the cemetery supervisor prior to any installation of a monument, grave marker, mausoleum or tomb. 
(b)  All installations of monuments, grave markers, mausoleums or tombs will occur during regular cemetery office hours. 
(Ord. No. O-02-82, § 1l., 9-9-02; Ord. No. O-2012-71, § 1(Att.), 7-23-12) 
Chapter 7 - EXPLOSIVES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Gas, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Regulation of explosive substances, G.S. § 160A-183. 

Sec. 7-1. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful to explode or otherwise use blasting agents and any dangerous explosives within the corporate limits of the city or within one (1) mile thereof except as provided in this chapter and the North Carolina State Fire Prevention Code. 
(Code 1967, § 27-1; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1A, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-2. - Storage. 
    No dangerous explosive shall be stored within the corporate limits of the city or within one (1) mile thereof unless the explosive is for immediate use and all provisions of the North Carolina State Fire Prevention Code have been complied with. Blasting caps and explosive materials shall be brought to the site of the permitted explosion in separate magazines. 
(Code 1967, § 27-2; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1A, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-3. - Permit-Required. 
    Any person desiring to use dangerous explosives within the corporate limits of the city or within one (1) mile thereof shall first apply for and obtain a permit for the same from the fire marshal. 
(Code 1967, § 27-3; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1A, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-4. - Application. 
    Application for a permit under this chapter shall be made on forms provided by the fire marshal. A copy shall be sent to the director of engineering. The application shall contain: 
(1)  The date, time and place of the proposed explosion or other use; 
(2)  The purpose of the same; 
(3)  The nature and amount of the dangerous explosive to be exploded or otherwise used; 
(4)  A full description of the manner in which the dangerous explosive is to be exploded or otherwise used, including all safety devices to be used and precautions to be taken to ensure that there will be no damage to person or property as a result of the same. 
(5)  A scaled site plan displaying the proposed blasting site, inhabited structure, public traffic route or utilities within a one-thousand-foot radius of any proposed magazine. 
(Code 1967, § 27-4; Ord. No. O-2011-111, §§ 1B, C, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-5. - Fee. 
    The application for a permit required under this chapter shall be accompanied by the payment of a nonrefundable fee to cover the cost of examining and investigating the same which shall be set by the city council and published in the Manual of Fees and Charges. 
(Code 1967, § 27-5; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1B, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-6. - Investigation of applicant; approval or disapproval; insurance requirements. 
(a)  Upon receiving an application for a permit under this chapter, the fire marshal shall examine the same and make such investigation in connection therewith as he deems necessary including the qualifications and experience of the individual proposing to do the blasting. 
(b)  If after examining such application and making such investigation the fire marshal finds that the proposed explosion or other use of dangerous explosives can be done safely and without danger of damage to person or property, he shall advise the applicant in writing that a permit for the same will be issued upon receipt of evidence that the applicant has and will keep in force when engaged in such explosion or other use a policy or policies of insurance providing coverage irrespective of negligence on the part of the user for the benefit of any person whose person or property is damaged as a result of such use in the sum of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) for injury suffered by any one (1) person or one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for damage done to any single piece of property with such coverage including explosion and collapse. Upon receipt of such evidence the fire marshal shall issue the permit. 
(c)  If after examining such application and making such examination the fire marshal is of the opinion that such proposed explosion or other use cannot be done safely or without the danger of damage to person or property or such applicant does not furnish the fire marshal evidence that the applicant has and will keep in effect when engaged in such explosion or other use the insurance required hereby, the fire marshal shall refuse to issue the permit applied for. 
(Code 1967, § 27-6; Ord. No. O-2011-111, §§ 1B, C, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-7. - Issuance of permit for continual operation. 
    If an applicant for a permit under this chapter desires to explode or otherwise use dangerous explosives for a series of explosions or other use over a continuous period of time, the fire marshal may issue a permit for the same upon compliance with the provisions of section 7-6, except that such period of time shall not be for greater than six (6) months. The permit shall apply only to explosions or other use at the single site and shall be revocable at any time the fire marshal finds either of the following: 
(1)  Persons or property have been damaged as the result of such explosions or other use; 
(2)  There is danger that persons or property may be damaged from the continuation of such explosions or other use; or 
(3)  The insurance required under this chapter is no longer in effect. 
(Code 1967, § 27-7; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1C, 11-28-11) 
Sec. 7-8. - Appeal from permit denial. 
    If the fire marshal refuses to issue a permit required by this chapter to an applicant, or after issuing the same revokes it, and the applicant feels aggrieved thereby, the applicant may appeal the decision of the fire marshal with respect to the same to the city council which may, after a hearing upon the matter, either sustain the action taken by the fire marshal or overrule the same and direct that the permit applied for be issued or that the permit revoked be reinstated. 
(Code 1967, § 27-8; Ord. No. O-2011-111, § 1C, 11-28-11) 
Chapter 8 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire limits established, § 5-2; explosives, Ch. 7; gas, Ch. 9; use of unlined chimney as a gas vent prohibited, § 9-25; use of existing flues to vent gas appliances restricted, § 9-26; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 10; housing, Ch. 11; solid waste, Ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19; rollerskates, skateboards prohibited within the fire district, § 19-8; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 21; subdivisions, App. A; zoning, App. B. 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, G.S. § 14-286; investigation of fires and inspection of premises, G.S. § 58-79.1 et seq.; state volunteer fire department, G.S. §§ 58-80.1 et seq.; safety precautions in hotels, G.S. §§ 58-81.5 et seq.; power of the town to restrict, regulate and prohibit the keeping, use, etc., of explosives, inflammable substances, etc., see G.S. § 160A-183. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Flammable signs, banners, etc. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit any sign, banner, flag or pennant made of paper, cloth, oil cloth, plastic or similar flammable material to be posted, hung or otherwise affixed to or made to stand or lean against or suspended between any building, marquee, wall, fence, post, pole, gasoline pump or otherwise within the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Billboards that have been licensed, inspected and approved by the city building inspector; 
(2)  Construction signs posted on property where the construction is being carried on; 
(3)  Signs posted for the safety of the public; 
(4)  United States, State of North Carolina and other official flags or flags of civic, charitable and fraternal organizations; 
(5)  Signs, banners, flags or pennants placed upon privately owned premises calling attention to events being or to be carried on or conducted on the premises; 
(6)  Banners suspended across the street in accordance with policies approved by the city council. 
(c)  Any person desiring to temporarily display a sign, banner, flag or pennant which would otherwise be unlawful under subsection (a) above may do so after first obtaining a permit for the same from the city manager. The permit shall be issued by the city manager, provided that: 
(1)  The sign, banner, flag or pennant is of special interest to the people of the city. 
(2)  The person wishing to display the same: 
a.  Furnishes to the city manager a list of the locations at which the signs, banners, flags or pennants are to be displayed; the number of each to be displayed at each such location; the length of time each will be so displayed; and written evidence that the property owner upon whose property the same are to be displayed has consented to the same. 
b.  Agrees in writing that the signs, banners, flags or pennants shall be removed by him or at his expense not later than the expiration date of the permit. 
(3)  The sign, banner, flag or pennant does not violate any of the provisions of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 8-2) 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, App. B, § X. 
Sec. 8-2. - Parade floats to contain flameproof materials. 
    All floats participating in parades within the city shall contain flameproof materials approved by the fire marshal. 
(Code 1967, § 8-3; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.A., 10-11-10) 
Cross reference- Parades and demonstrations, § 19-81 et seq. 
Secs. 8-3-8-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE MARSHAL'S OFFICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., adopted Oct. 11, 2010, amended art. II in its entirety as set out herein. Formerly, art. II pertained to life safety/emergency management division. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Inspection services advisory committee, § 2-116 et seq. 

Sec. 8-26. - Organization. 
(a)  The fire marshal's office shall consist of the fire marshal and other inspectors or deputy or assistant inspectors as authorized by the city council. 
(b)  For the purpose of this chapter, whenever the designation "fire marshal" is made it shall include any duly authorized inspector or deputy or assistant inspectors of the fire marshal's office. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-27. - General duties of division and inspectors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the fire marshal's office to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory codes adopted herein, and to make all inspections necessary to determine whether or not the provisions of this chapter and such codes are being met. 
(b)  The current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the fire marshal's office. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-28. - Conflicts of interest. 
    No officer or employee of the fire marshal's office shall be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building or any part thereof, unless he is the owner of such building. No officer or employee of the fire marshal's office shall engage in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-29. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The fire marshal's office and the fire marshal shall keep complete and accurate records in convenient form of all applications received, permits issued, inspections and reinspections made, and all other work and activities of the fire marshal's office. Periodic reports shall be submitted to the fire chief, city manager and other agencies as required. 
(b)  All applications, inspections, reinspections, and maintenance reports, and any and all other reports and submissions required by law to be made to the fire marshal's office shall be submitted in a manner and format, and by a method prescribed by the fire marshal within five (5) business days after the inspection, reinspection, test, maintenance activity, or other activity required by law with respect to fire prevention and fire protection has been completed. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10; Ord. No. O-2017-13, § 1, 2-27-17) 
Sec. 8-30. - Inspection procedure. 
(a)  Inspections. 
(1)  The fire marshal's office shall inspect all buildings with the exception of one- and two-family dwellings periodically to determine that all buildings, structures and processes are in compliance with this chapter and the appropriate code. In accordance with the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, all occupancies shall be inspected no less than the following schedule: 
Once every year: Hazardous, institutional, highrise, assembly (except churches and synagogues), residential (except one- and two-family dwellings and only interior common areas of dwelling units of multi-family occupancies). 
Once every two (2) years: Industrial and educational (except public schools). 
Once every three (3) years: Business, mercantile, storage, churches and synagogues. 
Frequency rates for inspection of occupancies mandated by N.C. General Statutes shall supersede this section. Nothing in this section is intended to prevent the fire marshal's office from conducting more frequent inspections than the schedule prescribed in this section. 
(2)  When deemed necessary by the fire marshal's office, materials and assemblies may be inspected at the point of manufacture or fabrication or inspections may be made by approved and recognized organizations. No approval shall be based upon reports of such organizations unless the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such organization. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-31. - Oversight does not legalize violation. 
    No oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of the fire marshal or other official employee of the fire marshal's office shall be deemed to legalize the violation of any provisions of this chapter or any provision of any regulatory codes adopted in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-32. - Powers of fire code officials. 
(a)  Authority. The fire marshal and other inspectors or deputy or assistant inspectors as authorized by the city council are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and the regulatory codes adopted in this chapter. 
(b)  Right of entry. The fire marshal and other inspectors or deputy or assistant inspectors as authorized by the city council shall have the right of entry on any premises except one- and two-family dwellings, within the jurisdiction of the regulatory codes adopted in this chapter at reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection or enforcement of the requirements of this chapter and the regulatory codes, upon presentation of proper credentials. 
(c)  Stop-work orders. Whenever any building or structure or part thereof is being demolished, constructed, reconstructed, altered or repaired in a hazardous manner, or in violation of any provisions of this chapter, or in violation of any regulatory codes adopted in this chapter, or in violation of the terms of the permit or permits issued therefor, or in such a manner as to endanger life or property, the fire marshal and other inspectors or deputy or assistant inspectors as authorized by the city council may order such work to be immediately stopped. Such order shall be in writing to the owner of the property or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the reasons therefor and the conditions under which the work may be resumed. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.B., 10-11-10) 
Secs. 8-33-8-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 8-53. - Fire code permit required. 
    No person shall commence or proceed to maintain, store, or handle materials, or conduct processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or to install equipment used in connection with such activities, which are required by this chapter, or any provisions of the regulatory codes adopted in this chapter without first obtaining a written permit from the fire marshal. 
    Such fire prevention permit shall not be a substitute for any other permits or license required by this code or other law. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1a, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., adopted Oct. 11, 2010, changed the title of § 8-53 from "Fire prevention code permit required" to "Fire code permit required." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 8-54. - Application. 
    Written application shall be made for all permits required by the fire marshal's office and shall be made on forms provided by the fire marshal's office. The application shall be made by the owner or occupant of the building, structure or vessel affected or by his authorized agent or representative and, in addition to such other information as may be required by the fire marshal to enable him to determine whether the permit applied for should be issued, shall show the following: 
(1)  Name, business address, and telephone number of the owner; 
(2)  Name, business address, and telephone number of the authorized representative or agent, if any; 
(3)  A statement of the intended use of the building or structure or operation to be conducted on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, §§ 1a, 1b, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-55. - Submission of plans, specifications. 
    Detailed plans and specifications shall accompany each application for a permit under this article when required by the fire marshal in order for him to determine whether the proposed work complies with the appropriate regulatory codes or ordinances. Plans shall be drawn to scale with sufficient clarity to indicate the nature or extent of the work or process proposed, and the plans and specifications together shall contain information sufficient to indicate that the work or process proposed will conform to the provisions of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1a, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-56. - Issuance. 
    When proper application for a permit has been made, and the fire marshal is satisfied that the application and the proposed work or processes comply with the provisions of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes, he shall issue such permit, upon payment of proper fee or fees as provided in section 8-60. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1a, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-57. - Revocation. 
    The fire marshal may revoke and require the return of any permit issued under this article by notifying the permit holder in writing the reason for the revocation. Permits shall be revoked for any material departure from the approved application, plans or specifications; for refusal or failure to comply with requirements of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes; or for false statements or misrepresentations made in securing a permit. A new permit may be issued when compliance has been obtained. A new permit fee will be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1a, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-58. - Time limitations on validity. 
    All permits issued under this article shall expire by limitation twelve (12) months after the date of issuance, with exception of open burning permits and other special use permits which will expire within the time limitations indicated on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98) 
Sec. 8-59. - Changes in work or use after approval. 
    After a permit has been issued, changes or deviations from the terms of the application and permit, or changes and deviations from the plans or specifications involving any work under the jurisdiction of this chapter or of any regulatory codes adopted herein shall not be made until specific written approval of such deviations has been obtained from the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1a, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Sec. 8-60. - Fees. 
    Fees for the following permits under this article shall be as set forth in the city's administrative policy manual: 
(1)  Permits by use; 
(2)  Open burning permit fees; 
(3)  Special use permits; 
(4)  General inspection fees; 
(5)  Plans review fees; 
(6)  Operational permits; and 
(7)  Construction permits. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.C., 10-11-10) 
Secs. 8-61-8-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE STANDARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-2010-84, § 1.D., adopted Oct. 11, 2010, changed the title of art. IV from "North Carolina Fire Prevention Code Standards" to "Fire Prevention Code Standards." 

Sec. 8-71. - The current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code adopted. 
    The current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, as adopted by North Carolina Building Code Council and as amended, is hereby adopted by reference as though fully set forth herein as the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code for the city to the extent such code is applicable for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, § 1c, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.D., 10-11-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.D., adopted Oct. 11, 2010, changed the title of § 8-71 from "North Carolina Fire Prevention Code adopted" to "The current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code adopted." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 8-72. - Amendments to code. 
    Amendments to the regulatory codes adopted by reference in this article, which are from time to time adopted and published by the agencies or organizations referred to herein shall be effective in the city at the time such amendments are filed with the city clerk as provided in section 8-73. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98) 
Sec. 8-73. - Copies of codes and amendments filed with clerk. 
    An official copy of the regulatory code adopted in this article, and official copies of amendments thereto, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. Such copies shall be official copies of the codes and amendments. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98) 
Sec. 8-74. - Penalties for violations of fire prevention code. 
(a)  Compliance responsibility for enforcement. Compliance with the provisions of this chapter, including all requirements of the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code adopted herein, shall be enforced by the fire marshal. The fire marshal, in exercising his enforcement responsibilities, shall employ enforcement alternatives that most effectively secure compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Violations. Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, including the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code adopted herein, or who shall erect, alter or repair in violation of any specifications or plans submitted and approved herein, shall be deemed to have committed a violation of this chapter, including the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, or any lawful order issued or plan approved herein; or any architect, builder, contractor, engineer, agent or other person who acts in concert, participates, directs or assists in the creation or maintenance of a violation of this article or any order issued or plan approved herein; or any person who shall erect or use any land, building or structure or any part thereof contrary to this article, the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, any order issued or plan approved herein; or any person who shall omit, neglect or refuse to do any act provided for in this article, including the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, or any order issued or plan approved herein, shall be held responsible for a violation of this chapter and be subject to the penalties and remedies herein provided. 
(c)  Penalties and remedies. Enforcement may be by any one (1) or a combination of the following methods, and the institution of an action under any of these methods shall not relieve any party from any other criminal or civil proceeding prescribed for violations. 
(1)  Criminal offense. A violation of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor offense as provided by General Statutes section 14-4, and the maximum fine or term of imprisonment, or both, as authorized by law is hereby imposed. 
(2)  Civil penalty. Any act constituting a violation shall subject the offender to a civil penalty in the following amounts: 
Any person, firm, corporation or agent who shall violate any technical provisions of the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code which creates an imminent safety to life shall be subject to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. 
Any person, firm, corporation or agent who shall exceed any lawfully posted occupancy shall be subject to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per person in excess of the posted occupancy. 
Any person, firm, corporation or agent who shall lock, block or obstruct an exit shall be subject to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per exit for a first violation, two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per exit for a second violation and five hundred dollars ($500.00) per exit for a third and all subsequent violations. 
No penalty shall be assessed until the person alleged to be in violation has been notified of the violation by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service (inspection). Any fire inspection officer who has a reason to believe that a violation of this chapter or the aforesaid technical provisions of the current edition of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code has been committed shall either send a civil penalty citation to the violator by certified mail or personally deliver such citation to the violator stating the nature of the violation, the penalty to be imposed upon the violator, and shall direct the violator to pay the penalty to the City Clerk, P. O. Drawer 1180, Rocky Mount, 27801 within fifteen (15) days of receipt. 
(3)  Appeals to civil penalty. Any person(s) cited for violating any provisions of this chapter may appeal such civil penalty to the fire chief, no later than five (5) business days from issuance of the civil penalty. The appeal shall be in writing and shall state appellant reason(s) for filing such appeal. The fire chief shall investigate such appeal, and shall render a decision based on evidence shown no later than five (5) business days from date appeal was filed. Such findings of the fire chief shall be in writing and shall be binding. 
(Ord. No. 0-98-21, § 2, 3-9-98; Ord. No. 0-06-99, §§ 1a, 1c, 1d, 12-11-06; Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.D., 10-11-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-84, § 1.D., adopted Oct. 11, 2010, changed the title of § 8-74 from "Penalties for violations of North Carolina Fire Prevention Code" to "Penalties for violations of fire prevention code." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Chapter 9 - GAS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; explosives, Ch. 7; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; housing, Ch. 11; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 13; utilities, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Interfering with gas appliances; G.S. § 14-151. 

Sec. 9-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known or may be cited as the gas ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 24-1) 
Sec. 9-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer means any person using gas, including gas for residential, commercial or industrial purposes or any combination of such purposes. 
    Gas means artificial gas, natural gas or mixed gas consisting of both artificial and natural gas; undiluted liquefied petroleum gas; butane gas. 
    Gas appliance means any appliance or device utilizing gas in its operation. 
    Gas distributor means a person or company holding and exercising a franchise, license or permit to distribute gas within the gas service area of the city, including the gas division of the utility department of the city. 
    Gas facility means piping, fittings, meters or other devices used for the distribution, transmission or delivery of gas to or for use in gas appliances. 
    Gas service area of the city means that area embraced within the corporate limits of the city and within one (1) mile thereof. 
    Permittee means a person having a valid permit issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Vent and vent connector means a pipe, flue or chimney designed or installed to carry the products of combustion from a gas appliance to the outside atmosphere. 
(Code 1967, § 24-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 9-3. - Standards applicable. 
    The construction, installation, extension, maintenance, alteration or repair of any gas facility, gas appliance, vent or vent connector, or any other work pertaining to gas facilities and gas appliances within the purview of this chapter shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and with the requirements, standards and provisions of the National Fuel Gas Code (ANSI Z223.1-1988; NFPA54-1988), Volume III, North Carolina State Building Code, 1980 Edition with amendments, "American Standard Requirements for Installation of Domestic Gas Conversion Burners," current edition (ANSI Z21.8-1971 with addendums), and section 2 of the "American Standard Code for Gas and Air Piping in Industrial Installations" (A.S.A. B31, section 2). All such code provisions are on file in the office of the city clerk and available for public inspection, and are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in this chapter to the same extent as if included in verbatim from and constituting standards of the city for the purposes of this chapter. If any of the provisions of such codes conflict with any of the provisions of this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall govern and be controlling. All amendments and additions to the provisions of the codes cited in this section shall before becoming effective be adopted by reference by the city council and shall be filed with the city clerk. Such amendments or additions thereupon shall become amendments and additions hereto and shall have the same force and effect as the original codes herein identified. 
(Code 1967, § 24-3) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; housing, Ch. 11; utilities, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 9-4. - Adoption of standards for liquefied petroleum gas. 
    All the provisions and requirements of the standards for the design, installation and construction of containers and pertinent equipment for the storage and handling of liquefied petroleum gases, as recommended by the National Fire Protection Association's copyrighted pamphlet No. 58, 1986 with addendums, are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as fully and completely as though set out herein in verbatim. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with such provisions and requirements within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 24-4) 
Sec. 9-5. - Liability of city. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee thereof any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured by any defect in any gas facility or appliance or by any work in connection therewith; nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof be deemed to have assumed any such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized hereunder or by the issuance of any certificate of approval, permit or license hereunder by the inspections services division. 
(Code 1967, § 24-5) 
Sec. 9-6. - Enforcement. 
    The inspections services division shall and is authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this chapter. The city shall promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and regulations for the carrying out the provisions and intent of this chapter. The inspections services division, upon presentation of proper credentials, may enter any building or premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making inspections and ascertaining whether there has been compliance with the provisions of this chapter. It shall be the duty of the division to confer, from time to time, with appropriate representatives of the gas company, the local health department and the local fire department and otherwise obtain from proper sources all helpful information and advice respecting the safe and proper operations of gas facilities and gas appliances, and the division shall present to the city council recommendations for its consideration with reference thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 24-7) 
Sec. 9-7. - Permit required. 
    No construction, installation, extension, alteration or repair of a gas facility or the gas control components of a gas appliance shall be done unless the person doing the work first obtains a permit therefor from the inspection services division; provided, however, that a permit is not required for adjusting any gas appliance or for the repair of leaks in any gas facility in which the supplying meter was not locked due to an unsafe condition. Each permit shall state the kind of work to be performed thereunder and that it shall be designated in the permit. Such permit shall also state the location by street and number of the consumer's premises where such work is to be done and shall be valid only for the location so stated. A separate permit shall be issued for each consumer's premises and shall terminate one hundred eighty (180) days after issuance unless extended by the inspections services division for good and sufficient cause. The city shall collect a fee in accordance with the schedule of fees adopted by the city council and on file in the office of the supervisor of inspections. 
(Code 1967, § 24-12; Ord. No. 0-02-104, § 1a, 11-11-02) 
Sec. 9-8. - Effect of permit. 
    The issuance or granting of a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall not be deemed or construed to be a permit for or approval of any violation of the provisions hereof or any other applicable law. No permit purporting to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter shall be valid. 
(Code 1967, § 24-13) 
Sec. 9-9. - Temporary use of gas. 
    When only the temporary use of gas is desired, the inspections services division, upon application, may issue a permit for the temporary use for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days, provided that the consumer's gas facility is given a test similar to that required for any facility for which a longer use is contemplated. 
(Code 1967, § 24-14) 
Sec. 9-10. - Interfering with gas company facilities. 
    No person, unless in the employ of the gas company or having express authorization of the gas company shall repair, alter or open a gas facility of the gas company or set or remove a gas service meter or do any other work on the gas supply system of the gas company. 
(Code 1967, § 24-15) 
Sec. 9-11. - Emergency repairs. 
    In the event of any emergency endangering the life, health, safety or property of any person necessitating immediate repairs to any gas facility or gas appliance, such emergency repairs may be done without first obtaining the permit required by this chapter. Not later than the next succeeding business day the permit required under this chapter shall be applied for. 
(Code 1967, § 24-16) 
Sec. 9-12. - Notice requesting inspection. 
    When any work done under a permit issued by the inspections services division is completed and ready for inspection, the person to whom the permit has been issued shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after completion, give notice to the gas inspector that the same has been completed and is ready for inspection. The inspections services division shall cause the work to be inspected within forty-eight (48) hours thereafter to see that the work done conforms to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 24-17) 
Sec. 9-13. - Certificate of approval. 
    Upon the completion of the work for which a permit has been issued the inspections services division shall issue a certificate of approval if, after inspection, it is found that such work has complied with the provisions of this chapter and has been performed in full conformity with this chapter. A duplicate of each certificate of approval shall be delivered to the gas company and used as its authority to grant gas service. The form and contents of such certificate shall be prescribed by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 24-18) 
Sec. 9-14. - Disconnection of dangerous or defective facilities. 
    The inspections services division is authorized to cause to be disconnected any gas facility or appliance connected before a certificate of approval has been issued which upon inspection is found defective or in such condition as to endanger life, health, safety or property. In all cases where such disconnection is made a notice shall be affixed thereto and shall state that the same has been disconnected by the inspections services division, together with the reason or reasons therefor, and it shall be unlawful for any person to remove the notice or to reconnect the gas facility or appliance until authorized by the inspections services division to do so. 
(Code 1967, § 24-19) 
Sec. 9-15. - Privilege license. 
    No person shall construct, install, extend, alter, repair or improve any gas facility or gas appliance within the gas service area of the city unless such person has first procured a privilege license therefor from the inspections services division, or unless such person works under the direct supervision of a licensed gas serviceman. All applications for such license shall be in writing, upon forms to be prescribed by the city. All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire June 30 next following the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked as herein provided, shall be nontransferable and shall be posted conspicuously to public view in the principal place of business of the licensee. 
(Code 1967, § 24-20) 
Sec. 9-16. - Liability insurance, bond required. 
    Before any license is granted to any person as provided in this chapter, such person shall file with the city a certificate or other evidence that he has in force a comprehensive general liability insurance policy including products liability-completed operations, with coverage for the hazards of explosion, collapse and damage to underground equipment, with limits of not less than one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) bodily injury for any one (1) accident and sixty thousand dollars ($60,000.00) property damage for any one (1) accident. Such policy shall be issued by an insurer licensed to do business in the state and may be procured in the name of the person by which the licensee is employed. In addition such person shall give a good and sufficient bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Code 1967, § 24-21) 
Sec. 9-17. - Rough piping inspection. 
    Rough piping inspections shall be made by the inspections services division after all piping authorized by the permit has been installed, before such piping has been covered or concealed or any fixture or gas appliance has been attached thereto (ANSI Z223.1, NFPA54). 
(Code 1967, § 24-22) 
Sec. 9-18. - Final piping inspection. 
    Test or final piping inspection for the city shall be made by the inspection services division after all piping authorized by the permit has been installed and after all portions thereof which are to be concealed by plaster or otherwise have been installed but before being concealed and before any fixtures or gas appliances have been attached thereto. This inspection shall include the test procedure for gas piping in accordance with the International Fuel Gas Code (§ 406.4.1). All tools, apparatus, labor and assistance necessary for the test shall be furnished by the permittee. All piping connected to the supplying meter shall be rigid and securely supported. 
(Code 1967, § 24-23; Ord. No. 0-02-104, § 1b, 11-11-02) 
Sec. 9-19. - New permit required after twelve months' disuse.
