(14)  For any renewal, the licensee and any on-site managers shall submit a certified statement from the chief of police verifying compliance with the bars, taverns, and nightclubs nuisance and violence reduction program. 
(15)  A certificate from the zoning inspector certifying that the proposed place of business is located in an appropriate zoning district. 
(16)  A copy of a valid ABC permit for the bar, tavern, or nightclub. 
Failure to provide the information and documentation required by this subsection shall constitute an incomplete application and it shall not be processed until complete. In addition, a licensee or an applicant for a license shall have a continuing duty to promptly supplement application information required by this section in the event that said information changes in any way from what is stated on the application. The licensee or applicant shall supplement the application on file with the police department within fifteen (15) days from the date of such change. 
(b)  Issuance of bar, tavern, and nightclub license. The chief of police shall issue a license for a bar, tavern and nightclub if all requirements for such license described in this article are met unless he finds in writing that: 
(1)  The correct permit or license fee has not been tendered to the city, and, in the case of a check, or bank draft, not honored with payment upon presentation; or 
(2)  That the operation of the bar, tavern, or nightclub as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the city's building, zoning, and health regulations; or 
(3)  Any applicant has failed to answer or falsely answered a question(s) or request for information on the application form provided. 
(4)  Any applicant, including any proposed on-site manager, has been convicted of a crime: 
a.  Involving: 
1.  Any felony; 
2.  A misdemeanor offense of assault, battery, bribery, obstructing justice, carrying a deadly weapon, hand gun violations, controlled dangerous substances, gaming violations, nudity/sexual display/obscene matter violations, pandering, sexual offenses, theft; or 
3.  A violation of any ordinance regulating bars, taverns, or nightclubs of any city, county, or state; and 
b.  For which: 
1.  Less than two (2) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
2.  Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
3.  Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement for last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two (2) or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any two-year period. 
(5)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors, if the application is a corporation; or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; or the on-site manager is not over the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(6)  The security plan will more likely than not be insufficient to prevent injury to patrons of this bar, tavern, or nightclub, including a statement of the reasons for this finding. 
(7)  It is more likely than not that the plan for control of noise emanating from the building or parking lot will not be sufficient to prevent a violation of the noise ordinance, including a statement of the reasons for this finding. 
(c)  Approval or denial of application. The chief of police shall act to approve or deny a complete application for a license under this article as soon as reasonably possible and in any event shall approve or deny said license thirty (30) days from the date that said application was accepted. Upon the expiration of the thirty (30) days, unless the applicant consents to an extension of time, the applicant shall be permitted to begin operating the bar, tavern, or nightclub for which the license is sought, unless and until the chief of police notifies the applicant of a denial and states the reason(s) for denial. Any applicant, including an applicant for a renewal license, whose application for a license is denied shall have the right to appeal such denial by giving written notice to the city manager within fifteen (15) days from the date of denial. In the case of an appeal, due process shall be accorded the applicant pursuant to section 13-307 of this article and such applicant shall have all of the rights of a person whose license has been revoked or suspended. The appeal hearing before the city manager provided by section 13-307 shall be held within ten (10) days of the date notice of appeal is received. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-304. - On-site manager. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to act or serve as on-site manager of a bar, tavern, or nightclub unless the licensee has submitted the information required by section 13-303 to the chief of police and the chief of police has approved the person as an on-site manager. The chief of police shall have fifteen (15) days after submission to approve the on-site manager. 
    The applicant or licensee shall submit the information required by section 13-303 for at least two (2) on-site managers so that one (1) will be available at all times to manage and supervise the establishment. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-305. - Control of premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to relinquish control of a bar, tavern, or nightclub to any other person except an on-site manager. The licensee or an on-site manager must remain on and in control of the premises during all events, including private parties. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-306. - Revocation or suspension of bars, taverns, and nightclubs license. 
    Any license issued for a bar, tavern, or nightclub may be revoked or suspended after notice and a hearing, where it appears that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this article, or where the on-site manager or any employee of the licensee, has engaged in any conduct at the bar, tavern, or nightclub which violates any law or ordinance relating to the operation of the business and of which the licensee has actual or constructive knowledge, or in the exercise of reasonable diligence should have had actual or constructive knowledge, or the occurrence of two (2) or more serious public safety incidents within any twelve-month period unless reasonable measures have been take to prevent a re-occurrence. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-307. - Revocation or suspension proceedings. 
    Upon the determination of a violation of this article or the existence of any other condition which is grounds for revocation or suspension of a license pursuant to section 13-306 of this article, the chief of police shall serve written notice upon the person whose license has been determined to be subject to revocation or suspension. The notice shall state (a) the specific grounds which make the license subject to revocation or suspension, and (b) the opportunity for a hearing before the city manager, provided written notice requesting a hearing is received by the city manager within fifteen (15) days of service of the notice of revocation or suspension. The city manager or his designee shall conduct the hearing and within ten (10) days shall render his decision in writing either revoking the license, suspending the license for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days, or finding that insufficient grounds for revocation or suspension exist and that the person should retain his or her license. In the case of a revocation or suspension, the decision shall state the reasons for the action taken. 
    The decision of the city manager shall be subject to review in the Superior Court of Nash or Edgecombe County by proceedings in the nature of certiorari, but, unless a court of competent jurisdiction otherwise provides, said appeal shall not stay any action taken with regard to the license. Any petition for writ of certiorari for review shall be filed with the clerk of superior court within thirty (30) days after notice of the decision has been received by the licensee. 
(1)  Unless good cause exists to contest a petition for a writ of certiorari, the city shall stipulate to certiorari no later than ten (10) business days after the petitioner requests such a stipulation. 
(2)  The city shall transmit the record to the court no later than five (5) business days after receiving the order allowing certiorari. 
(3)  Notwithstanding the provisions of any local rule of the reviewing court which allows for a longer time period, the city shall file its brief within fifteen (15) days after it is served with the petitioner's brief. 
    An appeal by an applicant or licensee from the superior court shall be governed by the North Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure, but, unless a court of competent jurisdiction otherwise provides, said appeal shall not stay any action taken with regard to the license. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-308. - Bars, taverns, and nightclubs nuisance and violence reduction program. 
    Licensees and on-site managers of bars, taverns, and nightclubs must attend the police department's bars, taverns, and nightclubs nuisance and violence reduction program at least once each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-309. - License fee schedule. 
    It has been determined, based on estimates from the chief of police and the finance director as well as the experience of other cities, that the cost and expense incurred by the city in implementing the licensing procedures regarding bars, taverns, and nightclubs will be at least two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per license. Accordingly, the fee for a bar, tavern, and nightclub license is established at two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The license fee shall be paid when the application is submitted and shall be nonrefundable. There shall be no prorating of the license fee, except that in the case of an original application made after December 31, one-half of the license fee shall be due. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-310. - Criminal penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor as provided in G.S. § 14-4 and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment, or both. Each violation shall be considered a separate and distinct offense, and each day of continued violation shall be considered as a separate offense. The issuance of a notice of violation or a suspension or revocation of a bar, tavern, or nightclub license shall not prohibit the imposition of a criminal penalty and the imposition of a criminal penalty shall not prevent the issuance of a notice of violation or a suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-311. - Civil injunction. 
    In addition to the issuance of a notice of violation, the suspension or revocation of a bar, tavern, or nightclub license, or a prosecution for criminal violations, any person who violates this article may be subject to all civil and equitable remedies set out in G.S. § 160A-175. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Sec. 13-312. - Severability. 
    In the event that any provision of this article, or any part thereof, or any application thereof to any person or circumstance, is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction on its face, or as applied, such holding shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of any of the remaining provisions of this article, or any part thereof, or any application thereof to any person or circumstance or of said provision as applied to any other person or circumstance. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the city council that this article would have been adopted had such unconstitutional, invalid, or ineffective provisions not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-21, 3-14-11) 
Chapter 14 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- City prohibited from enacting inconsistent ordinance on crimes the elements of which are identical to state law, G.S. § 160A-174(b)(6); criminal law, G.S. Ch. 14; punishment for violation of ordinance, violation of ordinance constitutes infraction or class 3 misdemeanor, G.S. § 14-4. 

Sec. 14-1. - Defacing, removal of signs. 
    It shall be unlawful to tear, deface, mutilate, take down or in any manner destroy any advertisement or legal, public or private notice posted for public view within the corporate limits, except that the owner of the property upon which such advertisement or notice has been posted without his permission may remove the same. 
(Code 1967, § 3-3) 
State Law reference- Unlawful posting of advertisements, G.S. § 14-145. 
Sec. 14-2. - Attaching signs, posters, etc., on trees, utility poles. 
    No person shall post any bills, posters, signs or advertisements on any trees or telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole along any of the streets of the city. This section shall not be construed to include street signs, placed on the poles by the city for designating names of streets. Each sign, poster, bill or advertisement posted in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 3-4) 
State Law reference- Unlawful posting of advertisements, G.S. § 14-145. 
Sec. 14-3. - Possession of dangerous weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display or willfully or intentionally possess or have immediate access to any bowie knife, dirk, dagger, slingshot, loaded cane, brass iron or metallic knuckles, razor, pistol, shotgun, rifle or other deadly weapon of like kind upon or in any city park, city transit bus, or city building or portion thereof, owned, leased as lessee, operated, occupied, managed, or controlled by the city, as well as the appurtenant premises to any such city building. It shall also be unlawful for any person to possess such dangerous or deadly weapons while under the influence of intoxicating drink, or at the premises of a church, polling place, or other place of public assembly. The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Persons authorized by state or federal law to carry dangerous or deadly weapons in the performance of their duties; or 
(2)  Persons participating in city sponsored events, programs, displays, or activities involving dangerous or deadly weapons provided such persons have been expressly authorized by the chief of police to display or have in their possession or control the dangerous or deadly weapon they possess or control. 
(Code 1967, § 12-4; Ord. No. 0-95-37, § 1, 7-10-95; Ord. No. 0-95-66, § 1, 12-11-95) 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate explosives, § 10(c). 
State Law reference- Concealed weapons, G.S. § 14-269; selling weapons to minors, G.S. § 14-315; permitting children to use firearms, G.S. § 14-316; sale of certain weapons without permit forbidden, G.S. § 14-402. 
Sec. 14-4. - Discharge of firearms, fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or project any stone, rock, shot or other hard substance by means of a slingshot, bean shooter, air rifle, pop gun, bow or other similar contrivance; or to fire any pistol, gun or other firearm; or to discharge any fireworks within the city; except on archery ranges, firing ranges or in legally established shooting galleries or ranges, or in the discharge of duty by law enforcement officers. The use of firearms in the destruction of rodents, pigeons, squirrels or similar animals or birds or reptiles that are considered a menace to public health or property may be permitted by special permission of the chief of police. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the use of fireworks for exhibition or entertainment purposes by persons to whom permits have been granted by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 12-5) 
Sec. 14-5. - Planting of certain trees prohibited. 
    No cottonwood or elm trees shall be planted within the city limits. This shall not prohibit or be applicable to the planting of Chinese Elm trees. 
(Code 1967, § 12-25) 
Sec. 14-6. - Blocking or obstructing storm drainage pipes and ditches. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, dump, roll or in any manner place or cause to be placed any objects or materials in a drainage pipe, box culvert, drainage ditch or any other storm- water carrier receiving street runoff which may cause a blockage or reduction in flow capacity. These objects and materials include but are not limited to leaves, pine straw, grass clippings, tree limbs, lumber, construction and landscaping debris, bulky items or any other type of solid waste capable of causing an obstruction. 
(b)  The director of public works or his representative may grant temporary authority to block or obstruct a drainage system for construction, repair or maintenance activity. This temporary authority is for limited duration and does not relieve the grantee of responsibility for any damages caused by such blockage or obstruction. 
(c)  The superintendent of streets is hereby directed, authorized and empowered to notify in writing the owner of any lot, place or area within the city limits on which any of the conditions set forth in (a) above exist that such condition must be abated by removing and/or remedying such condition on or before a specified date which date shall not be less than seven (7) days from issuance of the notice. 
(d)  If the owner upon whom a notice to abate the blockage or obstructing condition fails, neglects or refuses to remedy the condition within the time specified in the notice, the superintendent of streets shall forthwith cause such condition to be removed, abated or remedied. The cost of such action shall be paid by the owner or other person responsible for the condition, and if not paid shall be a lien upon the real estate or premises upon which the condition arose and shall be collected as unpaid taxes. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19. 
Sec. 14-7. - Spilling, dumping, leaking, etc., of hazardous chemicals or waste into or on the city's storm drains, sanitary sewers or drainage ditches, streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spill, dump, leak or in any manner allow or cause hazardous chemicals or wastes to gain access into the city's storm drains, sanitary sewers or drainage ditches, streets, etc. If such a condition happens or is found to exist the person or owner responsible for the condition shall take immediate steps to abate the condition as directed by local, state or federal officials. All costs associated with the abatement and cleanup of the condition are the responsibility of the person causing the condition. The city shall be reimbursed for any material and labor provided to assist in such abatement or cleanup. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19; sanitary sewers, § 21-26 et seq. 
Sec. 14-8. - Notice of towing required; contents of notice. 
(a)  Any firm, or corporation which tows or removes a motor vehicle (or any other machine intended to travel over land by self-propulsion or while attached to a self-propelled vehicle) by any means from private property without the knowledge of the owner of such vehicle, shall, within forty-eight (48) hours of such towing, furnish notice of the towing to the chief of police. Each twenty-four (24) hour period which elapses thereafter without the chief of police being notified shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The written notice of towing required to be furnished to the chief of police under section 14-8(a) shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner or other person entitled to possession of the vehicle if such can be reasonably ascertained; 
(2)  A description of the vehicle; 
(3)  The license plate number and the state which issued such license plate if the vehicle has a license plate; 
(4)  The location from which the vehicle was towed; 
(5)  The person authorizing the towing; and 
(6)  The location where the vehicle is stored and the name of the person having custody thereof. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-82, § 1(12-34, 12-35), 9-25-89) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-89-82, § 1 adopted Sept. 25, 1989, amended Ch. 12 of the 1967 Code by the addition of §§ 12-34 and 12-35 and at the discretion of the editor and provisions have been included herein as § 14-8. 
Cross reference- Abandoned vehicles, § 10-176 et seq.; towing provisions regarding abandoned vehicles, § 10-186 et seq. 
Sec. 14-9. - Loitering for the purpose of engaging in drug related activity. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section "public place" means any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley or alleyway, plaza, park, driveway, parking lot, or transportation facility, or the doorways and entrance ways to any building which fronts on any of the foregoing places, or a motor vehicle in or on any of those places, or any property owned by the City of Rocky Mount. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remain or wander about in a public place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of violating any subdivision of the North Carolina Controlled Substances Act, North Carolina General Statutes 90, Article 5. Such circumstances shall include: 
(1)  Repeatedly beckoning to, stopping, or attempting to stop passers-by, or repeatedly attempting to engage passers-by in conversation, whether such passers-by are on foot or in a motor vehicle, for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting, or procuring another to illegally possess, transfer, or buy any controlled substance; or 
(2)  Behaving in such a manner as to appear that he or she is about to engage in or is engaged in an unlawful drug related activity; or 
(3)  Repeatedly passing to or receiving from passers-by, whether on foot or in a motor vehicle, money, objects, or written material, for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting, or procuring another to illegally possess, transfer, or buy any controlled substance. 
(c)  In order to be a violation of subsection (b), the person's affirmative language or conduct must be such as to demonstrate by its express or implied content or appearance a specific intent to induce, entice, solicit or procure another to illegally possess, transfer, or buy a controlled substance. 
(d)  No arrest shall be made for a violation of subsection (b) unless the arresting officer first affords the person an opportunity to explain his or her conduct, and no one shall be convicted of violating subsection (b) if it appears at trial that the explanation given was true and disclosed no intent to violate any subdivision of the North Carolina Controlled Substances Act. 
(e)  The violation of any provisions of this section shall be a misdemeanor as provided by North Carolina General Statutes 14-4. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-91, § 1(12-36), 11-13-89) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-89-91, § 1, adopted Nov. 13, 1989, amended Ch. 12 of the 1967 by the addition of § 12-36 and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as § 14-9. 
Sec. 14-10. - Smoking in municipal buildings and vehicles. 
(a)  Definition. "Smoking" shall mean the inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying of a lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, or other combustible tobacco product. 
(b)  Smoking prohibited in city administrative office building. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in the city administrative office building located at 331 South Franklin Street. 
(c)  Smoking regulated in other municipal buildings. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any building or facility or portion of a building or facility now or hereafter owned, leased, operated, occupied, managed, or controlled by the city, except, that smoking shall be permitted in specifically designated areas in buildings other than the city administrative office building. The city manager shall have the authority to designate smoking areas within each such city building or facility. An area within any such building or facility may be designated as a smoking area only if in the judgment of the city manager the ventilation of such area is sufficient, any adverse impact on municipal employees and members of the public is minimal, and no fire or other safety hazard will be created by smoking in such area. 
(d)  Smoking regulated in municipal vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any vehicle now or hereafter owned or leased by the city unless it has been designated for smoking by the city manager. 
(e)  Exemptions. This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Dwelling units under the supervision and direction of the Rocky Mount Housing Authority. 
(2)  Buildings owned by the city that are leased to others where the occupancy and activity within the building is not controlled by the city. 
(f)  Penalty. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with G.S. 14-4. 
(Ord. No. 0-93-58, §1, 9-27-93; Ord. No. O-08-17, § 1, 3-10-08) 
Sec. 14-11. - Carrying of concealed handguns on city property. 
(a)  City buildings and parks to be posted. The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized and instructed to post conspicuous signs on or within each park and each building or portion of a building owned, leased as lessee, operated, occupied, managed, or controlled by the city, as well as the appurtenant premises to such buildings, indicating that carrying a concealed handgun therein or thereon is prohibited. 
(b)  City buses to be posted. The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized and instructed to post conspicuous signs in or on each city transit bus owned, leased as lessee, or operated by or for the city indicating that carrying a concealed handgun therein or thereon is prohibited. 
(c)  Location of signs. Signs on buildings shall be visibly posted on the exterior of each entrance by which any member of the general public can enter the building. The signs posted in city parks, appurtenant premises to city buildings, and city transit buses shall be placed in an appropriate location to clearly indicate that the carrying of concealed handguns in such park, appurtenant premises, or bus is prohibited. 
(d)  Unlawful to carry concealed handguns. It shall be unlawful for any person not a law enforcement officer to carry a concealed handgun or city property or in a city vehicle which has been posted pursuant to this section. The violation of this section shall constitute a violation of article 54 of chapter 14 of the North Carolina General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 0-95-53, § 1, 10-23-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. § 14-415.11(c). 
Sec. 14-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2004-57, § 1b, adopted July 12, 2004, repealed § 14-12 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to installation of electric fences as enacted by Ord. No. 0-97-14, § 1, adopted March, 24 1997. 
Sec. 14-13. - Regulation of panhandling. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this subsection. 
(1)  Aggressive manner shall mean: 
a.  Approaching or speaking to a person, or following a person before, during, or after panhandling if that conduct is intended or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm, damage to or loss of property, or to otherwise be intimidated into giving money or any other thing of value; 
b.  Approaching within three (3) feet of a person being panhandled unless that person has indicated that he or she wishes to make a donation; 
c.  Continuing to panhandle from a person after such person has given a negative response to such panhandling; 
d.  Intentionally touching or causing physical contact with another person without that person's consent in the course of panhandling; 
e.  Intentionally blocking or interfering with the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including unreasonably causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact; 
f.  Using violent or threatening language or gestures toward a person being panhandled; 
g.  Following a person being panhandled with the intention of asking that person for money or other things of value; 
h.  Panhandling from anyone who is waiting in line for entry to a building or for any other purpose; or 
i.  Panhandling in a group of two (2) or more. 
(2)  Automated teller machine shall mean a device, linked to a financial institution's account records, which is able to carry out transactions, including, but not limited to, account transfers, deposits, cash withdrawals, balance inquiries, and mortgage and loan payments. 
(3)  Automated teller machine facility shall mean an area comprised of one (1) or more automatic teller machines and any adjacent space made available to customers of financial institutions. 
(4)  Check-cashing business shall mean any person or entity engaged in the check-cashing business as defined in Article 22 of Chapter 53 of the General Statues of North Carolina. 
(5)  Financial institution shall mean any corporation, credit union, or savings and loan association, receiving, soliciting, or accepting money or its equivalent on deposit as a business. 
(6)  Panhandle shall mean making a solicitation in person requesting an immediate donation of money. Purchase of an item for an amount of money far exceeding its value, under circumstances where a reasonable person would understand that the purchase is in substance a donation, is a donation for the purpose of this section. Panhandling does not include passively standing or sitting with a sign or other indication that one is seeking donations, without addressing any solicitation to any specific person other than in response to an inquiry by that person. 
(7)  Public place shall mean a place that a governmental entity has title to or a place to which the public or a substantial group of persons has free access, including, without limitation, any street, highway, parking lot, plaza, transportation facility, school, place of amusement, park, or playground. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful to: 
(1)  Panhandle in an aggressive manner in any public place. 
(2)  Panhandle on private or residential property without carrying written permission to engage in such conduct from the owner or other person lawfully in possession of such property. 
(3)  Panhandle within twenty (20) feet of any entrance or exit of any financial institution, check-cashing business, or automated teller machine without the consent of the owner of such facilities or other person legally in possession thereof; provided, however, that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility the twenty-foot distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the facility. 
(4)  Panhandle an operator or other occupant of a motor vehicle for the purpose of performing or offering to perform a service in connection with such vehicle or otherwise soliciting the sale of goods or services. This subsection shall not apply to services rendered in connection with emergency repairs requested by the operator or passenger of such vehicle. 
(5)  Panhandle an operator or occupant of a motor vehicle on a public street in exchange for blocking, occupying, or reserving a public parking space, or directing the operator or occupant to a public parking space. 
(6)  Panhandle while under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance. 
(7)  Panhandle by stating that funds are needed to meet a specific need, when the solicitor has the funds to meet that need, does not intend to use funds to meet that need, or does not have that need. 
(8)  Panhandle in any public transportation vehicle; or at any bus, train, or taxi station or stop, or within twenty (20) feet of the entrance or exit of any bus, train, or taxi station or stop. 
(9)  Panhandle after sunset or before sunrise. 
(10)  Panhandle while standing or sitting on the roadway, shoulder, or median of any street or highway. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor as provided by North Carolina General Statutes § 14-4, and, upon the first conviction, shall be subject to a maximum fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisonment for a period not to exceed seven (7) days, or both, and upon the second or subsequent conviction shall be subject to a maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-6, § 1, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 14-14. - Helmets, elbow pads and kneepads required at city skateboard parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a skateboard, inline skates, or bicycle, or to participate or engage in skateboarding, inline skating, or freestyle bicycling at any city skateboard park without wearing a helmet, elbow pads and kneepads. 
(b)  Signs shall be posted at all city skateboard parks providing notice that any person engaging in skateboarding, inline skating, or freestyle bicycling must wear a helmet, elbow pads, and knee pads and that any person failing to do so will be subject to citation under this section. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-72, § 1, 8-25-03) 
Sec. 14-15. - Graffiti. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Chalk means any device in solid form of chalk, paint, wax, epoxy or similar substance capable of being applied to a surface by applying pressure, and upon application, leaving a mark at least one-eight ( 1/8 ) of an inch in width. 
(2)  Chief of police means the chief of police of the city or his or her authorized designee. 
(3)  Graffiti means any inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn painted or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property, natural or man-made, by a graffiti implement or chalk, without the prior written consent of the property owner delivered to the person placing the graffiti on the property. Graffiti does not include temporary, easily removable chalk or other water-soluble makings on public or private sidewalks, streets, natural surfaces, or other paved or cemented surfaces which are used in connection with traditional children's activities such as drawings of bases for stickball, kickball, handball, hopscotch or similar activities, nor shall it include similar easily removable markings used in connection with any lawful business activity or public purpose. 
(4)  Graffiti implement means any aerosol paint container, broad tipped marker, stick on label, paint stick, paint, etching equipment, brush or other device capable of scarring or leaving a visible mark on any natural or man-made surface. 
(5)  Property owner(s) shall mean and include the owner of the property, such property owner's manager or agent, or any other person in lawful control or possession of the property. 
(b)  Graffiti declared a nuisance. 
(1)  The existence of graffiti on public or private property in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and dangerous to the public safety and welfare, and is therefore subject to the removal and abatement provisions specified in this section. 
(2)  It is the duty of the property owner to which the graffiti has been applied to remove such graffiti. 
(c)  Violation of section a misdemeanor. It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden by this section or to fail to do or perform any act required by this section. Any violation of this section shall be punished as specified herein. 
(d)  Graffiti unlawful. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place graffiti upon any public or private property. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) to possess any graffiti implement upon any school ground, public place, bridge, culvert, or any residential property of which they are not a resident or guest, or at any private business, unless such person can establish to the reasonable satisfaction of the police that the possession of such implement was part of a school project, home project, or some other lawful activity. 
(e)  Removal of graffiti. 
(1)  Removal by the perpetrator. 
a.  Any person applying graffiti on public or private property shall remove such graffiti or cause such graffiti to be removed within seventy-two (72) hours after notice from the city or the owner of the property involved. If the graffiti is applied by a person under the age of eighteen (18), the parents or legal guardians of such minor shall be responsible for such removal. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any person who has applied graffiti to fail to remove such graffiti within seventy-two (72) hours after receipt of notice to remove the graffiti. 
(2)  Removal by the city. 
a.  Whenever the city becomes aware of the existence of graffiti on private property, the city is authorized to remove the graffiti as set forth in this subsection after first giving notice to the property owner to remove or effectively obscure such graffiti as provided in this subsection. The notice shall be given by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service, and shall contain the following: 
(i)  The street address or other description of the property sufficient for identification of the property. 
(ii)  A statement that the property is a public nuisance due to the existence of the graffiti. 
(iii)  A statement that the graffiti must be removed or effectively obscured within seven (7) days after receipt of the notice and that if the public nuisance created by the graffiti is not abated within that time the city will abate the public nuisance at the cost of the property owner as set forth in this subsection. 
(iv)  Information identifying any graffiti removal assistance available through the city and private graffiti removal contractors. 
b.  If the property owner fails to remove or effectively obscure the graffiti within the prescribed seven (7) days after receipt of notice described above, the city may cause the graffiti to be removed or effectively obscured at the expense of the property owner. If the cost of removing or obscuring the graffiti is not paid by the property owner within thirty (30) days of the receipt of a statement for the cost of such removal or obscuring, the expenses thereof shall be lien on the property where the graffiti was abated and shall have the same priority and be collected as unpaid ad valorem taxes. 
c.  Appeal. Any property owner who receives a notice to remove or obscure graffiti may appeal to the city manager within seven (7) days of receipt of the notice. The appeal notice shall state the reasons for the appeal. The city manager or his designee shall set a hearing within seven (7) business days after receipt of the notice of appeal. If, on appeal, the city manager or his designee determines that the graffiti is a public nuisance and must be removed, the city manager or his designee shall establish a new date for removing or obscuring the graffiti. The city shall not remove or obscure graffiti until a decision has been rendered by the city manager or his designee. 
d.  Emergency removal. If the city determines that any graffiti is an imminent danger to the safety or welfare of the public it shall prepare a notice as described in subsection (e)(2)a., which shall serve as an emergency notice, including a specific allegation of how the safety or welfare of the public is in jeopardy and why the graffiti constitutes an imminent danger. If the city is unable to provide personal service of this emergency notice after two (2) attempts to do so, then the city may remove the graffiti at its own expense after posting such property with said notice. If a property owner receives notice that emergency removal has been deemed necessary by the city the property owner shall: 
(i)  Cause the immediate removal of the graffiti or cause the graffiti to be obscured or; 
(ii)  Give permission to the city to obscure or remove the graffiti at the city's cost or; 
(iii)  Immediately obtain appropriate relief from a court of competent jurisdiction directing the city to stop any attempt to obscure or remove any graffiti. 
e.  Repairs/restoration. In no case shall the city paint or repair any area defaced by graffiti more extensively than where the graffiti itself is located. The city shall not be required to restore the obscured area to its original condition (i.e. exact color, texture etc.) 
(f)  Penalties. 
(1)  The following penalties shall apply for violations of this section. 
a.  Violations of subsection (d)(1), the placement of graffiti, or subsection (e)(1) failure to remove such graffiti by perpetrator, shall be punishable by: 
(i)  First violation- A fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
(ii)  Second violation- A fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. 
(iii)  Each subsequent violation- A fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(2)  Violations of subsection (d)(2), possession of graffiti implements: 
a.  First violation- A fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
b.  Second violation- A fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. 
c.  Each subsequent violation- A fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 0-06-88, § 1, 11-27-06) 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 10; public grounds peddling and soliciting permit, § 13-111 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20; subdivisions, App. A; zoning, App. B. 
State Law reference- Parks and recreation, G.S. § 160A-350 et seq.; use of property tax funds for parks and recreation, G.S. § 160A-209(c)(24). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Vehicles on public grounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or to park any vehicle on any part of any park, athletic field, school ground or other public lands within the city except upon the driveways therein or in the areas designated as parking spaces. 
(Code 1967, § 13-2) 
Sec. 15-2. - Activities at city lake. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in, wade in, ice skate or walk upon or in any manner encroach upon or place any boat or vehicle upon or in the city lake on Sunset Avenue in the city. Nothing herein shall prohibit feeding the ducks or fishing from the banks of the lake or other activity for which a permit has been secured from the city recreation department. Remote-controlled boats are allowed provided a written permit is secured from the director of recreation. 
(Code 1967, § 13-1) 
Secs. 15-3-15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS 

Sec. 15-26. - Hours generally; extinguishment of light; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remain in or enter any park owned by the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. All lights utilized to illuminate park recreation areas shall be extinguished at 12:00 midnight except upon order of the director of the city recreation department. This section shall not apply to any person or group of persons using any park on an overnight basis after having obtained a permit for such use from the director of the city recreation department so long as such use is consistent with the permit. 
(Code 1967, § 13-4) 
Sec. 15-27. - Specific parks; activities regulated. 
(a)  Battle Park. It shall be unlawful to park or remain in parked cars in Battle Park in areas that have been designated closed between sunset and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Frank's Field (Taylor Park). Frank's Field or Taylor Park, located in Nash County and bounded by Wildwood Avenue, Evergreen Road and Shady Circle Drive, shall be closed between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. It shall be unlawful for any person, during these hours to enter, remain in or leave a motor vehicle parked upon the city park. 
(Ord. No. 0-92-8, § 1, 1-13-92) 
Sec. 15-28. - Group activity; signs. 
(a)  Group activity. Whenever any group, association or organization desires to use park facilities for a particular purpose, a representative of the group, association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the director of recreation for such purposes. The director of recreation will grant the permit if it appears that the group, association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the parks and the proposed activity of the group will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, safety and recreation. 
(b)  Signs declaring park use regulations. Signs shall be erected at the entrances to parks setting forth the hours of opening and closing the parks. Other signs regulating the use of the park areas by the public may be established throughout the parks when such regulation has been established in this section. All signs are to be observed by the public and it shall be unlawful for anyone to violate any such posted regulation. 
(Code 1967, § 13-6) 
Sec. 15-29. - Wildlife protected. 
    The shooting or trapping of birds, squirrels or other game in any park within the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 13-3) 
Cross reference- Bird sanctuary declared, § 4-2. 
Sec. 15-30. - Picnic shelters. 
(a)  Picnic shelters in all city parks are available to churches, clubs, families and other local groups at a fee which shall be set by the city council and published in the Manual of City Policies and may be reserved by calling the office of the director of parks and recreation. This subsection shall apply only when picnic shelters are to be used for social purposes and no fund-raising activity is involved. 
(b)  Picnic shelters in Sunset Park and Tom Stith Park shall be available to local groups for fund-raising purposes upon payment of a deposit to the city and upon receipt of a permit from the director of parks and recreation. 
(c)  Picnic shelters shall be available for fund-raising activities to local groups whose membership is at least partially composed of Rocky Mount citizens and whose purpose in renting a picnic shelter for fund raising is nonprofit. Shelters shall not be available for rent to groups from neighboring towns unless their membership and purpose is countywide in scope. The city reserves the right to decide whether a group qualifies for use of a picnic shelter for fund-raising purposes. 
(d)  The only fund-raising activity permitted in the picnic shelters shall be the sale of food and drink products except that the sale or use of alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited. Permission to sell food and drink products is contingent upon approval by the appropriate county health department, and it is the responsibility of the applicant group to obtain health department approval. 
(e)  Permission to use picnic shelters for fund-raising purposes is contingent upon certification by the chief of police that the applicant has arranged for traffic control. If the chief of police determines that increased traffic-control measures are necessary, the applicant shall be required to employ the number of off-duty police officers specified by the chief at the applicant's expense. 
(f)  An advance deposit for damage, one cleanup, utilities and other expenses to be determined by the director of parks and recreation shall be paid. The unused portion of this deposit (as determined by the director of parks and recreation), if any, will be returned provided the shelter and surrounding grounds are cleaned up by 9:00 a.m. the following day to the satisfaction of the recreation department representative. If cleanup is provided by the city, the charge shall be actual payroll plus twenty-seven (27) percent and actual equipment charges. The amount of the deposit shall be determined by the city council and published in the Manual of City Policies. 
(g)  If the group desires to rent the shelter for longer than two (2) hours, health regulations relative to restroom facilities must be followed. 
(h)  If an application for a permit under this section is denied, the applicant may appeal to the city manager. 
(i)  Permits for the use of picnic shelters for fund-raising purposes are nontransferable. 
(Code 1967, § 14-13; Ord. No. 0-90-36, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Secs. 15-31-15-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAR RIVER WATER SUPPLY RESERVOIR AND RECREATION AREA 

Sec. 15-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means any vehicle left unattended on the reservoir bed. 
    Fixed blind means a structure erected at a fixed location either on the shore or in water for the purpose of hunting and shooting waterfowl. A stationary blind shall be: 
(1)  Of such size and strength that it can be occupied by and conceal one or more hunters, or 
(2)  Large enough to accommodate and conceal a boat or skiff from which one or more hunters can hunt or shoot waterfowl. 
    Floating blind means a floating device, whether in motion or anchored, that can be occupied by and conceal one or more hunters, uses a means of concealment other than the device's paint or coloration, and is used in the water for the purpose of hunting and shooting waterfowl. 
    Parks and recreation waterfowl blind means a waterfowl blind owned by the city for the exclusive purpose of waterfowl hunting. 
    Permitted blind means a blind in which the owner has received a permit from the city for construction and or use. 
    Reservoir means the Tar River Reservoir as shown on map entitled "City of Rocky Mount, N. C. Water Use Map" marked "Exhibit A" (hereinafter referred to as the "Reservoir Map") incorporated herein by reference and on file in the city clerk's office. 
    Reservoir bed means any land area at the reservoir, including the bank, below the high water property line of the city. 
    Reservoir watershed means the land area from which stormwater drains into the reservoir. 
    Vehicle means and includes any wheel, track, or other vehicle designed or intended to travel over land by self propulsion or while attached to any self propelled vehicle. 
    Warden means the employee of the city duly authorized to enforce the requirements of this article and to protect the public in its use of the reservoir. 
    Zone means a specific water area of the reservoir as indicated on the reservoir map. The boundary lines between zones shall be marked by buoys in the Tar River Reservoir as indicated on the reservoir map. Permitted activities in each zone are set forth in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-1; Ord. No. O-2007-111, § 1a., 10-22-07; Ord. No. O-2007-124, § 1a., 11-26-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-52. - Violations; penalty. 
    Violations of any provision of this article or the failure to comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this article or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as follows: 
(1)  First offense: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(2)  Second offense: One hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(3)  Third and each subsequent offense: Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-2; O-2007-111, § 1d., 10-22-07) 
Sec. 15-53. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The warden or his duly authorized agent shall have the power and authority to deny admission to the reservoir to any person known to have violated the rules and regulations or ordinances governing the reservoir, or to any person having alcoholic beverages in his possession or who shows evidence of being under the influence of alcohol. 
(b)  The warden or his duly authorized agent shall also have the power and authority to remove from the reservoir any person who violates any of these requirements. 
(c)  The warden or his duly authorized agent shall have the duty to swear out warrants against any person for violating or failing to comply with this article. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-3) 
Sec. 15-54. - Boating. 
(a)  General requirements. 
(1)  All boats shall enter and leave the reservoir water only at public landing ramps provided by the city. An owner of property adjoining zones B, C, D or E may secure only his own boat to his pier, dock, float or slip on the reservoir. 
(2)  Private boats shall normally be permitted on the reservoir at any hour unless specific hours are determined by the city or the warden and posted at entrances to the reservoir. If specific hours are determined in the interest of public safety, the warden may, in his discretion, issue such after hours permits to fishermen or persons wishing to tie up or dock their boat overnight at a location away from the public dock and launching ramps. In no case shall an after hours permit be issued for power boating, water skiing, sailing or any activity other than fishing from or docking the boat. 
(3)  Each boat entering the reservoir shall contain a life vest meeting the approval of the United States Coast Guard, cushion and such other equipment as necessary to meet any applicable state or federal regulations. 
(4)  Boats shall at all times be operated in a manner that will not endanger it or the lives or property of others. 
(5)  Any person under sixteen (16) years of age shall not operate a power boat unless accompanied by a person sixteen (16) years of age or older. 
(6)  Piers, docks, floats or slips for tying up boats may be constructed in zones B, C, D and E provided a permit therefor has been issued by the warden. The warden will approve in advance the location and construction of each pier, dock, float or slip, verifying that each will meet minimum standards set by the city engineer, and that the proposed location will not disrupt boat traffic on the reservoir. In no case shall the warden permit the installation of a pier, dock or float at any point where the reservoir is less than one hundred (100) feet in width. Permits shall not be transferrable. 
(7)  The warden shall inspect at least annually each pier, dock, float and slip, and shall notify the owner of any deterioration or damage. Owners shall maintain any pier, dock, float or slip in good condition at all times. 
(8)  The warden shall cause to be removed any such structures from city property at any time the age, conditions or use of the structure becomes hazardous in his opinion. 
(9)  Boats having marine waste disposal systems shall not be permitted on the reservoir unless the system has been sealed by having the through-the-hull discharge fitting or seacock securely capped or plugged or both, and the connection between the device and the discharge fitting or seacock removed. 
(10)  Houseboats shall not be permitted on the reservoir. 
(11)  It shall be unlawful to move, damage or in any way alter buoys that have been placed on the reservoir. 
(b)  Power boating. 
(1)  Power boating shall be permitted in all zones except zone A. 
(2)  Power boats within one hundred (100) feet of the shore or one hundred (100) feet of the docks or ramps shall not proceed at a rate of speed that will cause an excessive wake. Power boats passing under the Bend of the River Bridge (S.R. 1745) shall proceed at a rate of speed that will cause no wake. 
(3)  Power boats in zone D shall not proceed at a speed that will disrupt fishing or sailing activities. 
(c)  Water skiing. 
(1)  Water skiing shall be prohibited in zones A and D and only permitted in zones B, C and E. 
(2)  Boats pulling water skiers shall have at least two (2) responsible persons in the boat, unless the boat is equipped with an approved wide angle rear view mirror. 
(3)  Each water skier shall wear a vest-type life preserver approved by the United States Coast Guard at all times. 
(4)  Boats returning for a downed skier shall do so with caution. 
(5)  Skiing from or into public ramps or docks is prohibited. 
(d)  Sailing. 
(1)  Sailing shall be permitted in zones B, C, D and E. 
(2)  Sailing craft shall have the navigation rights over power craft. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-4; Ord. No. 0-90-57, § 2, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 15-55. - Fishing. 
(a)  Only boat fishing is permitted in zone D of the reservoir. Water skiing, swimming and similar activities disruptive to fishing are prohibited in this zone. 
(b)  Boat fishing is permitted in zones B, C and E but not exclusively. Other permitted activities in these zones at times may disrupt fishing. 
(c)  Bank fishing in zone D or E shall be permitted at any location, provided reasonable care is taken to avoid littering the shore or polluting the water. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-6) 
Sec. 15-56. - Hunting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person except the warden or authorized law enforcement personnel to carry, possess, discharge, fire or shoot any pistol, rifle, shotgun, or other firearm over, across, upon, or from the reservoir except as permitted in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or project by means of a sling shot, bean shooter, air rifle, pellet gun, pop gun, bow, or any similar means or contrivance, any stone, rock, shot, or other hard substance over, across, into, upon, or from the reservoir. 
(c)  It shall be lawful to hunt migratory waterfowl in zone E, those parts of zone D (Sapony Creek) North of State Road 1717, or within a permitted parks and recreation waterfowl blind during waterfowl season provided a general permit for such hunting has been issued by the warden. No shotgun larger than twelve (12) gauge shall be used. General permit and float blind hunters must remain more than five hundred (500) yards from any residence, fixed blind, highway, state road, other hunter or restricted area. 
(d)  Upon the issuance of a permit by the chief of police, it shall be lawful to use the type of firearm specified in such permit for the destruction of rodents, pigeons, squirrels, or similar animals, birds, or reptiles that are a menace to public health, safety or property. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, discharge, or cause to be discharged, any fireworks or pyrotechnics over, across, into, upon, or from the reservoir unless a permit for such use or discharge has been issued by the city council. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a blind or other method of concealment on the regulated section of the reservoir without an annual permit from the reservoir warden. Permitted blinds are for the exclusive use of the permit holder. All other hunters must remain five hundred (500) yards from permitted blinds. Guests must have written permission. No fee may be charged by permit holder to hunt permitted blinds. Permitted blinds must be hunted a minimum of once per season and the permits must be permanently displayed on the blind. Failure to comply with any part of this article may result in removal of the blind by the city. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface a permitted blind. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-7; Ord. No. 0-90-57, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. O-2007-124, § 1b.-d., 11-26-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2007-124, § 1b., adopted November 26, 2007, changed the title of § 15-56 from "Use of firearms" to "Hunting." 
Cross reference- City declared bird sanctuary, § 4-2; possession of dangerous weapons, § 14-3; discharge of firearms and fireworks, § 14-4; wildlife within parks protected, § 15-29. 
Sec. 15-57. - Swimming. 
(a)  Swimming shall not be permitted in zone A or B of the reservoir. 
(b)  In zone C, swimming shall be permitted in locations designated by the warden having toilets, facilities and services for swimming safety. 
(c)  Swimming in zone C incidental to water skiing is permitted at any location. 
(d)  Swimming shall be permitted in zones D and E at locations designated by the warden having toilet facilities nearby. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-8) 
Sec. 15-58. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages. The consumption of alcoholic beverages on the reservoir shall be prohibited. Persons using alcoholic beverages or found to be under the influence of alcohol shall be denied the use of the reservoir and adjoining city property. 
(b)  Littering. No trash or refuse shall be deposited in the reservoir or on the shore except in the containers provided. 
(c)  Watering, etc., animals. The watering, washing or wallowing of any horses, mules, cattle or other domestic animals shall not be permitted in or along the shore of the reservoir. 
(d)  Animal carcasses. In no case shall dead animals be placed in the reservoir or on the reservoir watershed. 
(e)  Proximity of burial grounds. No burial ground shall be established on the watershed within fifteen hundred (1500) feet of the water supply intake, or at any location within three hundred (300) feet of the high water mark of the reservoir. 
(f)  Residences, businesses, etc. Any residence, place of business or place of public assembly adjoining the reservoir shall be located in conformity with any applicable zoning law, and shall be provided with an approved means of sewage disposal. 
(g)  Disposal of deleterious substance. No person shall dispose of any substance on the reservoir watershed that may have a deleterious effect on the quality of the water. 
(h)  Reserved. 
(i)  Parking in ramp area. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle, boat or trailer in the ramp area at the Bend of the River Ramp for any purpose other than immediate loading or launching of boats. 
(j)  Blocking egress from parking area. It shall be unlawful to double park or park a vehicle in such a manner as to block egress from the parking lot for any other vehicle at the Bend of the River Boat Ramp. 
(k)  Removal of barricades. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove or tamper with any barricades or other devices intended to close or limit the use of any ramp, driveway, or other grounds at the reservoir belonging to the city. 
(l)  Trespass upon the reservoir bed. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to drive, cause to be driven, or permit any vehicle to be driven, operated, or left upon the reservoir bed. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-9; Ord. No. 0-90-57, § 2, 8-13-90; Ord. No. O-2007-111, § 1b., 10-22-07) 
Sec. 15-59. - Permits. 
    Permits shall be required for certain activities at the Tar River Water Supply Reservoir, including, but not limited to camping, hunting, piers, fixed blinds, float blinds and parks and recreation waterfowl blinds. Fees shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the city council and published in the city's manual of city policies. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-10; Ord. No. 0-89-43, § 1, 6-26-89; Ord. No. O-2007-124, § 1e., 11-26-07) 
Sec. 15-60. - Seaplanes. 
    Seaplanes or other amphibious aircraft or any other aircraft, except kites as set forth in section 15-62, capable of landing or taking off on the water are prohibited on the reservoir. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-11) 
Sec. 15-61. - Water-skiing kites. 
    Water skiers using a kite apparatus to take off or land on the water are permitted on the reservoir in Zone E. 
(Code 1967, § 171/2-12) 
Sec. 15-62. - Abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  Any abandoned vehicle is deemed an environmental hazard and inimicable to the public welfare and shall be removed from the reservoir bed as soon as possible by the chief of police or his designee. 
(b)  Any abandoned vehicle removed from the reservoir bed shall be impounded until such time, but no longer than seventy-two (72) hours, as the full cost of the said removal may be calculated. 
(c)  The owner of any abandoned vehicle removed from the reservoir bed by the city shall pay in full the cost of said removal and present proof of such payment and ownership of the vehicle before said vehicle is released to the owner or responsible party for the vehicle. 
(d)  Appeals for the cost of removal of any abandoned vehicle under this article shall be as provided in the G.S. § 20-219.11(c) through (f); 20-219.12; 20-219.13; and 20-219.14. 
(e)  Failure to pay the cost of the removal and storage of any vehicle removed under this article shall be handled as provided in G.S. § 44A-4(b) through (g). The proceeds of any such sale shall be disbursed as provided in G.S. § 44A-5. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-11, § 1c., 10-22-07) 
Secs. 15-63-15-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOWN EAST FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS AND OTHER SPECIALLY DESIGNATED CITY SPONSORED EVENTS 

Sec. 15-76. - Activities prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to protect and promote the public health, safety, welfare, and enjoyment of participants at the Down East Festival, and other special designated city sponsored events, by regulating certain activities as enumerated herein. 
(b)  Applicability. This article shall apply to that city sponsored festival known as the Down East Festival of the Arts and may be made to apply to any other city sponsored festival or event if so designated by action of the City Council of the City of Rocky Mount. 
(c)  Hours and areas regulated. At the Down East Festival of the Arts, this article shall apply from 6:00 a.m. through 7:00 p.m. on the scheduled day of the event, or the rain date, if necessary, to all of that area bounded by Franklin Street, Hammond Street, Arlington Street and Goldleaf Street that is public in nature such as streets, sidewalks, parking lots and any other publicly owned property. 
    At other events designated by the city council, this article shall be applicable at such locations, dates and times as designated. 
(d)  Unlawful to operate bicycle or other wheeled vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle, tricycle, unicycle, moped, skateboard or any other wheeled vehicle, roller skates or roller blades (all hereafter referred to as "wheeled vehicle") on or within the boundaries of the Down East Festival or any other city sponsored event to which these provisions have been made to apply. For purposes of this article, "operate" shall mean the use, putting into action, or causing to function of a wheeled vehicle by a person mounted thereon. This article shall not apply to wheelchairs, baby strollers or baby carriages. 
(e)  Unlawful to throw balls, etc. It shall be unlawful for nay person to toss or throw a ball, Frisbee, model airplane or similar object on or within the boundaries of the Down East Festival or any other city sponsored event to which these provisions have been made to apply. 
(f)  Exception. Subsection (d) and (e) shall not apply to the operation of any wheeled vehicle or the throwing or tossing of any ball, Frisbee, or other object if the otherwise prohibited activity is part of an authorized exhibit or display. The director of the city parks and recreation department or his designee shall have the authority to specify the conditions under which wheeled vehicles may be operated and balls, Frisbees or objects may be thrown or tosses. 
(g)  Animals at the Down East Festival. Animals, whether on leashes or not, are prohibited at the Down East Festival and other special designated events sponsored by the city. 
    The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to dogs who accompany visually or hearing impaired persons. 
(h)  Unlawful to conduct outside sales. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, display, offer for sale or to sell any merchandise or other item, any service, food or beverage (hereafter referred to as "outside sales") on public property within the boundaries of the Down East Festival unless such person has been issued a permit for such outside sales by the city parks and recreation department. Any person conducting outside sales shall display the permit issued by the parks and recreation department in a conspicuous place at the location of the outside sales. 
    Such permit shall be presented upon the request of a law enforcement officer or any city employee who desires to inspect it for purposes of ensuring compliance with this article. 
(i)  Merchants. Operators of businesses located within the boundaries of the area described in subsection (c) herein, or within such other designated area, are exempt from the permitting requirements of subsection (h) provided that the items offered for sale during the date of the festival, or other event, are offered for sale on a regular and continuing basis. 
(Ord. No. 0-92-068, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Chapter 16 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERSONNEL PLAN OF THE CITY OF ROCKY MOUNT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Personnel, § 490 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-26. - Merit principle and equal opportunity in employment; affirmative action officer. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Applicability. This article shall apply to all segments of the city government. 
(2)  Purpose. The purpose of this article shall be to establish the city's policy regarding equal employment opportunity. 
(3)  Policy. It shall be the continuing policy of the city that they shall be no discrimination in the treatment of minority group job applicants or employees in the application of any city policy, practice, rule or regulation. Efforts to achieve and maintain a city work force that is appropriately balanced by race and sex shall be limited only by the vacancies that occur as a result of turnover and expansion, and by the availability of minorities and women with required skills. All applicants and employees, regardless of race, creed, national origin, sex, age, disability, religion or political affiliation, shall be treated on the same basis with respect to employment, performance evaluation, performance pay consideration, promotion, training opportunities and all other city activities. Sexual harassment, a form of sex discrimination, is prohibited and will not be tolerated. 
(b)  Affirmative action defined. For the purpose of this article, "affirmative action" shall be defined as a set of program objectives designed to increase the utilization of under-utilized minorities and women at all levels and segments of the city's work force. 
(c)  Affirmative action officer. Coordinator for the city in matters pertaining to equal employment opportunity shall be the city manager or his designee. His duties will be to coordinate the efforts of all segments of the city government. He shall regularly report to the city council concerning the state of progress, with recommendations where appropriate. Administration of this program shall be the responsibility of the city manager, or his designee, as the city's affirmative action officer. He has the support of the city council. He and the staff are responsible for the following: 
(1)  Implementing policy, affirmative action programs, and internal and external communication techniques; 
(2)  Assisting department heads in arriving at solutions to problems; 
(3)  Periodically auditing hiring and promotion patterns to ensure that goals and objectives are met and reported to the city council; 
(4)  Assisting in the identification of problem areas; 
(5)  All external recruitment sources shall be informed verbally and confirmed in writing of the city's policy, stipulating that such sources actively recruit and refer minorities for all positions listed. The city will include appropriate equal opportunity clauses in all external documents such as purchase orders, leases and contracts. The city will endeavor to publicize its program in various news media and will include the phrase "equal opportunity employer" on application forms and in advertisements for employment; 
(6)  Supervisors shall be directed to contact the equal employment opportunity coordinator for advice and counsel to ensure that all employees are given proper consideration for promotions, upgradings, transfers and other personnel actions. 
(Code 1967, § 2-13; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-94-66, § 1, 11-28-94) 
Sec. 16-27. - Responsibility of city manager. 
    The city manager shall be responsible for the administration of the personnel policies and rules which shall apply to all appointed employees except those specifically exempt. 
(Code 1967, § 2-14; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-28. - Human resources director. 
    Upon city council approval, the city manager may establish the position of human resources director. This individual shall assist in the preparation and maintenance of the position classification plan and the pay plan, and perform such other duties in connection with a modern personnel program as the manager shall require. If a human resources director is appointed, all matters dealing with personnel shall be routed through the human resources director who shall maintain a complete system of personnel files and records. 
(Code 1967, § 2-15; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-29. - Reciprocal agreements. 
(a)  The city is authorized and empowered to enter into reciprocal agreements, upon such terms as may be agreed upon, for the use of equipment, materials, facilities and services with any public agency or body for purposes deemed of benefit to the personnel system. 
(b)  The human resources director, acting in behalf of the city manager, may cooperate with other governmental agencies charged with public personnel administration, in conducting personnel tests, recruiting personnel, training personnel, establishing lists from which eligibles shall be certified for appointment and for the interchange of personnel and their benefits. 
(Code 1967, § 2-16; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-30. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall be applicable to all employees except as provided below: 
(1)  Elected officials shall be exempt from the provisions of this article except section 16-157. 
(2)  Part-time officials appointed by the city council to advisory or special boards and commissions shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(3)  Those employee appointments made by the city council pursuant to the Charter or state law shall be exempt from division 2 of this article only. 
(Code 1967, § 2-17; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Secs. 16-31-16-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

Sec. 16-46. - Coverage. 
    The most recently adopted Position Classification Plan of the City of Rocky Mount shall be the classification plan of the city which is on file in the city clerk's office. This classification plan shall include all regular classes of positions in the service of the city except as provided in section 16-30. 
(Code 1967, § 2-19; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-47. - Allocation of positions. 
    Authority to allocate positions to classes on the basis of the nature of duties and responsibilities is vested in the city manager. The city manager shall report allocations to existing classes to the city council for its information at the city council's first meeting following the effective date of the allocation. 
(Code 1967, § 2-20; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-48. - Establishment of classifications. 
    Authority to establish new classifications of positions is vested in the city council. The city council will consider recommendations of the city manager in determining the need for a new classification of positions. 
(Code 1967, § 2-21; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-49. - Maintenance of plan. 
(a)  The human resources department shall be responsible to the city manager for the administration and maintenance of the position classification plan. Department heads shall be responsible for bringing to the attention of the human resources department the need for new positions and material changes in the nature of duties, responsibilities, working conditions or other factors affecting the classification to which any existing or proposed position is allocated. The human resources department shall make appropriate studies and report its findings and recommendations to the city manager. 
(b)  When the human resources department determines that a substantial change has occurred in the nature or level of duties and responsibilities of an existing position or that a new position is required, it shall recommend to the city manager that he: 
(1)  Revise the existing position description in conjunction with the department head, or prepare a new position description; 
(2)  Allocate or reallocate the position to the appropriate class within the existing classification plan; or 
(3)  Recommend to the city council that it amend the position classification plan to establish a new class to which the position may be allocated. 
(Code 1967, § 2-22; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Secs. 16-50-16-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PAY PLAN 

Sec. 16-66. - Coverage. 
    The most recently adopted schedule of pay ranges and classes grouped by pay ranges shall be the pay plan for the city and is on file in the city clerk's office. The plan includes all regular classes of positions included in the classification plan. The provisions of the pay plan and this division apply to all regular, full-time employees except those exempted in section 16-30 or as otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1967, § 2-25; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-67. - Maintenance of plan. 
    The human resources department shall be responsible to the city manager for the administration and maintenance of the pay plan. Each year prior to the preparation of the annual budget the human resources department shall review the pay and fringe benefit programs of comparable governmental and private institutions in the area during the fiscal year. Based on the studies and recommendations of the human resources department and the general financial condition of the city, the city manager shall recommend to the city council such changes to the pay plan as necessary to maintain the fairness and adequacy of the pay plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-26; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-68. - Transition to new plan. 
    The following four (4) principles shall govern the transition to a new or amended pay plan: 
(1)  No employee shall receive a pay reduction as a result of the transition to a new pay plan; provided, that this provision shall not apply to a general pay plan reduction. 
(2)  Any employee, except those classified as trainees, being paid at a rate lower than the minimum rate established for his respective pay classification shall have his pay raised to the new minimum for the class. 
(3)  Any employee classified as a trainee shall receive a pay increase sufficient so that the pay relationship to the minimum of the appropriate class for that range does not change.
