(4)  Any employee being paid at a rate above the maximum rate established for his respected class shall remain at his present pay as long as the maximum is below the employee's present pay, except as may be specifically authorized by action of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-27; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-69. - Payment within range. 
    All employees covered by the pay plan shall be compensated at either the minimum or maximum of the range or at a rate between the minimum rate and the maximum rate for the pay range established for their respective job classification except employees whose salaries are above the established maximum rate following transition to a new plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-28; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-70. - Entrance at minimum. 
    Each new employee shall be appointed at the minimum pay which has been established for the classification in which he is employed, except: 
(1)  If the new employee does not meet the minimum requirements of the position and qualified applicants for the position are not available, the city manager may designate the employee as a trainee to be appointed at a salary below the minimum. 
(2)  When the city manager determines that there has been a demonstrated inability to recruit at the minimum salary or that an applicant possesses exceptional qualifications, the city manager may authorize the employment of an applicant at a higher rate than the minimum in the pay range. 
(Code 1967, § 2-29; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-71. - Trainee pay. 
    A new employee who does not meet all of the established qualifications for a position may be appointed with the approval of the city manager at a training pay no more than ten (10) percent below the minimum pay established for the position. The employee shall continue to receive a reduced salary during the probationary period until the appointing department head with the approval of the city manager determines that the trainee is qualified to assume the responsibilities of the position, or until the end of the probationary period when the employee is either discharged or moved to a listed rate in the pay range established for the position. 
(Code 1967, § 2-29; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-72. - Performance pay increases. 
(a)  The city manager shall each year include funds in the budget proposal to the city council providing for performance pay increases. 
(b)  Performance pay increases shall be granted to employees in recognition of individual job performance with the approval of the city manager, acting upon a recommendation of the employee's supervisors and department head. The amount of the performance pay increase shall vary depending on the employee's position within the assigned pay range, level of performance, and the annual guidechart for performance pay increases approved by city council. 
(c)  Typically, employees are eligible for performance pay increases once a year. However, if an exceptional performance level and/or other circumstances warrant, the city manager, upon recommendation of the department head and review by the human resources director, may grant more than one (1) increase per year to an individual. 
(d)  Employees in a trainee status as provided in section 16-71, part-time and temporary employees as defined in section 16-103, and employees serving a probationary period as provided in section 16-106 shall not be eligible to receive a performance pay increase. 
(e)  Regular employees who are serving a training period following promotion, transfer or voluntary demotion to a new job classification shall not be granted performance pay increases during that training period unless specifically authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 2-31; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-92-23, § 1(a), 4-13-92) 
Sec. 16-73. - Reclassified employees. 
    An employee whose position is reclassified to a class having a higher pay range shall receive an increase only if necessary to reach the minimum of the new salary range. An employee whose position is reclassified to a class having a lower pay range shall not receive a reduction in salary as a result of the reclassification. A reclassified employee is not considered to be serving a probationary or training period following the reclassification. 
(Code 1967, § 2-32; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-74. - Promoted employees. 
(a)  An employee promoted to a position in a class having a higher pay range shall receive a ten (10) percent pay increase or an increase to the minimum of the new salary range, whichever is higher, in recognition of the promotion. 
(b)  If an employee fails to perform satisfactorily in the new position, the employee may be: 
(1)  Reinstated to his former position if a vacancy exists; 
(2)  Moved to another position if a vacancy exists; 
(3)  Terminated. 
(c)  Following his promotion, a promoted employee shall serve in a training status for a period of time equal in length to the probationary period designated for the class of positions to which he has been promoted. At the end of the training period, the employee shall be: 
(1)  Retained in the position; or 
(2)  Granted an extended training period, subject to the concurrence of the human resources director; or 
(3)  Removed from the position in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 2-33; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-75. - Pay of transferred employee. 
    The pay of an employee reassigned to a position in the same class or to a position in a different class with the same salary range shall not be changed by the reassignment provided that such an employee may receive a pay increase with the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-76. - Demoted employees. 
    The pay of an employee demoted to a position in a class with a lower pay range shall be adjusted to five (5) percent above the minimum of the new range or to five (5) percent below his former pay, whichever is lower. With justification presented by the department head, recommendation by the human resources director, and with the approval of the city manager, a demoted employee may be placed at some other point within the new pay range. 
(Code 1967, § 2-35; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-77. - Part-time employees. 
    The pay plan established by this article is for full-time service. An employee appointed for less than full-time service shall be paid at a rate not less than the minimum pay for a comparable class of positions in the pay plan, as determined by the city manager. For the purpose of this section, part-time employees are defined as those employees who do not work an average of twenty-five (25) hours per week in the immediately preceding twelve-month period. 
(Code 1967, § 2-36; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-78. - Workweek. 
(a)  The standard workweek of city employees is defined as the period commencing at 7:00 a.m. Saturday and ending at 6:59 a.m., the following Saturday. 
(b)  Sworn law enforcement employees of the police department, who are below the rank of police sergeant, work on a rotating-shift basis and are covered by a twenty-eight-day work period rather than a seven-day workweek. 
(c)  Fire protection employees of the fire department, who are below the rank of fire captain, work on a rotating-shift basis and are covered by a twenty-seven-day work period rather than a seven-day workweek. 
(d)  Exempt salaried employees not covered by subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall work a sufficient number of hours to accomplish the tasks for which they are responsible but not less than thirty-seven and one-half (371/2) hours per week. 
(Code 1967, § 2-37; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-79. - Pay periods. 
(a)  All hourly (nonexempt) employees and salaried (exempt) employees shall be paid biweekly on Friday for hours worked through 6:59 a.m. on the preceding Saturday, except that employees working on a shift that ends at 8:00 a.m. shall be paid for the entire shift. 
(b)  Salaried law enforcement and fire protection employees working on rotating shifts shall be paid biweekly on Friday for the appropriate work period ending immediately prior to the established pay day. 
(c)  If the pay day falls on a holiday, employees shall be paid on the last day prior thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 2-37.1; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-80. - Effective day of pay adjustments. 
    Pay adjustments approved after the first working day of a pay period shall become effective at the beginning of the next pay period or at such other date as specifically authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 2-38; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-81. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2018-54, § 1, adopted June 11, 2018, repealed § 16-81, which pertained to personal payment by finance director and derived from Code 1967, § 2-39, Ord. No. O-91-45, § 1, adopted July 8, 1991; and Ord. No. O-94-66, § 2, adopted Nov. 28, 1994. 
Sec. 16-82. - Call-in pay. 
    Any hourly employee called in to work for any period not immediately before or after his normal work period shall receive call-in pay in the amount of one (1) hour's pay at the regular rate in addition to being paid for the actual time worked for each occurrence. Actual time worked shall be computed in one-half-hour increments with any portion of one-half hour being considered as one-half hour. This provision does not apply to any employee on a standby basis. 
(Code 1967, § 2-40; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-83. - Report-in pay. 
    Any employee who is unable to work because of inclement weather or other factors beyond the city's control shall receive report-in pay in an amount equal to one (1) hour's pay at the employee's regular rate, provided that the employee reports to his immediate supervisor at his normal place of work at his normal reporting hour. This pay is to be paid only once in any given day. 
(Code 1967, § 2-40.1; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-84. - Tardiness. 
    Employees who report late for work shall be docked for such time as they are late with a minimum of one-quarter hour's pay being deducted for any one (1) incident. Employees who are habitually late may be subject to dismissal by the department head. 
(Code 1967, § 2-41; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-85. - Payroll deductions. 
(a)  Payroll deductions are allowable for the purpose of facilitating employee contributions for certain specified purposes. An employee may authorize deductions from his paycheck for payments for employee benefit programs and safety equipment, contributions to recognized community service organizations, and for legally required payments for social security and income taxes. Authority to allow specific deductions within the aforementioned permitted categories is vested in the city manager, provided that deductions may not be allowed for a purpose which is not open to all employees. 
(b)  No deduction shall be made from an employee's paycheck without express written prior consent of the employee unless such deduction is required by law. 
(Code 1967, § 2-41.1; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-86. - Educational incentive pay. 
(a)  Any employee who completes a course of formal study while in service which leads to an associate, bachelor's or master's degree shall be eligible for educational incentive compensation in amounts as approved periodically by the city council; provided that: 
(1)  The course of study must have been pursued outside regular employment. 
(2)  The course of study must be directly related to the employee's current job, departmental jobs or preparing the employee for transfer/promotion within the city organization. 
(3)  The degree must not be a requirement for the position held by the employee. 
(4)  The employee must have completed his initial probationary period. Effective July 1, 2002, employees hired in regular full-time sworn law enforcement positions will immediately become eligible for educational incentive pay for college degrees they have earned. Effective October 1, 2004, employees hired in regular full-time firefighting positions will immediately become eligible for educational incentive pay for college degrees they have earned. 
(5)  An employee earning educational incentive pay who is promoted to a position for which the degree is required will no longer be paid the educational incentive for that degree. 
(b)  Educational incentive pay will be paid in addition to base salary and is not included in computing performance pay increases or other increases which are granted as a percentage of base salary. 
(c)  Any employee applying for educational incentive pay must have received approval from the human resources director prior to entering the course of study leading to the degree if the course of study was begun after November 1, 1977. 
(d)  The provisions of this section are not applicable to the degrees earned by those employees who have received merit increases for those degrees in lieu of educational incentive pay prior to July 1, 1976. 
(Code 1967, § 2-41.2; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-98-90, § 1, 12-14-98; Ord. No. 0-02-66, § 1a, 7-22-02; Ord. No. 0-2004-75, § 1, 9-13-04) 
Sec. 16-87. - Longevity pay. 
(a)  The city council shall appropriate funds as a part of the city operating budget for a longevity pay plan, in recognition of long years of continuous service. 
(b)  Each full-time employee employed as of July 31, 2011, as defined in subsection (d) of this section will be eligible for longevity payments according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Five (5) full years of service but less than ten (10) years ..... 2.5% 
(2)  Ten (10) full years of service but less than fifteen (15) years ..... 4.0% 
(3)  Fifteen (15) full years of service but less than twenty (20) years ..... 5.0% 
(4)  Twenty (20) full years of service but less than twenty-five (25) years ..... 6.0% 
(5)  Twenty-five (25) full years of service or more ..... 6.5% 
Employees hired after July 31, 2011, shall not be eligible for longevity pay. 
    Payment shall be a percentage of the sum of the employee's base annual salary as of June 30 plus any overtime paid to the employee for the fiscal year ending June 30. Credit shall be given for continuous time in service through June 30 of the calendar year in which payment is being made. Longevity payments are made once annually on a date specified by the city manager, usually in December between the twenty-fourth and twenty-sixth pay periods. Employees must be actively employed by the city at the time payments are made in order to qualify for longevity pay, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Leave of absence, military leave or other authorized leave shall not constitute breaks in service provided that the employee has not worked for another employer, with the exception of the armed forces in the case of military leave, prior to his return to the city. Resignations discharges or unauthorized leave shall constitute broken service. 
(d)  Employees employed on or before July 31, 2011, shall have their eligibility for longevity pay based upon their total regular full-time service with the city. Employees with a break in service as defined in subsection (c) above, and who are subsequently rehired on or before July 31, 2011, shall have their prior full-time service with the city counted in determining their rate of longevity pay; the period of time during which they were not employed full-time with the city shall not be credited toward their longevity record. 
(e)  Once an employee is rehired on or before July 31, 2011, for full-time service, the employee must work for five (5) consecutive years before he will become eligible to receive longevity pay. At that point, any prior service will be added to current service to determine the employee's longevity payment rate. 
(f)  Employees having service with another unit of government which is creditable to the retirement system shall receive credit for such service time if they were employed by the city prior to November 1, 1977. 
(g)  Employees who retire or die while in service and who are otherwise eligible shall receive longevity payments at the time of their separation from service or death as a part of final compensation, and their payment shall be computed at one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the total annual allowance that would otherwise accrue for each full month of service for which no allowance has been paid beginning with the preceding July 1. 
(Code 1967, § 2-41.3; Ord. No. 0-89-52, § 1, 6-26-89; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. O-2011-70, § 1, 7-11-11) 
Sec. 16-88. - Language skills incentive pay. 
(a)  An employee in the police, fire, finance (business office and collections) and utilities departments is eligible for language skills incentive compensation in amounts as approved periodically by the city council, provided that: 
(1)  The employee's possession and use of non-english language skills will be beneficial to the city's delivery of exceptional customer service; 
(2)  The employee's position, duties and schedule involve frequent customer contact and allow the employee to be available to other city work units who may need assistance in translating English to another language (or vice versa); 
(3)  The employee has demonstrated proficiency, through testing approved by the human resources department, in a language used by a significant portion of the city's customer base. Pay for languages in addition to Spanish (including American Sign Language) will be considered on a case-by-case basis and will be reviewed periodically by department heads and the human resources director. 
(b)  Language skills incentive pay may be discontinued when the employee is transferred to a position not allowing him/her to meet the eligibility criteria; when participation in the program interferes with regular job duties; when designated non-english language skills are no longer at the proficient level; or when the employee voluntarily withdraws from participation in the program. 
(c)  Employees choosing to participate in this program and who receive language skills incentive pay must be available on a regular basis to use bilingual skills. Typically, those language skills will be used during the employee's regular work hours; however, the city may require the employee to be available for stand-by or call back situations for up to a week with no additional "stand-by pay". 
(d)  Language skills incentive pay will be paid in addition to base salary and is not included in computing performance pay increases or other increases which are granted as a percentage of base salary. 
(e)  Any employee applying for language skills incentive pay must have received approval from the department head and human resources director prior to being tested for proficiency. 
(Ord. No. 0-2002-66, § 1b, 7-22-02) 
Sec. 16-88.1. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-88.2. - Stand-by pay. 
    Any employee who is specifically designated for a specified period of time to remain at home or in close contact so as to be available to answer emergency calls during off-duty hours shall be compensated for such inconvenience in an amount equal to seven (7) times the employee's regular hourly rate of pay for each calendar week on a stand-by basis. 
    Any hours actually worked while on stand-by shall be compensated at the normal rate of pay except that any hours so worked that are in excess of forty (40) for the applicable workweek shall be compensated at a rate of one and one-half (11/2) times the normal hourly rate of pay for the affected employee. 
(Ord. No. 0-90-21, § 1, 3-12-90; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Secs. 16-89-16-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - APPOINTMENTS, DISMISSALS, DEMOTIONS, SUSPENSIONS 

Sec. 16-101. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division shall be applicable to all employees except those exempted in section 16-30 unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1967, § 2-42; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-102. - Employment opportunities publicized. 
    The human resources director shall publicize opportunities for employment with the governmental unit including the pay ranges and employment qualifications for positions to be filled. 
(Code 1967, § 2-43; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-103. - Appointments. 
(a)  Role of human resources department. The human resources department shall be responsible for assisting the department head in recruiting and employing such employees as are authorized for the department by the classification plan and by the budget. All applications for employment shall be investigated by the human resources department which shall then refer those applicants most qualified for the position to the appointing department. No commitments shall be made to an applicant or employee before all available interested individuals have had the opportunity to be considered for the position. 
(b)  Authority designated. Department heads and the manager's staff shall be appointed by the city manager. Appointments to the position of city manager, city attorney and city clerk shall be made by the city council. 
(c)  Types of appointments. The types of employee appointments are defined as follows: 
(1)  Regular full-time: Appointed to an authorized regular full-time position requiring twenty-five (25) hours or more of work per week on average. 
(2)  Probationary: Appointed to an authorized regular full-time position and serving the initial probationary period following employment as provided in section 16-106. 
(3)  Regular part-time: Appointed to work in an authorized regular part-time position requiring less than twenty-five (25) hours per week on average. 
(4)  Temporary full-time: Appointed to replace a regular full-time employee who is unavailable for work due to approved leave or appointed to a temporarily or seasonally authorized position requiring twenty-five (25) hours or more per week on average. 
(5)  Temporary part-time: Appointed to replace a regular part-time employee who is unavailable for work due to approved leave or appointed to a temporarily or seasonally authorized position requiring less than twenty-five (25) hours per week on average. 
(Code 1967, § 2-44; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-104. - Qualification standards. 
    Employees shall meet the employment standards established by the position classification plan and such other reasonable minimum standards as to character, aptitude, ability to meet the public, and physical condition as may be established by the city manager with the advice and recommendations of the human resources director and department heads. 
(Code 1967, § 2-45; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-105. - Nepotism. 
(a)  Two (2) members of an immediate family shall not be employed in the same administrative division at the same time. 
(b)  No two (2) members of an immediate family shall be employed at the same time if it results in an employee's having regular direct or indirect supervisory authority of influence over management and personnel considerations affecting an immediate family member. 
(c)  Immediate family members of the city manager, assistant city manager(s), human resources director or finance director shall not be employed by the city. 
(d)  The provisions of this section apply to promotions, demotions, transfers, reinstatements and new appointments. Although these provisions are not intended to be retroactive, any circumstances or work assignments which conflict with this policy at the time of adoption of this section, should be reported to the city manager and resolved by the department head within one (1) year. 
(e)  Immediate family is defined as a spouse, parent, guardian, grandparent, grandchild, son, daughter, brother, sister and the various combinations of half, step and in-law relationships derived from these. Domestic partners, not married but living in the same household, are included in this definition. 
(f)  Departments may develop more restrictive policies on nepotism, subject to review of the human resources director and approval of the city manager, if they are determined to be in the best interest of departmental operations. 
(g)  Exceptions to the city's policy on nepotism can be made with the city manager's approval if unusual circumstances create significant recruitment difficulties or if employment of immediate family members in the same division will be limited to a short-term, temporary situation; however, the limitations set forth in 16-105(b) and (c) shall not be waived. 
(Code 1967, § 2-46; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-00-69, § 1, 8-14-00) 
Sec. 16-106. - Probationary period. 
(a)  All newly hired and rehired employees appointed to a regular, full-time position shall serve a probationary period following their date of hire or rehire. The standard length of the probationary period is six (6) months; certain classes of positions as designated by the city manager upon the advice of the department head and the human resources director may require a twelve-month probationary period. Employees serving a probationary period shall receive all benefits provided in accordance with this article, with the following exceptions or as otherwise provided: 
(1)  The employee may accumulate vacation leave but shall not be permitted to take vacation leave during the probationary period unless denial of such leave shall create an unusual hardship. Vacation leave may be granted to such employee only with the approval of the city manager. 
(2)  The employee, if dismissed during the probationary period, shall not be eligible to be paid for accumulated vacation leave. Furthermore, probationary employee does not have the right to appeal any suspension, demotion or dismissal action taken against him. 
(b)  Before the end of the probationary period, the employee's supervisor shall appraise the employee's performance in writing using the standard performance appraisal form, and the employee's department head shall indicate in writing to the city manager: 
(1)  That the employee has had an opportunity to discuss with his supervisor the employee's accomplishments, failures, strengths and weaknesses; 
(2)  Whether the employee is performing satisfactory work; 
(3)  Whether the employee should be retained in the position or should be discharged; and 
(4)  If the employee is to be retained in the position, whether the employee should receive a pay increase signifying the successful completion of the probationary period, or the employee has not yet completed the probationary period satisfactorily, and that the period should be extended for a specified period of time not to exceed six (6) months. 
(c)  A new appointee may be dismissed at any time during the probationary period if the appointing department head determines that the employee is not performing his assigned duties satisfactorily. 
(Code 1967, § 2-47; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-107. - Reinstatement. 
    An employee who has been separated because of reduction in force or who has resigned while in good standing shall be credited with his previously accrued sick leave if he is reinstated within ten (10) years. If the reinstated employee has continued to be a member of either the local government employee's retirement system or the law enforcement officers' benefit and retirement fund, he shall receive full credit for all accrued contributions to the time of his separation. The provisions of this section shall apply only to those employees who are reinstated after July 26, 1971. 
(Code 1967, § 2-48; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-108. - Discipline. 
(a)  Policy. It is the policy of the city to ensure the safe, efficient and effective conduct of its operations by establishing fair and reasonable rules and regulations governing the work performance and conduct of its employees and to administer and enforce these rules and regulations in an equitable manner without prejudice or favoritism. 
(b)  Definition. "Discipline" means the application of a method, through a system of rules, to ensure conduct of an employee which is in keeping with the objectives of the organization. It involves training and counseling to improve performance and rewards and penalties to correct behavior. 
(c)  Disciplinary system. The city's disciplinary system begins for an employee on his first day on the job and continues throughout his working career. The various elements that comprise this system include orientation, job instruction, corrective counseling, training, performance appraisal, reprimands, commendations, performance pay increases and disciplinary actions. 
(d)  Disciplinary actions. When an employee fails to meet the standards, objectives or rules for his job, work unit, department or the city, it is the responsibility of the employee's supervisor to take or recommend disciplinary action. The term "supervisor" may refer to the employee's immediate supervisors as well as other supervisors up the chain of command to department head who have the authority to initiate the following types of disciplinary actions: 
(1)  Corrective counseling; 
(2)  Oral reprimand; 
(3)  Written reprimand; 
(4)  Suspension without pay; 
(5)  Demotion; 
(6)  Dismissal. 
The degree of discipline administered in any given situation will depend upon the nature and severity of the infraction, the motive and past record of the employee, discipline administered in previous situations, and the applicable rules, regulations and procedures established in this policy statement and in departmental and work unit policies. 
(e)  Corrective counseling. 
(1)  Is an informal discussion between an employee and his immediate supervisor concerning an employee's job performance or conduct. 
(2)  Is designed to help the employee improve performance or conduct in the case of a minor mistake or rule infraction by clarifying the standards required, stressing the employee's good performance and weaknesses, and subsequently those steps necessary for correction. 
(3)  Can be administered by a supervisor without prior approval of the division or department head. 
(4)  Should be noted in employee's record located in the division or supervisor's incident file. 
(f)  Oral reprimand. 
(1)  Is a more formal discussion between an employee and his immediate supervisor concerning the employee's job performance or conduct. 
(2)  Is to be used where earlier counseling or training has not corrected the problem or where the employee has disregarded work rules or standards of conduct of a relatively serious nature. 
(3)  Can be administered by a supervisor without prior approval of the division or department head. 
(4)  Should be noted in employee's record located in the division or in supervisor's incident file. 
(g)  Written reprimand. 
(1)  Is a formal notification that the employee's work habits, performance or conduct are unsatisfactory and that the employee must improve or more serious action will be taken. 
(2)  Is to be used where earlier counseling, training or oral reprimands have not corrected the problem or where the employee has disregarded work rules or standards of conduct of a serious nature. 
(3)  Can be administered by a supervisor after prior review and approval by the division head. 
(4)  Must be recorded and a copy forwarded to the department head and to human resources department for placement in the employee's personnel file. To avoid misunderstandings it is strongly suggested that the written reprimand be signed by the employee acknowledging receipt. If the employee refuses to sign the reprimand, his refusal should be noted on the reprimand along with the date on which the reprimand is delivered. 
(h)  Suspension without pay. 
(1)  Disciplinary suspension means the temporary removal of an employee from his position without pay as a means of notifying the employee that his work habits, performance or conduct are significantly unsatisfactory. 
(2)  Nondisciplinary suspension means the temporary removal of an employee from his position without pay during the course of an investigation, hearing or trial of any criminal or civil matter or when suspension would be in the best interest of the employee or the city. 
(3)  Is to be used for severe infraction of rules or standards; for excessive violations after the employee has received a written warning and has made insufficient effort to improve performance; or for nondisciplinary reasons as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection. 
(4)  Can be administered by a supervisor: 
a.  Without prior approval if necessary to avoid undue disruption of work, to protect the safety of persons or property, or for other serious reasons. 
b.  With prior review and approval of the division and department head for up to six (6) workdays. 
c.  With prior review and approval of the division and department head and city manager for up to twenty (20) workdays. 
d.  With prior review and approval of the division and department head and city manager for an indefinite period of time as a nondisciplinary measure as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection. 
(5)  A copy of a notice to the employee will be forwarded to the human resources department and placed in the employee's permanent personnel record. 
(6)  An employee who has been suspended without pay will not be allowed to request annual or sick leave during the period of the suspension, nor will the employee accumulate annual or sick leave during this period. 
(7)  An employee who has been suspended without pay as a nondisciplinary measure and is subsequently fully reinstated may be authorized by the city council to receive full or partial pay and benefits for the period of the suspension. An employee who has been suspended without pay as a disciplinary measure and whose suspension, on appeal, is reversed may be awarded as much of the pay and benefits lost during the suspension as ordered by the city manager or recommended by a peer review panel. 
(i)  Demotion. 
(1)  Is the movement of an employee to a position in a class with a lower pay range. 
(2)  Is to be used when other disciplinary measures have been unsuccessful and the employee has continued to perform his duties unsatisfactorily. 
(3)  Can be administered by a supervisor only upon prior approval by the division and department head and human resources director. 
(4)  Must be fully documented in writing including the reasons for the demotion. This record will be forwarded to the human resources department and placed in the employee's permanent personnel record. 
(j)  Appeals. 
(1)  An employee served with an oral or written reprimand may file a grievance concerning the reprimand using the city's grievance procedure as provided in section 16-142. 
(2)  A regular full-time employee who has been suspended or demoted shall have the right to appeal the decision to the city manager within seven (7) calendar days of being notified of the decision. Within seven (7) calendar days of the receipt of the notice of appeal, the city manager or his designee shall schedule a hearing for the employee. At this hearing the employee shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to hear the evidence against him, to contest adverse evidence and to present favorable evidence. Within seven (7) calendar days following the hearing, the city manager shall render a written decision to the employee. In all such cases the decision of the city manager is final. 
(3)  As an alternative, a regular full-time employee who has been suspended or demoted may elect to appeal the decision to a peer review panel within seven (7) calendar days of being notified of the decision. The human resources director will facilitate the scheduling of an investigation by a panel of employees who have been trained as peer panelists. Because the peer review process is an "all employee" process, lawyers are not eligible to participate. An employee who is appealing a suspension or demotion decision may be assisted in preparing and presenting his grievance by a trained peer panelist. A written response, signed by all panelists, shall be issued notifying the employee of the panel's decision. In all cases going before a peer review panel, the decision of the panel is final. 
(Code 1967, § 2-49; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-109. - Dismissal. 
(a)  The provisions of this section are applicable to all regular full-time employees who have completed their probationary periods as provided in section 16-106. 
(b)  It is the policy of the city to correct the unsatisfactory work performance or conduct of its employees by providing each employee with the necessary information and training and by the fair and uniform use of disciplinary actions. When these efforts have failed, or when an employee's actions are of a serious or threatening nature, the city has the right and obligation, following a complete and fair hearing, to dismiss the employee from city service. 
(c)  Each supervisor has the authority to recommend the dismissal of an employee under his supervision. The employee's department head has the authority, after consulting with the human resources director concerning the facts of the case, notify the employee that he is being recommended to the city manager for dismissal. The department head must inform the employee that his dismissal will take effect unless the employee appeals the recommendation to the city manager or a peer review panel in accordance with provisions of this section. 
    The human resources director has the authority to review the facts of each case in which dismissal is recommended for conformance to policy and procedure. The human resources director acts in an advisory capacity only and does not have the authority to uphold or overturn the recommendation of the department head. 
    The city manager has the authority, upon the appeal of an employee, to uphold, alter or overturn the recommendation of the department head. In all such cases the decision of the city manager is final. 
    The peer review panel has the authority, upon the appeal of an employee, to uphold, alter or overturn the recommendation for dismissal by the department head. In all such cases, the decision of the peer panel is final. 
(d)  A regular full-time employee may be dismissed for any one (1) or combination of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud in securing or maintaining appointment or promotion; 
(2)  Inexcusable neglect of duty; 
(3)  Inefficiency or incompetency in performance of duties; 
(4)  Physical or mental disability which impairs performance of the work involved; 
(5)  Refusal to perform work assigned or to comply with reasonable written or verbal instructions of a supervisor; 
(6)  Use of alcohol or other mind-altering drugs while on duty, or reporting to work under their influence; 
(7)  Continued unexcused absence; 
(8)  Chronic absenteeism or tardiness; 
(9)  Conviction of a crime which will render the employee unable to perform tasks or which involves moral turpitude; 
(10)  Improper political activity as defined in section 16-158; 
(11)  Misuse, misappropriation, theft of or willful damage to public property; 
(12)  Discourteous treatment of the public or other employees; 
(13)  Use of abusive or obscene language or engaging in immoral or obscene behavior while on duty; 
(14)  Falsifying work or official city records; 
(15)  Unauthorized release of information which is designated by city policy as confidential; 
(16)  Disregard for citywide or departmental work and safety rules; 
(17)  Disregard for applicable residency restrictions; 
(18)  Failure to obtain or maintain a current license or certificate required by law as a condition for performing the job; 
(19)  Participation in any action that would in any way seriously disrupt or disturb the normal operation of the division, department or any other segment of municipal government; 
(20)  Possession of firearms or other deadly weapons on the job or on property owned, leased as lessee, operated, occupied, managed, or controlled by the city unless the employee is required as a condition of his or her employment to carry such firearms or deadly weapons. 
(21)  Acts during or outside of duty which are incompatible with the public service and which impair the ability of the employee to perform the tasks to which he has been assigned. 
The decision to recommend dismissal for any one (1) or combination of the above reasons will be based on the sound and considered judgment of the supervisor and/or department head in accordance with the provisions of this section to assure that the good of the city service is served thereby and that the intent of the policy is followed. 
(e)  Each employee who has been recommended by his department head for dismissal shall be presented with a written notice of such recommendation and shall have the right to appeal this recommendation to the city manager, or as an alternative, to a peer review panel, within seven (7) calendar days of his receipt of the notice or within ten (10) calendar days from the date the notice was mailed to the employee. 
    Within seven (7) calendar days of the notice of appeal, the city manager or his designee shall schedule a hearing for the employee. At this hearing the employee shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to hear the evidence against him, to contest adverse evidence and to present favorable evidence. 
    Within seven (7) calendar days following the hearing, the city manager shall render a written decision to the employee. In all cases, the decision of the city manager is final. 
    If the employee elects to appeal the recommendation for dismissal to a peer review panel, the human resources director will schedule a panel hearing within seven (7) calendar days of the notice of appeal. The employee may be assisted by a trained peer panelist in preparing and/or presenting his case. 
    Within seven (7) calendar days following the hearing, the peer panel will issue a written response to the employee signed by all panelists. In all such cases, the decision of the peer panel is final. 
(f)  An employee recommended for dismissal shall be immediately suspended without pay pending the exercise of his appeal rights. If the final decision is in favor of the employee, the city manager or the peer panel may award to the employee all or part of the pay and benefits lost as a result of the suspension. A dismissed employee is entitled to receive pay for all hours worked prior to his suspension pending appeal but is not entitled to any other back pay or pay for any unused vacation or sick leave. 
(Code 1967, § 2-50; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-96-2, § 1, 1-8-96) 
Sec. 16-110. - Reduction in force. 
    If a reduction in force becomes necessary, consideration will be given to the quality of each employee's past performance and the needs of the governmental unit as well as seniority in determining those employees to be retained. 
(Code 1967, § 2-51; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-111. - Exit procedure. 
    The human resources department shall be responsible for insuring that all debts owed to the city by a terminating employee are collected, and all compensation due a terminating employee is paid to the employee. In addition, prior to receiving their final pay all terminating employees will be interviewed by the human resources department to determine that all matters pertaining to the employee have been settled. 
(Code 1967, § 2-52; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Secs. 16-112-16-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT 

Sec. 16-126. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division shall be applicable to all employees except those exempted in section 16-30. The benefits provided by this division shall be for permanent full-time service unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1967, § 2-56; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-127. - Hours of work. 
    The hours of work of employees shall be as determined by the city manager from time to time. 
(Code 1967, § 2-57; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-128. - Overtime. 
(a)  All hourly paid employees shall be compensated at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours during the workweek. holiday pay, annual leave, sick leave, call-in-pay, report-in pay, and standby pay do not count as hours worked in determining eligibility for overtime pay at the premium rate. 
(b)  Sworn law enforcement employees of the police department below the rank of sergeant and fire protection employees below the rank of captain qualify for partial overtime pay exemptions based on their twenty-seven-day and twenty-eight-day work periods. Employees who work more than the maximum work hours established by federal labor regulations for those special work periods would be eligible for overtime pay at the premium rate. 
(c)  The city, as employer, may elect to grant compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay in cash. The compensatory time off is granted at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) hours for every hour of overtime worked. 
(d)  Under extreme emergency conditions, the city manager may determine that such conditions have imposed unusual and severe demands on city operations and employees, and upon such finding may authorize exceptions to the provisions of the overtime procedures stated in this section. The city manager may allow for additional pay or compensatory time for exempt/salaried employees who perform essential duties associated with an emergency and who would not ordinarily be eligible for overtime pay. Such exceptions allowing for additional pay do not apply to the city manager, his staff, or those exempt employees reporting directly to the city manager's office. The city manager shall report exceptions to overtime procedures under this provision to the city council for its information at the first council meeting following the effective date of the exceptions. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all regular and temporary employees. 
(Code 1967, § 2-58; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-96-54, § 1, 9-23-96) 
Sec. 16-129. - Vacation leave. 
(a)  Schedule. Each regular full-time employee with the appropriate number of years of service as defined in subsection (c) of this section shall earn vacation leave according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Less than five (5) full years of service, 2 × number of hours in normal workweek per year; 
(2)  Five (5) full years of service but less than ten (10) years, 2.4 × number of hours in normal workweek per year; 
(3)  Ten (10) full years of service but less than fifteen (15) years, 2.8 × number of hours in normal workweek per year; 
(4)  Fifteen (15) full years of service but less than twenty (20) years, 3.2 × number of hours in normal workweek per year; 
(5)  Twenty (20) full years of service but less than twenty-five (25) years, 3.6 × number of hours in normal workweek per year; 
(6)  Twenty-five (25) full years of service or more, 4 × number of hours in normal workweek per year. 
(b)  Breaks in service. Leaves of absence, military leave or other authorized leave shall not constitute breaks in service provided that the employee had not worked for another employer, with the exception of the armed forces in the case of military leave, prior to his return to the city. Resignations, discharges or unauthorized leave shall constitute broken service. 
(c)  Years of service. Employees shall have their eligibility for increased annual leave based upon their full-time service with the city. Employees with a break in service as defined in subsection (b) of this section, and who are subsequently rehired, shall have their prior full-time service with the city counted in determining their eligibility for increased annual leave; however, the period of time during which they were not employed full-time with the city shall not be credited. Employees having service with another unit of government which is creditable to the retirement system shall receive credit for such service time if they were employed by the city prior to November 1, 1977. 
(d)  Accumulation. Vacation leave may accumulate to a maximum of thirty (30) workdays of vacation leave, provided that upon the recommendation of a department head and with approval of the city manager, an employee may accumulate up to sixty (60) workdays of vacation leave for a special purpose. 
(e)  Conversion of excess accumulation. In the absence of any specific request by the employee to accumulate more than thirty (30) workdays of vacation leave, following the final pay period of the calendar year, any accumulated vacation leave in excess of thirty (30) workdays will automatically be converted to sick leave. 
(f)  Granting of leave. Employees shall be granted the use of earned vacation leave upon request at those times designated by department heads which will least obstruct normal operations of the department. However, an employee shall not be granted vacation leave while serving his probationary period unless the denial of the leave would create an unusual hardship. 
(g)  Final pay. Upon submission of his resignation, a regular, full-time employee shall be paid for vacation leave accumulated to the date of separate provided he has completed one (1) year of continuous service and provided he has submitted notice to his immediate superior at least two (2) weeks in advance of the effective date of resignation. An employee who is involuntarily separated without fault or delinquency on his part shall be paid for vacation leave accumulated to the date of separation. Compensation for accumulated vacation leave shall not be paid an employee separated for reasons of fault or delinquency or who does not submit the required notice. Upon the death of a regular employee, compensation for the accumulated vacation leave shall be paid to his estate. Final pay shall be limited to not more than thirty (30) workdays of accumulated vacation leave in all cases except in the event of the death of a regular employee. In such case all accumulated, unused vacation leave shall be paid. 
(Code 1967, § 2-59; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-94-66, § 3, 11-28-94) 
Sec. 16-130. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Privilege. Sick leave with pay is not a right which an employee may demand, but a privilege granted by the city. Notification of the desire to take sick leave should be submitted to the employee's supervisor prior to the leave or not later two (2) hours after the beginning of the scheduled workday. Departments or divisions may establish more restrictive rules regarding notification of a sick leave request if justified by the work schedule. If such rules are established, they are to be posted on employee bulletin boards and communicated to the employees affected. Failure to submit the required notice will subject the employee to loss of sick leave privileges. 
(b)  Rate earned. Each regular and probationary full-time employee shall earn sick leave at the rate of three and sixty-nine hundredths (3.69) hours per pay period (ninety-six (96) hours per year), except that firefighters shall earn sick leave at the rate of five and fifty-four hundredths (5.54) per pay period (one hundred forty-four (144) hours per year). For purposes of leave taken the firefighters' workday shall be considered to be each twelve (12) hours absent from duty. 
(c)  Granting. 
(1)  An employee may be granted sick leave from work with pay if his absence is due to sickness/disability, bodily injury, quarantine, required medical or dental examination or treatment, exposure to a contagious disease when continued work might jeopardize the health of others, or illness in the employee's immediate family which requires the care of the employee. 
(2)  In the event of the death of a member of the immediate family, the department head may grant an employee from one (1) to three (3) days of sick leave with pay per year. In the event of the death of some other family member or a close personal friend, an employee may be granted one (1) day of sick leave with pay per year. Subject to approval by the department head, additional time away from work in connection with the death of a family member or friend may be granted, but will be charged to vacation leave or will be taken as leave without pay. If the employee experiences more than one (1) incident per year of death among his family or friends, the department head may determine that additional sick leave days are warranted and should be granted during the same calendar year. 
(d)  Physician's certificate. Department heads may require a physician's certificate as to the nature of the illness and as to the employee's physical capacity to resume his duties for each occasion on which an employee uses sick leave, or requests leave, with or without pay, due to sickness. An employee who is absent due to sickness with or without pay five (5) or more times in a six-month period of one (1) day or more shall be required to furnish proof of illness for the next twelve (12) months in order to receive any sick leave benefits during the twelve-month period. The department head shall be responsible for the application of this provision to the end that employees shall not be on duty when they might endanger their health or the health of other employees, and there will be abuse of sick leave privileges. 
(e)  Accumulation. Sick leave shall be cumulative with no limit on the maximum accumulation. 
(f)  Credit for accumulated leave. 
(1)  Employees who retire, resign in good standing or are dismissed from employment with the City of Rocky Mount and are reinstated within ten (10) years shall retain all accumulated sick leave credit. 
(2)  Employees hired by the City of Rocky Mount on or after March 1, 2003, may transfer credit, upon their employment, for up to sixty (60) days or four hundred eighty (480) hours of sick leave accumulated but not used while working for another local or state government agency and participating as a contributing member of the N.C. Local Government Employees Retirement System or the N.C. State & Teachers Retirement System. Documentation of the leave balance with the former employer must be provided. Sick leave accumulation associated with withdrawn service is not eligible for transfer credit. 
(3)  After five (5) years of continuous service with the City of Rocky Mount as contributing members of the N.C. Local Government Employees Retirement System, employees may receive credit for the balance of sick leave accumulated but not used while working for another local or state government agency and participating as a contributing member of the N.C. Local Government Employees Retirement System or the N.C. State & Teachers Retirement System. Sick leave that may have been transferred upon initial employment in accordance with section 16-130(f)(2) will not be considered for additional credit. Documentation of the leave balance with the former employer must be provided. Sick leave accumulation associated with withdrawn service is not eligible for transfer credit. 
(4)  Employees who retire may receive additional service credit toward retirement for the unused portion of their sick leave in accordance with the applicable rules of the Local Government Employees Retirement System. Such credit shall be granted at the rate of one (1) month's service credit for each twenty (20) days of unused sick leave. 
(5)  No employee shall be paid for accumulated sick leave. 
(g)  Advancement. The city council may, on the recommendation of the city manager, advance sick leave to an employee with five (5) or more years of service who has exhausted his sick leave because of a major operation or illness. However, in no case shall sick leave be advanced in excess of two (2) working days per calendar year of service of the employee. 
(h)  Disability retirement. Any employee who has been on sick leave and/or leave without pay for a period of twelve (12) consecutive weeks shall be reviewed by the employee's department head and the human resources department. If at that time there is no likelihood that the employee will be able to return to work, the employee will be required to file an application for disability retirement. 
(i)  Shared leave provision. This shared leave program and policy has been established by the City of Rocky Mount for active duty employees who earn sick/vacation accruals. The purpose of this policy is to provide leave for eligible employees when attendance is inadvisable and/or impossible due to the catastrophic illness of the employee, as defined in subsection 6.27(B) of the City of Rocky Mount Personnel Policy, and when required absences exceed their accrued leave. The shared leave program is employee to employee and is available in addition to the benefits provided by the city. In cases of a catastrophic medical condition, an employee may apply for leave donations from other city employees and/or from the shared leave "bank." Consenting employees may agree to have leave donations transferred from their accumulated vacation balance to the sick account of a requesting employee or to the leave "bank". 
The city may modify or terminate the shared leave program at any time in its sole discretion. The shared leave program should be used before the city's advance sick leave provision. 
(1)  Definitions. 
a.  Serious medical condition: An incapacitating and/or life threatening non-job related illness/injury requiring an extended treatment and/or recovery period for which the employee anticipates being absent from work including, but not limited to cancer, major surgery, serious accident or heart attack, that: 
1.  Poses a threat to life or requires in-patient care, hospice care, or home health care; and 
2.  Keeps the employee from performing any portion of his regular work duties in accordance with a serious health condition as defined under the FMLA. 
Common illness or minor injury that is not serious or life threatening and incidents covered by worker's compensation and/or an employee's short-term disability policy shall be excluded from eligibility for shared leave. 
b.  Direct donations : Vacation leave donated from an employee to a qualifying named recipient. 
c.  Eligible employee : All regular employees with benefits, who have completed their initial probationary period with the city, shall be eligible to receive or to donate leave. 
d.  Shared leave bank : A holding account for leave. Leave can be donated directly to this account by employees to unnamed recipients. Unused donated leave is also deposited into this account. 
(2)  Leave recipient/employee requesting shared leave procedure. 
a.  Employee may request shared leave donations for a catastrophic medical condition if the employee has exhausted all accumulated vacation, sick, and compensatory hours. The application process can be initiated prior to the actual depletion of leave. 
1.  A request to receive donated leave and a certification of health care provider form, available in the human resources department and on the human resources department's web page, must be completed. If the recipient is unable to complete the application, their supervisor may do so upon verbal permission of the employee. No medical information can be released without the written signed consent of the recipient. 
2.  All applications to receive shared leave must first be submitted to the recipient's department head for his/her review before forwarding to the human resources department. If the department head determines that the employee meets the initial eligibility requirements of this rule, he shall provide a written recommendation to the director of human resources. The director of human resources may approve or deny the request. A denial of a request for shared leave may be appealed to the city manager. 
3.  When requesting shared leave, or at any time during the use of shared leave, an employee may be required by the director of human resources to undergo a medical review/examination to establish that the illness or injury is of a serious nature and keeps the employee from performing any portion of his regular work duties. If the employee fails to comply with the medical review and/or examination and/or fails to establish that a serious illness or injury exists, the use of shared leave shall be automatically denied or terminated by the director of human resources. 
4.  Once a request for shared leave has been approved by the director of human resources, all city employees will be notified that a recipient is in need of donations for shared leave. The shared leave program is voluntary and no employee shall be coerced, threatened, intimidated or financially induced into donating leave for purposes of this program. 
5.  Shared leave shall be applied retroactively to the date the employee depletes all forms of paid leave because of the current illness or injury. Shared leave shall be taken in full-hour increments. 
6.  While receiving shared leave the recipient shall not earn holidays, vacation or sick accruals. 
7.  Shared leave may be used only for the duration of the current serious illness or injury for which it was collected, up to a maximum of twelve (12) work weeks from the date the employee began using the shared leave. Shared leave may be granted for those serious health conditions for which the employee is expected to return to duty following a period of recuperation or treatment. 
8.  If the serious illness or injury improves so that the employee is no longer prevented from performing his regular work duties or the recipient separates from city service or retires, all unused portions of the shared leave shall be forfeited to a general pool. Leave time in this pool shall be administered by the department of human resources. Such leave time in this pool shall only be used to: 
(i)  Make up solicitation shortfalls, or 
(ii)  Be applied to the original recipient in the case of a relapse within a one-hundred sixty (160) work hour time period. When the employee has returned to work for one hundred sixty (160) consecutive, normal work hours, it shall be determined that he is no longer prevented from performing his regular work duties. 
(3)  Donor procedure. 
a.  An employee shall be eligible to donate only vacation hours to another employee or to the shared leave bank if the donation of vacation does not cause the accumulated vacation leave balance of the donating employee to be less than forty (40) hours. 
1.  Shared leave shall be paid according to the donating employee's regular rate of pay. The rate of pay of the donating employee shall be used in computing the amount of shared leave the requesting employee receives. For example, a leave donor who makes ten dollar ($10.00) an hour transfers an hour of vacation leave to a leave recipient who makes five dollars ($5.00) an hour. This translates into two (2) hours of sick leave for the leave recipient. 
2.  A shared leave donor authorization form, available in the human resources department and on the human resources department's website, must be completed. Shared leave shall be donated in full-hour increments. 
3.  Employees terminating service from the city are allowed to donate any vacation hours to the shared leave bank under this program. 
4.  Annual leave donation may be denied if it is determined by department head and approved by the human resource director that the potential leave recipient has a history of abusing sick leave. 
5.  Upon approval of the annual leave transfer application, the human resources department will forward the appropriate paperwork to the payroll technician. 
6.  Should the employee receiving donated leave terminate his/her employment with the city, direct donations balances will be deposited to the shared leave bank. 
(Code 19676, § 2-60; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-94-66, § 4, 11-28-94; Ord. No. 0-03-23, § 1, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 0-2005-101, § 1, 10-24-05) 
Sec. 16-131. - Sickness or disability covered by workers' compensation. 
    An employee absent from duty because of sickness or disability covered by the workers' compensation laws shall be eligible in accordance with the review and recommendations of the North Carolina Industrial Commercial as regulated by the North Carolina Workers' Compensation Act. The provisions of this section apply to all regular and temporary employees. 
(Code 1967, § 2-61; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-132. - Holidays. 
(a)  All employees shall receive full pay for the following holidays which shall be observed by all departments: 
New Year's Day; 
Martin Luther King's Birthday; 
Good Friday; 
Memorial Day; 
Independence Day; 
Labor Day; 
Thanksgiving Day and the following day; and 
Christmas. 
Regular part-time employees shall receive partial pay for the above-listed holidays based on the number of hours in their normal workday subject to the provisions in this section. 
(b)  Except for Christmas, which is provided for below, if the holiday falls on Saturday or Sunday, the preceding Friday or the following Monday will be observed as a holiday as determined by the city manager. Employees required to work on an observed holiday shall receive compensation at their regular rate for all hours worked on the holiday plus either: 
(1)  Holiday pay equal to their regular daily rate; or 
(2)  Time off on an hour-for-hour basis at a time which will least obstruct the normal operations of the department. If the employee actually works on the holiday and his hours worked during that workweek exceed forty (40), overtime pay will be due the employee for all hours over forty (40). 
Employees who do not work their regularly scheduled workday immediately preceding or following a holiday, and do not have authorized sick or annual leave, shall not receive holiday pay for the holiday. 
(c)  The Christmas holidays shall include December 24, 25 and 26. Eligibility for holiday pay for each department each year shall be the same as the eligibility for the general administrative offices as determined by the city manager. Holiday pay for the Christmas holidays shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of subsection (b) above. 
(d)  Holidays shall be defined as that period of time beginning at 7:00 a.m. on the day observed as the holiday and ending of 6:59 a.m. the following day, except that for the fire department, holidays are defined as that period beginning at 7:45 a.m. on the day observed as the holiday and ending at 8:00 a.m. on the following day. 
(Code 1967, § 2-62; Ord. No. 0-88-4, § 1, 1-11-88; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
State Law reference- Dates of public holidays, G.S. § 103-4. 
Sec. 16-133. - Military leave. 
    An employee who is a member of an armed forces reserve organization or the National Guard shall be granted two (2) calendar weeks of military leave for required military training in a calendar year, and any additional time necessary in the event of an emergency call-up. If the employee's military pay is less than the pay normally earned by the employee, the city will pay the employee sufficient salary to prevent a loss of his usual pay for the period of the military leave. 
    If an employee is called to active duty as a result of mobilization of forces by the commander-in-chief during a period of national emergency, the city manager shall request, and the city council may grant permission to pay an employee sufficient salary to prevent a loss in his/her usual pay for all or a part of the period of military leave. 
(Code 1967, § 2-63; Ord. No. 0-91-8, § 1, 2-11-91; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-92-23, § 1(b), 4-13-92) 
Sec. 16-134. - Civil leave. 
    An employee called for jury duty or as a court witness for the federal or state governments or a subdivision thereof shall be entitled to leave with pay for such duty in addition to keeping fees received for such duty. 
(Code 1967, § 2-64; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-135. - Educational leave. 
(a)  A leave of absence at full or part pay for a period not to exceed sixty (60) working days may be granted to an employee upon the recommendation of the supervising department head and with the approval of the city manager to permit an employee to take courses of study which will better equip the employee to perform his duties. 
(b)  Educational leave at full or part pay for a period not to exceed nine (9) months may be granted to an employee upon the recommendation of the supervising department head and with the approval of the city manager and the city council. 
(c)  An employee granted educational leave with full or part pay shall agree to return to the service of the city upon completion of his training and remain in the employ of the city for a period equal to twice the educational leave which he received, or reimburse the governmental unit for all compensation received while on educational leave. 
(Code 1967, § 2-65; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-136. - Reimbursement for training expense. 
    When an employee enters into a job-related training program with the prior approval of his department head and the city manager, he may be reimbursed for expenses such as tuition and books upon successful completion of the course. 
(Code 1967, § 2-66; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-137. - Leave without pay. 
    Upon the recommendation of the supervising department head and with the approval of the city manager, a regular full-time employee may be granted a leave of absence without pay for a period not to exceed six (6) months for reasons of personal or immediate family illness/disability, care of a newborn or adopted child, completion of education or special work which will permit the governmental unit to profit by the experience of the work performed. Notification and documentation of the need to extend an approved leave of absence shall be submitted to the city manager for review and approval. The provisions of this section do not apply to probationary employees. 
(Code 1967, § 2-67; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-138. - Insurance programs. 
    The city may make group life, accident, sickness and hospitalization insurance programs available for employee participation. Employees shall be enrolled in the programs upon their request or in accordance with the provisions of the insurance contracts. The city shall participate in the cost of the programs in such manner as determined by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-68; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-139. - Local government employees' retirement system. 
    Each employee shall be required to join the local governmental employees' retirement system as a condition of employment. Such membership shall commence on the first day of employment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-70; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-2004-85, § 1, 10-11-04; Ord. No. 0-2005-101, § 2, 10-24-05) 
Sec. 16-140. - Compulsory retirement. 
(a)  Excluding disability or voluntary earlier retirement, law enforcement officers, uniformed employees of the fire department, and electric line workers shall be retired on the last working day of the month which includes their sixty-fifth birthday. 
(b)  Each employee included in a group with a mandatory retirement age of sixty-five (65) as indicated in subsection (a) of this section may be granted one-year extensions in service annually by the city council, subject to the annual recommendation of the employee's department head and the city manager and upon the finding of a medical examiner designated by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-71; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-141. - Clothing allowance. 
    Law enforcement officers required to wear civilian clothing in the performance of their official duties shall be paid a clothing allowance, the amount and time of payment of which shall be determined by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-72; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-142. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)  Purpose. The city recognizes that the fair and prompt resolution of employee problems, complaints and questions is critical to good employee relations. For that purpose, a formal grievance handling process has been established. This process is intended to enhance, not replace, communications between an employee and his/her supervisors. It is not intended to preclude use of an "open door" policy, wherein an employee may discuss work-related matters directly with any level of management or with human resources staff. Both the grievance handling process and the traditional "open door" policy are designed to encourage an employee to voice concerns about how the application of city policies or procedures may have affected him/her. Retaliation, in any form, against an employee who makes use of this process will not be tolerated. 
(b)  Policy. It is the policy of the city to provide a procedure to ensure that all employees have the opportunity for presentation and resolution of their grievances, complaints or problems in an atmosphere of mutual respect and understanding. All administrative and supervisory personnel are expected to act promptly and objectively within the framework of this policy. It shall be the responsibility of the Human Resources Director to review matters submitted by employees on the grievance and appeal forms to determine eligibility for investigation or resolution under the grievance handling process. 
(c)  Grievance defined. A grievance is a complaint or problem experienced by an employee pertaining to the terms and conditions of his/her employment, the application of city policies, the working relationships between an employee and his/her supervisor, or the working relationships between an employee and his/her coworkers. 
(d)  Procedure. When an employee experiences a grievance, he/she shall follow the procedure outlined below: 
(1)  Step 1. The employee should discuss the problem with his/her immediate supervisor to seek a mutually satisfactory solution. Within two (2) working days, that supervisor will meet with the employee to give a verbal response to the grievance. If not satisfied, the employee may proceed to the next step in the process within two (2) working days of the immediate supervisor's response in step 1. 
(2)  Step 2. The employee shall document his/her grievance on the standard grievance and appeal form with a written statement of the situation and what action is requested to rectify the matter. The form shall be submitted to the Human Resources Director for forwarding to the next level of management, which in most cases, will be the division head. Within five (5) working days, the manager at that level will schedule a meeting with the employee to discuss his/her response to the grievance. Within two (2) working days of this meeting, the employee will indicate acceptance or rejection of the division head's response on the grievance and appeal form. If the response is rejected, the employee may proceed to step 3. 
(3)  Step 3. The employee takes his/her grievance form to the Human Resources Director for delivery to the next level of management, typically the department head. Within ten (10) working days, the department head shall meet with the employee to discuss the results of his/her investigation into the matter and his/her response. The department head's response shall be documented on the grievance and appeal form. Within two (2) working days, the employee shall indicate acceptance or rejection of the department head's response by marking the appeal form appropriately. If the employee rejects the response, he/she may proceed to step 4. 
(4)  Step 4. The employee may, within five (5) days, elect to appeal the department head's response to: 
a.  The city manager-The city manager, or his designee, shall meet with and respond to the employee's grievance with ten (10) working days following the employees' rejection of the response in step 3. Within five (5) working days following the meeting with the employee, the city manager shall document his response to the grievance on the appropriate appeal form with a copy being furnished to the employee; or 
b.  The peer review panel-If the grievance is of a nature that the matter may be heard by a peer review panel, the employee may elect this route by so notifying the Human Resources Department. 
(5)  Step 5. In the event the subject matter of the grievance involves a loss, or reduction, of pay, or job, the employee may bypass steps 1-4 and proceed directly to step 5. 
    In step 5 the employee may request a hearing before the city manager, or his designee, or the peer review panel. The employee shall make the selection by completing the necessary forms in the Human Resources Department. 
a.  The city manager-If the employee elects this route, he/she will receive an administrative hearing at which he/she may be represented by an attorney and may call witnesses on his/her behalf. The city manager, or designee, in making a decision in the case, will make a finding of fact to support the decision in resolution of the grievance and may sustain or modify the supervisor's recommendation. In case of disciplinary action, the city manager has the right to disciplinary action, the city manager has the right to lessen or increase any action recommended by the employee's supervisor(s) based on the facts in the case. 
b.  The peer review panel-If the employee elects this route, he/she has elected to participate in an employee process. The employee may be assisted in preparing or presenting his/her grievance by a trained peer panelist, but lawyers, not being city employees are not eligible to participate in the peer review process. In cases of disciplinary action, the peer panel may decide to modify the action taken, but in no case can the panel make the discipline more severe than originally recommended by the employee's supervisor. 
(e)  Rights of employee. The employee or employees shall have the right to seek the assistance of anyone in the written presentation of their grievance. The employee or employees shall be allowed reasonable time with pay during working hours if needed to prepare for the presentation of a grievance, provided such time has been cleared with the employees' immediate supervisor so that the employees' absence will not interfere with the efficient operations of the department/division. The right of all employees to use the grievance procedure for the purposes set forth in this policy shall be protected by each supervisor involved. 
(f)  Extension of time limits. Due to the complexity of the grievance, availability of pertinent information, or other factors beyond the supervisor's control, he/she may not be able to meet the time limits for response outlined in the procedure. In that event, the supervisor must inform the employee of how much more time will be needed. No extension longer than twice the amount of time established in the procedure will be allowed. In cases where the supervisor takes more than the established time to render a decision, the employee will be granted an equivalent extension of the period allotted for him/her to consider acceptance or rejection of the response.
