If the aggrieved employee fails to appeal the decision of a supervisor to the next step in the grievance procedure during the time allotted, it will be considered that the employee has accepted the decision rendered. If the supervisor fails to respond to an employee's grievance within the time period specified, without having requested an extension, the grievance will automatically advance to the next level of management for review and resolution. 
(g)  Distribution of report form. Upon the final resolution of the grievance, either by the City Manager's or peer panel's rendering a decision, or by the employee's accepting the decision of a superior, the Human Resources Director will be responsible for filing a copy of the decision in a confidential grievance file. In cases involving appeals of disciplinary action, the decision shall be documented in the employee's permanent personnel record. 
(Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-92-23, § 1(c), 4-13-92) 
Sec. 16-143. - Protest of information in personnel file. 
    If an employee feels any material in his personnel file is misleading or inaccurate, the employee may file a statement of protest with the director of human resources to be placed in his personnel file. 
(Code 1967, § 2-74; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Secs. 16-144-16-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CONFLICT OF INTEREST AND POLITICAL ACTIVITY 

Sec. 16-156. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division shall be applicable to all employees except those exempted in section 16-30. 
(Code 1967, § 2-78; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 16-157. - Conflicts resulting in financial gain; outside employment. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Conflict of interest means any act in which an elected official, appointed official or appointed employee receives a direct or indirect gain as a result of the exercise of their official responsibilities or as a result of using the position to which they have been elected or appointed. In any case in which a conflict of interest may be present, elected officials, appointed officials and employees appointed by the elected officials should make the circumstances known to the mayor or city council; and all employees appointed by the city manager should make the circumstances known to the city manager for a determination as to whether a conflict of interest does exist. 
(2)  Elected officials means those individuals elected to a position as may or councilmember. 
(3)  Appointed employees means individuals appointed to office by the city manager or his designee, and the city manager and city clerk. 
(4)  Immediate family means the same as defined in section 16-105. 
(5)  Appointed officials means those individuals appointed by the mayor, city council or any other governmental body or private entity to membership on a city board or commission. 
(b)  Specific acts creating conflicts. The following acts are deemed to be in conflict with the city's best interest: 
(1)  For an elected official, appointed official or appointed employee to give or receive gifts of more than token value which are in any way connected with their service or employment; 
(2)  For an elected official, appointed official or appointed employee or any member of their immediate family to benefit personally from any purchase of goods or services or to derive personal gain from any transaction in which they have an influence; 
(3)  For an elected official or appointed employee to have any direct or indirect interest in any enterprise doing business with the city except as a shareholder in a publicly-owned company where the amount of shares owned represents ten (10) percent of less of the total outstanding shares; 
(4)  For an elected official, appointed official, or appointed employee to loan or to borrow from individuals or concerns that do business with the city, except banks and other financial institutions; 
(5)  For an elected official or appointed employee to serve as an officer, director, employee or consultant of, or to receive income from, any enterprise doing business with the city or to seek to do so, except as may be permitted by law. 
(6)  For an appointed employee to use or permit others to use city employees, materials or equipment for personal purposes except in accordance with established policies permitting the same; 
(7)  For an appointed employee to accept compensation from noncity-related enterprises for services or time for which the employee is being paid by the city; 
(8)  For an elected official, appointed official or appointed employee to disclose to any person any information which may be used by the recipient for personal gain unless such information is in the public domain and generally available to others; 
(9)  For an appointed employee to accept any outside employment unless the same has been approved by the employee's department head and by the human resources office; in those cases where such employment is similar to or related to the employee's primary job responsibility, such approval must be granted by the city manager; 
(10)  For an elected official, appointed official or appointed employee to discuss possible future employment with a person, firm or any other business entity that is dealing with or may reasonably be expected to deal with the city concerning matters within the elected official's, appointed official's or employee's official duties or area of responsibility without disclosing such discussion concerning possible future employment to the city manager in the case of appointed employees or the mayor in cases of elected or appointed officials. 
(11)  For an elected official or appointed employee to commit any violation of G.S. § 14-234. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any violation of this section shall be deemed to be a conflict of interest and shall subject such violating employee to dismissal or other disciplinary action by the appointing authority or such legal action as permitted by the appropriate laws or ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 2-79; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-02-116, §§ 1a-1f, 12-9-02; Ord. No. 0-03-6, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 16-158. - Post-employment and post-service restricted. 
(a)  Based on the principle that good government needs to be honest, fair and accountable and that integrity sustains public confidence in government, an elected official, appointed official or employee shall be restricted in the following activities for one (1) year following his/her service or employment with the city: 
(1)  A former elected official, appointed official or appointed employee may not appear for compensation before the city, or its boards or commissions, on behalf of any person or private interest regarding any matter with which the official or employee was directly concerned during his or her city service or employment. To "appear" includes making any oral or written communications, including letters or phone calls, to any elected official, appointed official or appointed employee with the intent to influence a decision on behalf of any person or business. For purposes of this section, a former official or employee is presumed to have had access to knowledge or information concerning all work performed by subordinate personnel. 
(2)  A former elected official, appointed official or appointed employee may not disclose or use, for private advantage or personal profit, any confidential information acquired in the course of his city service or employment which is not otherwise made available to the public. 
(3)  The restrictions contained in this section on post-employment or post-service shall not apply to positions with or representation on behalf of any other local, state or federal agency. 
(4)  Following separation from city service, a former elected official, appointed official or appointed employee may negotiate for or hold a position prohibited by this section if, after review of the mayor, for elected or appointed officials, and the city manager, for appointed employees, it is determined that the position involves no conflict with the purposes and interests of the city. Such findings shall be in writing and made public by the city council. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from contracting directly with a former elected official, appointed official or appointed employee to represent the city's interests. 
(c)  Penalties: 
(1)  Upon determination by the city that a violation of this section, involving contract work, business, sale or transaction, has occurred, and upon recommendation of the city manager, the city council shall have the power to make the transaction in question null and void. 
(2)  Any person found to be in violation of this section may be disqualified from being appointed or employed in service to the city for a period of one (1) year. 
(3)  Any person or business found to be in violation of this section may be subject to other disciplinary or legal action permitted by the appropriate laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-116, § 2, 12-9-02) 
Sec. 16-159. - Political activity restricted. 
(a)  Every employee has a civic responsibility to support good government by every available means and in every appropriate manner. Each employee may join or affiliate with civil organizations of a partisan or political nature, may attend political meetings, may advocate and support the principles or policies of civic or political organizations in accordance with the constitution and laws of the state and in accordance with the Constitution and laws of the Unites States of America. However, no employee shall: 
(1)  Engage in any political activity while on duty; 
(2)  Be required as a duty of his office or employment, or as a condition for employment, promotion or tenure of office, to contribute funds for political or partisan purposes; 
(3)  Solicit, or act as custodian of, funds for political or partisan purposes; 
(4)  Coerce or compel contributions for political or partisan purposes by any other employee of the governmental unit; 
(5)  Use any supplies or equipment of the governmental unit for political purposes; 
(6)  Hold political office except political party office. 
(b)  Any employee who wishes to become a candidate for partisan or nonpartisan political office shall obtain an approved leave of absence prior to the announcement of his candidacy. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be deemed improper conduct and shall subject such employee to dismissal or other disciplinary action by the appointing authority. 
(Code 1967, § 2-80; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-02-116, § 3a, 12-9-02) 
Sec. 16-160. - Political campaigns. 
    Campaign speeches or other political activities by individuals seeking an elective office shall not be conducted on the premises of any city property nor shall any political candidate for office seek to contact and talk to employees while the employees are working for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-81; Ord. No. 0-91-45, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 0-02-116, § 3b, 12-9-02) 
Sec. 16-161. - Service on certain city boards, authorities, and committees prohibited. 
    No employee of the city shall serve as a regular or alternate member of the community appeals board, board of adjustment, planning board, Rocky Mount Wilson Airport Authority, or the transportation advisory committee; provided, however, city employees may serve as ex-officio members of such boards, authorities, or committees as provided by the city council, and provided further, any city employee serving as a regular or alternate member of any such board, authority, or committee on the date of adoption of this section may complete his or her term but shall not serve any additional term on such board, authority, or committee. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-5, § 1, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 0-02-116, 12-9-02; Ord. No. O-2011-85, § 4, 9-12-11) 
Chapter 18 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; animals, Ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 10; refuse, trash and waste, § 10-91 et seq.; housing, Ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 19; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 21; zoning, App. B. 
State Law reference- Radioactive waste, G.S. § 104E-1 et seq.; solid waste management, G.S. § 130A-290 et seq.; waste containers on highways, G.S. § 136-18.3; public enterprises, G.S. § 160A-311 et seq.; placing glass or injurious substance in road, G.S. § 136-91; regulation of the placing of trash, refuse and garbage in city, G.S. § 160A-303.1. 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bulk container means a waterproof metal container of not less than four (4) cubic yards, or more than eight (8) cubic yards in size, designed for solid waste storage and compatible for mechanical lifting and emptying by city-operated solid waste collection vehicles. 
    Bulky solid waste means large items such as metal furniture, appliances or other items either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste transportation vehicles by collection personnel with the equipment available therefor. 
    Central business district means that area of the city bounded by Arlington, Franklin, Hammond and Thomas Streets. 
    Commercial solid waste means solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, institutional or mobile home park and multiple housing facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Construction, demolition, land clearing and landscaping solid waste means discarded or unused construction materials, lumber, masonry, fixtures, stumps, trees, brush, dirt and other waste material resulting from construction, reconstruction, repair and demolition of buildings, structures or other improvements or from land clearing and landscaping activities on improved or unimproved property including trees exceeding six (6) inches in diameter at ground level. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a structure, and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or intended to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage solid waste means all putrescible wastes, including animal and vegetable matter, resulting directly from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food by humans, including food wrappers and containers, and minimum amounts of liquid necessarily incident thereto but excluding sewage and human waste. 
    Hazardous solid waste means waste or combination of wastes, in any form, which because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical, ionizing or infectious characteristics may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness, or which poses a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported or disposed of or otherwise managed. 
    Industrial solid waste means sawdust, shavings, feathers, cartons, boxes, glass, paper, wood, textiles, chemicals, plastic or other waste materials from processing plants, factories or manufacturing operations. 
    Medical solid waste means waste generated in connection with the testing, treatment or care of medical patients who have or may have communicable diseases, such as bedding or clothes, used instruments or utensils, pathological specimens or other similar material. 
    Multiple housing facility means a housing facility containing more than one (1) dwelling under one (1) roof. 
    Occupant means any person who, alone or jointly with others, is in actual possession of any dwelling unit or any other improved real property, either as owner or as a tenant. 
    Residential solid waste means solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding mobile home parks and multiple housing facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Rollout container means a 90, or under certain conditions enumerated herein, a 65-gallon capacity container of heavy duty plastic material held by a steel frame mounted on wheels and approved by the director of public works for containing residential solid waste until it is collected for disposal at a landfill. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state resulting from normal urban activities. 
    Yard solid waste means grass clippings, leaves, tree trimmings, shrubbery trimmings and other small quantities of rubbish normally coming from an occupied premises. 
(Code 1967, § 9-17; Ord. No. 0-90-66, § 1, 9-24-90) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-2. - Administration. 
    The collection, removal and disposition of all solid waste from within the city shall be under the jurisdiction and enforcement of the director of public works and his authorized agents, except as otherwise provided by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 9-18) 
Sec. 18-3. - Right of entry. 
    Solid waste collection personnel are hereby authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this chapter. Solid waste collection personnel shall not enter any building or part thereof including garage or carport for the purpose of collecting solid waste. 
Sec. 18-4. - Ownership of solid waste. 
    Upon collection of solid waste by the city, all such solid waste shall become the property of the city. 
Sec. 18-5. - Unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container which is not the property of that person without the consent of the owner of the container. 
(2)  Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection personnel or solid waste collection and transport equipment. 
(3)  Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the director of public works. 
(4)  Permit any dirt, rocks, sand, brick, broken concrete, lumber, tree trunks, limbs or trimmings, cinders, plaster, gravel, paper, cardboard or any similar material to fall, be scattered or blown upon any street from any vehicle transporting such material, or fail to remove such material immediately from the street. 
(5)  Place, discard, dispose or leave any solid waste upon a street or highway within the city, or upon any property owned or operated by the city unless such solid waste is placed in a designated location or in a solid waste container. 
Sec. 18-6. - Promulgation of regulations. 
    The director of public works may make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary regulations, not inconsistent with city ordinances, governing the storage, collection, transport, receiving and transfer, and disposal of solid waste. 
Sec. 18-7. - Precollection practices. 
    The occupant and/or owner of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial or business, industrial or other establishment producing solid waste within the corporate limits of the city shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid waste to serve such dwelling unit or establishment during the intervals between regular collections as provided in this chapter; and shall maintain such solid waste containers at all times in good repair and the area in which they are placed in a clean, neat and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1967, § 9-20) 
Sec. 18-8. - Residential solid waste storage, containers, etc. 
(a)  Garbage solid waste shall be stored in a rollout container until collected for disposal. Excess garbage which cannot be placed in the container must be bagged and on collection day placed beside or on top of the rollout container at curb side. Rollout carts shall be placed at the street curb or edge no earlier than dusk on the evening prior to scheduled collection and no later than 7:30 a.m. on collection days. Containers shall be returned to the back yard after collection but not later than the end of the collection day. 
    Failure to abide by this policy will result in the following penalty: 
Residents who leave their rollout carts at curbside in violation of this policy shall receive a courtesy card warning for the first violation and a warning sticker for the second violation. Third and future violations of failure to return the cart to its proper location will result in imposition of a penalty fee in an amount established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the fees and charges section of the administrative policy manual. 
(b)  Yard solid waste shall be securely bagged, boxed, packaged or otherwise containerized into one-man loads not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight, and placed at the curbline of the street for collection. Tree and shrubbery trimmings may be excluded from the containerizing requirement if cut into four-foot lengths and neatly stacked behind the curb with butt ends toward the street. Leaves may be excluded from the containerizing requirement during the portion of the year when special leaf collection equipment is in operation. During that time, leaves may be loosely piled directly behind the curbline but not in the gutter line or travel way portion of the street for collection. However, such loose piles of leaves will not be collected unless they are free of broken glass, cuttings, limbs, wire, or other debris that might damage collecting equipment. Yard solid waste may be placed in the rollout container if space permits. 
(c)  Bulky trash items such as worn-out furniture, stoves and other bulky items exceeding a one-man load will be collected if placed adjacent to and behind the front curbline or ditch line. The city will collect only those discarded appliances from which the electric motors have been removed. It shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or individual requesting collection of an appliance to remove the electric motor prior to collection by the city. Refrigerators and food freezers shall have the doors or lids removed. 
(d)  The occupant shall be responsible for maintaining the rollout container in a clean and operable condition. 
(e)  The city will furnish at no cost to the property owner one 90-gallon rollout container to each existing residence and business that is not already served by a dumpster. "Existing" residences and businesses are those that the city has certified for occupancy on or before July 1, 1991. Residences and businesses developed and certified for occupancy after July 1, 1991 will be required to furnish an approved rollout container at the property owner's expense in order to receive refuse collection service. 
(f)  The city will furnish one (1) container for each dwelling unit on a lot (for example, a duplex will receive two (2) containers). The owner of the property is responsible for the security and maintenance of the container and for its replacement in the event it is lost or removed during residency changes. The city will replace stolen carts, without cost, if a police report evidencing such theft is presented to the superintendent of environmental services. The owner, however, may provide in the lease agreement provisions that set forth the responsibilities of the tenant to the owner in the event the container has to be replaced. The city is not a party to any such agreement and will look to the owner to provide the container. An owner of property shall have ten (10) days after written notice to provide, or repair, a rollout container if none is available. The city will provide collection service for not more than two (2) containers per dwelling unit or business. The director of public works has authority to waive this limitation in circumstances where dumpster service is not practical or feasible. 
[(g)  Reserved.] 
(h)  The city will provide collection service to some properties using a 65-gallon container in accordance with the following conditions: 
(1)  The container must be requested by the occupant and approved by the superintendent of environmental services and meet city standards. 
(2)  The residence must be occupied by one person. 
(3)  The city will provide the container at no cost to the owner until July 1, 1991. 
(4)  The city reserves the right to replace the container with a 90-gallon container at any time it is determined by the superintendent of environmental services that the smaller container is not providing for the needs of the occupant. 
(i)  The city will exempt residents who are physically incapable of rolling the container to the street as certified by a physician, provided there is no relative, custodial or other help in the home capable of rolling the cart to the street. Residents with existing exemptions based upon age will retain their exemption 
    Residents may apply for exemption to this policy on forms provided by the city. The superintendent of environmental services will approve requests for exemption. 
    The superintendent will grant exemptions upon determination of physical incapability as certified in writing by a physician and determination that there is no relative, custodial or other help present in the household physically able to roll the container to the street. 
    Exemptions are valid for one (1) year from the date of the approval and must be certified annually based upon a verification by environmental services staff. A representative of the environmental services division will visit the applicant at renewal time to ascertain any changes in circumstances. Exemptions may also be secured on a temporary basis if warranted. The city will provide assistance in completing the application form as needed. Collection service to exempt residents will be provided in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  Once per week collection service on Thursday or Friday unless more frequent collection is approved by the city manager. 
(2)  Refuse must be placed inside the rollout container. 
(3)  The city will approve the location of the container near the house. 
(4)  The city's refuse collectors will roll the container to the truck, empty it, and return it to the location near the house. 
(Code 1967, § 9-20; Ord. No. 0-90-66, § 1, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 0-92-74, § 1a, 9-28-92; Ord. No. 0-97-21, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-97) 
Sec. 18-9. - Commercial solid waste storage. 
    Commercial solid waste shall be stored in bulk containers of such size and number approved by the director of public works, and shall be placed in locations conveniently accessible to waste collection equipment. Exceptions to the bulk container requirement may be made by the director of public works if insufficient space exists on a premises, container location is inaccessible to waste collection equipment or other conditions exist that conflict with the public interest. Upon approving an exception to the bulk container requirement, the director of public works shall specify the type, size, number, and location of other solid waste containers. All containers shall be leakproof, waterproof, kept in good repair and covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 9-20) 
Sec. 18-10. - Industrial solid waste. 
    Industrial solid waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the operator of the factory, plant, operation or enterprise creating or causing the waste. 
Sec. 18-11. - Construction, demolition, land clearing, landscaping solid waste. 
    All construction, demolition, land clearing and landscaping solid waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the contractor or builder or, in the event of their failure, by the occupant of the property. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 18-12. - Refuse collection fees and charges. 
(a)  Charges and fees for the collection and disposal of solid wastes and recyclable waste shall be established by the city council from time to time, a schedule of which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Charges and fees shall apply to the following categories of customers receiving solid waste collection service from the city: 
(1)  Residentially and nonresidentially occupied property whose solid waste is collected by the city in rollout containers; and 
(2)  Residentially occupied property whose solid waste is collected by the city in bulk containers; and 
(3)  Residentially and nonresidentially occupied property whose solid waste is collected by the city in bulk containers. 
(c)  A separate unit charge shall apply for each family or household occupancy of any structure served by a rollout or bulk container. A separate unit charge shall apply for each bulk container serving nonresidential property depending on the size of the container and frequency of collection. In the case of multiple customers sharing in the use of a common bulk container(s) having been previously agreed to by a majority of the affected customers, all customers will be required to participate on prorated basis according to the relative percentage of refuse deposited or as otherwise agreed to in writing and furnished to the superintendent of the environmental services division. 
    In the case of nonresidential occupancies served by a rollout container(s), a separate until charge shall apply for each container. 
(d)  In the case of multiple housing facilities containing more than four (4) dwelling units, the owner thereof shall pay annually to the city, not later than January 1, a fee that is equivalent to ten (10) percent of the dwelling units contained in the multiple housing facility multiplied by the annualized rate established by the city council as noted in subsection 18-12(a). In the event such fee is not paid, the owner thereafter shall pay fees in accordance with the nonresidential fee established for bulk containers. 
(e)  The fees and charges provided for in subsections (a) and (b) above shall be billed monthly and shall be payable with the city electrical, gas, water or sewer service billing, according to established billing procedures in effect at the time. Such charges, if unpaid, shall be a lien upon the property involved and may be collected as provided in G.S. § 105-385. 
(f)  If such charges shall not be paid as provided in paragraph (c) of this section, the city may discontinue further collection and removal of such garbage and refuse from the property involved. Further placement of garbage and refuse on such property shall be unlawful and shall subject the resident of the dwelling unit and for the owner of the property to all applicable health and sanitation regulations and laws. 
(Code 1967, § 9-20; Ord. No. 0-88-81, § 1, 9-26-88; Ord. No. 0-91-40, § 1, 6-24-91; Ord. No. 0-92-74, § 1b, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 18-13. - Hazardous solid waste. 
    Hazardous solid waste shall be handled, stored, collected, transported and disposed of as provided for in the Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, as amended. 
Sec. 18-14. - Restriction on contents of containers. 
    No person shall place any of the following items in a solid waste container for collection by public works department personnel: 
(1)  Dangerous items. Window glass, fluorescent tubes, sharp metal objects or other similar items which could cause injury to collection personnel. 
(2)  Hazardous and medical wastes. The generators of all such waste as defined by applicable federal and state laws are responsible for the storage, collection, transport and disposal in accordance with the latest regulations. 
(3)  Combustible material. Burning or smouldering material or any other items which would create a fire hazard to personnel or equipment. 
(4)  Destructive items. Rocks, bricks, concrete pieces, dirt and similar material that may be destructive to waste compaction equipment. 
(5)  Motor vehicle tires. Truck, tractor, farm implement, or more than four (4) passenger car tires shall not be placed in bulk containers. 
Sec. 18-15. - Medical solid waste. 
    Medical solid waste shall be incinerated or steam sterilized prior to collection. Sharp instruments such as hypodermic syringes and needles and similar items shall be incinerated or mutilated and sealed in impervious packages prior to collection in accordance with G.S. § 130A-294 or applicable federal laws regarding the storage, collection, transport and disposal of all such waste. 
Sec. 18-16. - Access to containers. 
    Routes for access to and egress from solid waste containers shall be improved and maintained to standards prescribed by the director of public works for the safety of solid waste collection personnel and equipment, and shall have at all points adequate clearance. Routes shall not be obstructed by locked gates, steps or vehicles, and service will not be provided when dogs or other animals threaten or interfere with collection personnel. 
Sec. 18-17. - Damage to containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully cut, slash or upset any container, bag, box or package containing solid waste or to strew the contents thereof. 
Sec. 18-18. - Collection schedule. 
    Except in case of emergencies, holidays or circumstances over which the city and the public works department have no control, the public works department shall collect and remove solid wastes without fee except as otherwise provided, according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Residential and garbage solid waste: All such waste shall be collected two (2) times each week. 
(2)  Yard and bulky solid waste : All such waste shall be collected one (1) time each week. 
(3)  Commercial solid waste : All such waste shall be collected two (2) times each week. 
(4)  Central business district : Solid waste within the boundaries of this district shall be collected daily except Saturday and Sunday. 
Sec. 18-19. - Ownership of solid wastes. 
    Upon collection of solid waste by the city, all such solid waste shall become the property of the city. 
Sec. 18-20. - Disposal facility. 
    The public works department shall operate a solid waste disposal facility to be known as a solid waste transfer station for the receipt and safe, sanitary disposition of all waste generated from within the corporate limits of the city except hazardous waste, building construction/renovation waste, land clearing and landscaping waste, tree trimming waste, roofing waste, automotive tires and industrial wastes. Wastes hauled by private solid waste collection contractors for any nonresidential land use shall be transported directly to the county landfill and shall not be accepted at the solid waste transfer station. Wastes from any source outside the corporate limits of the city shall not be accepted at the solid waste transfer station. 
(Code 1967, § 9-26; Ord. No. 0-89-53, § 2,6-26-89) 
Sec. 18-21. - Solid waste disposal facility operations. 
    The director of public works shall operate a solid waste receiving or transfer site for the receiving and the safe and sanitary disposition of all solid wastes from within the city except hazardous waste, construction and demolition waste, land clearing and landscaping waste, and industrial waste that will, in the opinion of the director of public works, be unduly detrimental to the receiving or transfer site. The disposal site shall be open at the times prescribed by the director of public works for the receipt of solid wastes. Wastes from outside the corporate limits of the city shall not be accepted at the receiving or transfer site. 
Sec. 18-22. - Regulations. 
    The director of public works may make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary regulations not inconsistent with city ordinances governing the storage, collection, transport, receiving and transfer and disposal of solid waste. 
Sec. 18-23. - Prohibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container which is not the property of that person without the consent of the owner of such container; 
(2)  Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection personnel or solid waste collection and transport equipment; 
(3)  Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the director of public works; 
(4)  Permit any dirt, rocks, sand, brick, broken concrete, lumber, tree trunks, limbs or trimmings, cinders, plaster, gravel, paper, cardboard or any similar material to fail, be scattered or blown upon any street from any vehicle transporting such material or fail to remove such material immediately from the street; 
(5)  Place, discard, dispose or leave any solid waste upon a street or highway within the city or upon any property owned or operated by the city unless such solid waste is placed in a designated location or in a solid waste container. 
Chapter 19 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND CERTAIN OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Consumption and possession of malt beverages and unfortified wine. 
(a)  Definitions. In addition to the common meanings of words, the following definitions shall be applicable herein: 
(1)  Malt beverages shall mean beer, lager, malt liquor, ale, porter, and any other brewed or fermented beverage containing at least one-half of one (0.5) percent, and not more than six (6) percent alcohol by volume. 
(2)  Open container shall mean a container on which the seal has been broken or container other than the manufacturer's unopened original container. 
(3)  Public street shall mean any highway, road, street, avenue, boulevard, alley, bridge, or other way within and/or under the control of the city and open to public use, including the sidewalks of any such street. 
(4)  Unfortified wine shall mean wine that has an alcoholic content produced only by natural fermentation or by the addition of pure cane, beet, or dextrose sugar, and that has an alcoholic content of not more than seventeen (17) percent alcohol by volume. 
(b)  Consumption on the public streets and on municipal property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor vehicle to consume malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on the public streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person to consume malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on any property, whether located inside or outside the corporate limits, owned, occupied, or controlled by the city including, but not limited to, public buildings and the grounds appurtenant thereto, municipal parking lots, public parks, playgrounds, recreational areas, tennis courts, and other athletic fields. 
(c)  Possession of open containers on the public streets and on municipal property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor vehicle to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified wine on the public streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified wine on any property, whether located inside or outside the corporate limits, owned, occupied, or controlled by the city including, but not limited to, public buildings and the grounds appurtenant thereto, municipal parking lots, public parks, playgrounds, recreational areas, tennis courts, and other athletic fields. 
(d)  Possession during special events prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on public streets, alleys, or parking lots which are temporarily closed to regular traffic for special events. 
(e)  Exemptions: With the permission of the city manager or his/her designee in accordance with chapter 19 of the City Code, possession and consumption of malt beverages and/or unfortified wine shall be permitted within a building or premises on city owned property where appropriate permits have been obtained as required by law for the possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages for the period of time permitted thereunder. 
(f)  Penalty. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with G.S. § 14-4. 
(Code 1967, § 12-2; Ord. No. 0-95-21, § 1, 5-8-95 Ord. No. 0-95-62, § 1, 11-13-95; Ord. No. O-2012-104, § 1, 11-26-12) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate consumption of alcohol on public property, G.S. § 18B-300(c). 
Sec. 19-2. - Marking of streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or attempt to advertise by marking or painting on any of the streets or sidewalks within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-2) 
Sec. 19-3. - Lights, barricades around obstructions and excavations. 
    Any person who puts any obstruction on any street or sidewalk or who cuts any excavation on any street or sidewalk without properly protecting the same with lights and otherwise in accordance with section 19-37 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day's continuance without such protection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 17-6) 
Sec. 19-4. - Tampering with danger lights, barricades. 
    No person shall interfere with any lantern or other guard placed around any obstacle or excavation to protect same. 
(Code 1967, § 17-7) 
Sec. 19-5. - Depositing, storing material on streets, sidewalks. 
    No person shall deposit any rubbish, building material, etc., on the streets and sidewalks so as to be dangerous to vehicle or pedestrian traffic. Storage of building materials on city property may be permitted during construction, but only after the necessary permit for construction has been obtained and the storage area approved by the director of public works or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1967, § 17-11) 
Sec. 19-6. - Plants, fences, etc., within right-of-way. 
    No person shall plant or cause to be planted any tree, shrubbery, hedge or similar planting within the right-of-way of any street or sidewalk within the city limits, nor place or erect, or cause to be placed or erected, any fence, wall, edifice or other construction within the same. This section shall not apply to any street or sidewalk not accepted and maintained by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 17-13) 
Sec. 19-7. - Erection of poles, fixtures, etc., within right-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect or place any pole, stake (including without limitation stakes and poles designed to keep vehicles off grass), fixture, right-of-way structure, or any other structure, or any underground facility within the right-of-way of any street or sidewalk within the city limits except as provided in this article. Fences, lamp post, mailboxes, and similar structures made of wood, plastic, or lightweight metal and of a size, design, or type that will collapse upon impact with a motor vehicle, and trees, plants, and shrubs, provided they do not obstruct the view of intersections or the line of sight in horizontal curves, are permitted within the right-of-way of local residential streets without a license. Certain other existing heavy and permanent structures may be licensed for right-of-way use as provided in this Article. 
(Code 1967, § 17-14; Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 1, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-8. - Roller skates, skateboards within fire district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use roller skates and skateboards upon the sidewalks or streets within the fire district of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 17-18) 
Cross reference- Fire limits, § 5-1; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 19-9. - Use of skates, coasters, etc., in roadway. 
    No person upon roller skates or a skateboard or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street at a crosswalk or intersection, and except upon streets set aside as play streets. 
(Code 1967, § 19-16) 
Sec. 19-10. - Discharge of oily substances. 
(a)  No person shall pour or spill, or permit to drip upon the asphalt pavement of any street, alley or public place in the city any kerosene, gasoline, benzine or other similar oil or oily substance or liquid. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to pour, drain or permit to be poured or drained any oil or other petroleum products into any street, open ditch, sewer or on the sidewalks within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 17-17) 
Sec. 19-11. - Construction and repair specifications. 
    All paving, construction, reconstruction and repair of streets, alleys, curbs and gutters, sidewalks and driveways in the city shall be in accordance with the Manual of Specification, Standards and Design (latest edition) approved by the city council and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, §§ 17-1, 17-5) 
Sec. 19-12. - [Use of roller skates, roller blades, skateboards or bicycles in certain areas.] 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use roller skates, roller blades, skateboards or bicycles upon the walkways around City Lake. 
(Ord. No. 0-92-83, § 1, 11-23-92) 
Sec. 19-13. - Right-of-way structures-Definitions. 
    Existing right-of-way structure means a right-of-way structure constructed, erected, or placed within the right-of-way of a local residential street prior to September 10, 2002. 
    Local residential street means a vehicular travel way constructed within a public right-of-way that has been recorded as such in the office of the register of deeds and is under the authority and control of the city. A residential street is designed and constructed to carry vehicular traffic volumes at low travel speeds and is not designated on the street mapping system as a collector or thoroughfare street. 
    Right-of-way license means a revocable license issued by the city granting the holder thereof the right to use a portion of the right-of-way of a local residential street for the purpose of having and maintaining an existing right-of-way structure. The license shall include, in addition to other provisions, insurance requirements, maintenance requirements, and a release and indemnity provision protecting the city. 
    Right-of-way structure means any mailbox support, fence, wall, endwall, entrance way, or similar structure located within the right-of-way of a local residential street that is constructed of wood, brick, stone, concrete, masonry, steel, or any other similar hard, heavy, and permanent material. Any mailbox, lamp post, fence, or similar structure made of wood, plastic, or lightweight metal, eight (8) inches or less in diameter, of a size, design, or type designed and constructed to collapse, breakaway, or go over upon impact with a motor vehicle, is not a right-of-way structure. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-14. - License required for right-of-way structure. 
    No person shall construct, erect, place, keep, or maintain any existing right-of-way structure within the right-of-way of any city street without first obtaining a license from the city. Right-of-way licenses shall be revocable upon thirty (30) days written notice if the city, in its sole discretion, determines that the use of the street right-of-way for such structure is in any way disruptive or unsafe to persons using the street or right-of-way, or if the city determines, in its sole discretion, that it needs to use the right-of-way for a purpose inconsistent with such structure, or if the licensee is in violation of any of the terms, conditions, or requirements of the license. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-15. - License requirements for right-of-way structures. 
    Any existing right-of-way structure may be licensed if the owner of the real estate adjacent to the local residential street right-of-way applies to the city for a license on or before December 31, 2002. A right-of-way license shall be issued to any owner of an existing right-of-way structure that meets the requirements of this Article. The owner shall release and indemnify the city against any and all liability caused by or resulting from the use of the right-of-way for such structure. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-16. - Regulations for right-of-way structures. 
    Any existing right-of-way structure constructed, erected, or maintained within the street right-of-way of a local residential street shall be marked with reflectors on all sides which are visible from the street. The size, type, and location of the reflectors for each structure shall be determined by the director of public works or his or her designee based on the size and location of such structure. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-17. - Transfer of right-of-way structure license. 
    Any person who purchases residential real estate which has a licensed, existing structure in the right-of-way adjacent to such property may apply to the city for a transfer of such license within thirty (30) days of the date of purchase. A right-of-way license shall be issued to the new owner if all the requirements of this article are met. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Sec. 19-18. - Removal of unlicensed right-of-way structures and poles, fixtures, etc. 
    Any existing right-of-way structure which has not been licensed on or before December 31, 2002, shall be removed from the right-of-way. In addition, any pole, stake, fixture, right-of-way structure, or other structure placed in the right-of-way in violation of this article shall be removed. 
(Ord. No. 0-02-83, § 2, 9-23-02) 
Secs. 19-19-19-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Local improvements, § 380 et seq.; planning and zoning, § 300 et seq.; authority to grant franchises for use, § 10(q); to maintain, repair, and regulate streets and sidewalks, § 10(g); ultimate street improvements, § 510 et seq. 
Cross reference- Truck routes established, § 20-181. 
State Law reference- Streets, G.S. § 160A-296. 

Sec. 19-36. - Construction or repair permit. 
(a)  No street, alley or curb and gutter shall be repaired nor any excavations made therein until a permit to do so has been obtained from the director of public works or his authorized representative. The director of public works or his authorized representative may for good and sufficient cause refuse to grant the permit, but the applicant therefor shall have the right to appeal from such refusal to the city manager. 
(b)  No street, alley or curb and gutter shall be constructed until a permit to do so has been obtained from the director of engineering or his authorized representative. The director of engineering or his authorized representative may for good and sufficient cause refuse to grant the permit, but the applicant therefor shall have the right to appeal from such refusal to the city manager. 
(c)  Permits issued pursuant to this section shall specify, as a minimum, the location and character of the proposed work, the address of the person to whom the same is granted, the name and address of the person by whom the work is to be done, when the work will be done and when it will be completed; the permit shall also specify when the same shall become void and shall require that written notice be given to the director of public works or engineering (as appropriate), or his authorized representative, when the work is actually begun and when it is completed. The permit shall be subject to revocation by the director of public works or engineering (as appropriate), or his authorized representative, for cause, and it shall be his duty to immediately revoke the same if the work or any part thereof is not done in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the city council and on file in the office of the city clerk. The permit shall become void if the work authorized therein is not completed within the time therein specified. 
(Code 1967, § 17-2) 
Sec. 19-37. - Protection of dangerous conditions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pave, repair or do any excavation or other work on any street or alley in the city which may create or cause a dangerous condition in, on or near any street, sidewalk, alley or driveway without placing and maintaining proper guardrails and signal lights or other warnings at, in or around the same, sufficient to warn the public of such work or excavation and to protect all persons using reasonable care from injuries on account of same. The guardrails and signal lights or other warnings shall be in accordance with specifications approved by the city council and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 17-3) 
Sec. 19-38. - Use of vehicles that damage or injure surface. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, push, pull or otherwise propel or cause to be driven, pushed or pulled or propelled over or along any street or other public way in the city any steam or gasoline tractor, motor car or other vehicle, wagon or equipment whatsoever, so as to cut, scrape, indent or otherwise deface or injure the paved surface of such street or other public way, or so as to crack, break or otherwise damage or injure the base or subbase of such paving. 
(Code 1967, § 17-8) 
Sec. 19-39. - Burning substances on paved surface. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or cause to be burned upon the paved surface of any such street or other public way in the city any oil, gasoline or other combustible substance or material whatsoever. 
(Code 1967, § 17-9) 
Sec. 19-40. - Deleterious matter on paved surface. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mix and place or cause to be mixed or placed upon the paved surface of any street or other public way in the city, so as to come in contact therewith, any lime, concrete mixture or other like deleterious substance or material. 
(Code 1967, § 17-10) 
Sec. 19-41. - Service stations; location of gas lines, oil pumps, etc. 
    No filling or service station shall maintain any gasoline line or oil pump or underground gasoline or oil pumps or any device or equipment whatsoever for serving, oiling or servicing automobiles any closer than allowed by the zoning ordinance of the city, but in no case within twelve (12) feet of any right-of-way line of any public street or alley. 
(Code 1967, § 17-20) 
Sec. 19-42. - Site clearance at intersections. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the term "street gutter flow line" shall mean the street gutter flow line of the curb adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted area; if there is no such curb, the height restriction set forth in this section shall be based upon the actual level of the paved or used portion of the public street or alley adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted area. 
(b)  In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this section, the city shall have the right to enter upon and remove from the triangular corner areas described in this section any of the growths prohibited by this section. Such entry and removal shall be without liability to the owners thereof. 
(c)  The areas in the city restricted by the provisions of this section are as follows: 
(1)  All of that portion of land lying within a triangular-shaped area on each street corner within the city and described by metes and bounds as follows: beginning at the precise corner of intersection point of the curbs of each of the two (2) streets forming each corner and extending twenty (20) feet along each such curbline from the curb intersection point, the third side being determined by the drawing of a straight line from the ends of such twenty-foot extensions. The foregoing areas shall be restricted regardless of whether the land is privately owned or unpaved or untraveled street right-of-way property. 
(2)  Where no curbs are in existence at such street intersections, the twenty-foot lines shall coincide with the central flow line of the ditches paralleling such uncurbed streets as shall be determined by the director of public works or his authorized representative. The provisions of this section shall apply only to those areas of the city in which the city's zoning ordinance requires construction on lots to be set back from the property line on each such lot. 
(d)  No person shall plant, grow or maintain in any restricted area any plant, hedge or shrub or other growth, except trees, at a height greater than two (2) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
(e)  Any trees planted, grown and maintained in any restricted area shall not have branches or foliage extending from the trunk thereof at a height lower than ten (10) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
(Code 1967, §§ 17-33-17-37) 
Secs. 19-43-19-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 19-61. - Construction or repair permit. 
    No person shall construct or maintain any driveway across any sidewalk or curbing or enter any public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of engineering or his authorized representative, which permit shall be in addition to any other permit which may be required. The application shall be in writing and shall show the improvements proposed to be made thereon and the type of construction, the length of the driveways, and such other information as the director of engineering or his authorized representative shall require. If upon investigation the director of engineering finds that the construction and maintenance of such driveway or driveways will not substantially impair or interfere with the safety or the use of the street or sidewalk by the public or interfere with the drainage or protection of the sidewalk and street and that same will otherwise comply with the applicable provisions of this Code and ordinances of the city, he shall issue a permit for the construction of such a driveway. 
(Code 1967, § 17-4) 
Sec. 19-62. - Display of goods. 
(a)  No person other than a person owning or occupying any lot or premises in the city, and conducting a business at such location, shall have the right to display goods, wares, merchandise, signs or any other objects on the space on the sidewalk in front of his store or other place of business; provided, however, that no such display shall unreasonably restrict the use or access of such sidewalk areas by pedestrians, the city or any other person. 
(b)  If at any time it is determined by the chief of police that goods, wares, merchandise, signs or other objects are being displayed in a manner that unreasonably restricts the use or access of the sidewalks, he shall notify the person responsible for such display in writing. Upon receipt of such notice the person responsible shall remove or cause to be removed any objects obstructing the use or access of the sidewalk area. 
(Code 1967, § 17-12) 
Sec. 19-63. - Discharge of water. 
    Any person allowing a gutter, drain or downspout to discharge any water on a public sidewalk within the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day's continuance thereof shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not apply in cases where the director of public works or his authorized representative has approved a method of discharging such water under or over the sidewalk and such drain is so constructed as to carry water away without spreading over the sidewalk and without constituting a menace to pedestrians. 
(Code 1967, § 17-16) 
Sec. 19-64. - Snow removal. 
    Each occupant of a business which fronts on a paved sidewalk or a portion of a paved sidewalk shall clear off any snow which may accumulate on the paved sidewalk in front of his business within twelve (12) hours from the time it accumulates. The failure so to do shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 17-21) 
Sec. 19-65. - Riding bicycle on sidewalks, walkways. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk or walkway within a business district in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 19-14) 
Secs. 19-66-19-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES AND DEMONSTRATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Parade floats to contain flame-proof materials, § 8-2; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20. 

Sec. 19-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block means that portion of any street lying between its intersections with other streets. 
    Demonstration means any assembly together or concert of action between more than four (4) persons for the purpose of protesting any matter, making known any position, or promoting certain persons or organizations, or attracting attention to such assembly. 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public places, involving more than four (4) persons or more than three (3) vehicles. 
(Code 1967, § 12-42) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-82. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to or from school classes or participating in educational or recreational activity where such activity is under the supervision and direction of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  Any governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions; 
(4)  Picketing or other orderly processions on the sidewalks, involving fewer than ten (10) persons, and conducted entirely within one (1) block, that do not violate any other municipal or state law; 
(5)  A parade that is conducted under the sponsorship of the city. 
Sec. 19-83. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Violation of this article shall be a criminal misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, as provided in G.S. § 14-4. 
(b)  In addition to or in lieu of criminal remedies, violation of this article shall subject the offender to the levy of a civil penalty in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Civil penalties remaining unpaid after seven (7) days may be collected by means of a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(c)  This article may also be enforced by an appropriate equitable remedy issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction. 
Sec. 19-84. - Effect of state law. 
    The prohibition contained in G.S. § 14-277.2 against possession of dangerous weapons and other provisions of law shall be strictly enforced. 
Sec. 19-85. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to organize, conduct or participate in any parade or demonstration in or upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place within the city unless a permit has been issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43(a)) 
Sec. 19-86. - Same-Application. 
    A written application on a form supplied by the city shall be made to the chief of police by persons desiring to have a parade or demonstration. Such applications shall be submitted at least seventy-two (72) hours in advance. However, where good cause is shown or in the judgment of the chief the activity would involve significant political or religious features and therefore be entitled to enhanced deference or protection under the state and federal constitutions, the chief of police shall consider applications filed after the deadline. Employees of the police department shall immediately indicate the time of receipt on the face of the application. The application shall be signed by the applicant and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(2)  If the parade or demonstration is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible head of such organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person to be present and responsible for the conduct of the parade or demonstration; 
(4)  The date when the parade or demonstration will be conducted; 
(5)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or demonstration; 
(6)  The time when units of the parade or demonstration will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
(7)  The times when the parade or demonstration will begin and terminate; 
(8)  The route to be travelled, the starting point and the termination point, or the location if stationary; 
(9)  A statement as to whether the parade or demonstration will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets, sidewalks, parks, alleys or other public places proposed to be traversed or occupied; 
(10)  The approximate number of persons, animals and vehicles expected to participate, and the type of animals and a description of the vehicles; 
(11)  Whether minors are likely to participate. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43(c)) 
Sec. 19-87. - Same-Issuance. 
(a)  The application submitted under this article is expressly included as part of any permit granted. A permit shall be issued on a form supplied by the city to the person who signed the application. Such person shall be required to accompany the parade or demonstration, and the permit shall be invalid unless in his possession. The permit shall be deemed issued under the terms stated in the application unless otherwise provided. The permit shall set the duration, speed of travel and space between persons or vehicles in the parade or demonstration; may prescribe the portions or areas of streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places to be used; and may impose such other reasonable requirements necessary for the control and safe movement of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(b)  The chief of police shall issue a permit unless he makes written findings based upon specified facts that: 
(1)  The activity cannot be conducted without unreasonable interference with normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic in the area; or 
(2)  The activity cannot be held without unreasonably interfering with the provision of normal police and fire protection to the public; or 
(3)  The event will require the closing of or unreasonably restrict the flow of vehicular traffic along a highway under the control of the state, in which case the permit shall not be issued until permission has been secured from the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43(d)) 
Sec. 19-88. - Same-Processing time; notice; right of appeal. 
    Applications for permits under this article shall be processed and decisions made as expeditiously as possible, and at least within forty-eight (48) hours. If the application was submitted more than seven (7) days in advance of the event, the permit, alternate permit or written notice of denial shall be mailed to the applicant. Otherwise, the police department shall exercise reasonable diligence in attempting to notify the applicant of the action taken as soon as possible by telephone or other means. Any person aggrieved by action taken on a permit application may file a written notice of appeal, first with the city manager and then with the city council. The city manager shall act on the appeal as expeditiously as possible. The city council shall hear an appeal as expeditiously as possible and in any event within seventy-two (72) hours after written notice of an appeal from the city manager's decision has been filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43(f)) 
Sec. 19-89. - Same-Revocation. 
    The chief of police may revoke any permit granted for a parade or demonstration for the following causes: 
(1)  The substantial violation of this article or the terms and conditions or a permit; or 
(2)  A material misstatement of any fact on the application. 
(Code 1967, § 12-45) 
Sec. 19-90. - Unlawful participation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or participate in any parade or demonstration for any purpose or in any manner other than those set out in the application and permit. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43(a)) 
Sec. 19-91. - Alternate permits. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application as submitted under this article, may grant a permit for a date, time, place or over a route different from that named by the applicant, or subject to stated requirements and conditions. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police, on a form supplied by the city. 
Sec. 19-92. - Interference, obstruction. 
    No person shall hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or demonstration being conducted under authority of a lawfully issued permit. No driver of any vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade or demonstration when such vehicles or persons are in motion and identifiable as a parade or demonstration under this article. 
Sec. 19-93. - Sidewalk obstructions. 
    Police officers observing unreasonable obstructions of sidewalks as a result of a parade or demonstration, such that pedestrians are unreasonably hindered or forced to step into the street, shall take reasonable steps to make the sidewalk available for pedestrian travel. 
Sec. 19-94. - Parking restrictions. 
    The chief of police, when reasonably necessary, may prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street or highway constituting a part of the route of a parade or demonstration. The chief of police shall cause signs to be posted to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street if such signs are posted less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance. 
ARTICLE V. - TREES 

Sec. 19-94.1. - Purpose. 
    In order to protect and conserve plantings on rights-of-way and public property, this article provides for the pruning, treatment and removal of trees, root systems, and shrubs as is deemed necessary by the city council or official acting under the authority of the city council. The article is also intended to provide for the trimming or removal of trees on public properties when they obscure street lights, interfere with overhead and underground utility lines or constitute a hazard to pedestrian or vehicular traffic or otherwise endanger public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-95. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this article, certain terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.] 
    Public property means all real property that is owned or leased by the City of Rocky Mount or which is maintained by it, or any part of any rights-of-way as defined hereinafter. 
    Rights-of-way means property located within and adjoining the streets, roads and highways within the city, which rights-of-way are owned by the city or the state or are otherwise maintained by the city or the state. Questions of rights-of-way locations are determined by the city engineer. 
    Street trees means trees and shrubs within the rights-of-way of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public properties. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-96. - Tree advisory board. 
    The city council has established a tree advisory board to make recommendations to the city manager relative to trees and shrubbery on city property to the city manager and perform other duties as designated in this article. 
    The tree advisory board is comprised of eleven (11) members. Seven (7) of the members shall be appointed by the city council and four (4) shall be city staff members as follows: 
    The director of utilities or designee; the director of parks and recreation or designee; the director of development services or designee; and the director of public works or designee. The city manager may designate other employees to serve as staff to the board as needed. 
    Appointed members shall serve four-year terms with each member of the city council appointing one (1) member. 
    Any member who fails to attend at least seventy-five (75) percent of the regular and special meetings held by the board during any one-year period shall be removed from the board by the city council. Vacancies resulting from a member's failure to attend the required number of meetings shall be filled as provided herein. The chairman of the board will notify the proper appointing authority if a member is absent twenty-five (25) percent of the meetings, and appointment will be made by the appointing authority to fill that vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97; Ord. No. O-2010-68, § 1, 7-12-10; Ord. No. O-2018-79, § 2, 8-13-18) 
Sec. 19-97. - Operation. 
    The tree advisory board shall choose its officers, adopt rules for transaction of business, and keep a record of its members' attendance and of its resolutions, discussions, findings, and recommendations, which shall be public record. The board shall set a regular meeting schedule, and the chairman may call a special meeting upon request by a majority of board members. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-98. - Compensation. 
    Members of the tree advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-99. - Duties. 
    In coordination with city staff, the tree advisory board shall: 
(1)  Study, investigate, counsel and develop, and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs along streets, rights-of-way and on other public properties. 
(2)  Conduct tree surveys of existing trees along streets and on city property within the city. 
(3)  Foster communication among the citizens of Rocky Mount that will provide needed protection of trees and coordinate active measures to support their health and growth within the city. 
(4)  Investigate available grants, loans or contributions from other governmental agencies, public or private corporations, agencies, or individuals, and recommend the expenditure of any proceeds toward the accomplishment of the board's purpose. 
(5)  Locate and identify historic trees through the assistance of appropriate civic groups and, with the consent of any owners, may designate such trees by marker or device. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-100. - Applicability. 
    The terms and provisions of this article shall apply to all public property as defined herein. The terms and provisions of this article shall be consistent with any requirements imposed by state law or by the North Carolina Department of Transportation in connection with any state-owned or maintained rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-101. - Planting standards. 
    The tree advisory board shall be responsible for developing an official street tree species list comprised of three groups of trees: small trees, medium trees, and large trees. No trees other than those included in the list may be planted as street trees without permission of the board. 
    The tree advisory board shall also be responsible for establishing standards, as approved by the city manager, for the spacing of city trees in accordance with the species size classes in the official street tree species list. These standards will cover spacing between street trees, the distance street trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks, the distance street trees may be planted to overhead and underground electric lines, gas lines, water lines, sewer lines, or other utilities, and any other areas involving the spacing of street trees, park trees, or city owned trees. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-102. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants, and shrubs within the rights-of-way of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and other public properties, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public properties. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall remove, mutilate or kill a tree growing on public property or in the public rights-of-way without first obtaining the approval of the city manager. 
    The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any publicly owned tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electrical power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is infected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other pest. 
    This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners provided the selection and location of said tree(s) are in accordance with the guidelines for planting, spacing and maintenance developed by the tree advisory board. The city reserves the right to approve any plantings which take place in public rights-of-way areas maintained by the City of Rocky Mount. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-103. - Pruning guidelines. 
    It shall be unlawful, except as described below, for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such degree as to remove the normal canopy and to disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees which interfere with or are an eminent threat to utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempt from this article. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-104. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street trees shall be removed in a timely fashion not to exceed ninety (90) days from removal of trees and to a depth so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surrounding surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-105. - Historic trees. 
    In order to protect significant trees within the City of Rocky Mount, the city council hereby establishes the historic tree designation. A historic tree may be designated by resolution of city council at the request of the tree advisory board. The property owner shall consent to the designation, in writing, before the historic tree is designated. Historic trees may be located on public or private property. A historic tree may lose its designation upon the written consent of the property owner to the board with approval by the city council. 
    No historic tree shall be trimmed, cut or removed without prior written notice. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97) 
Sec. 19-106. - Criteria; historic trees. 
    A tree shall meet one (1) of the following criteria in order to be designated as a historic tree. 
(1)  It has reached its mature growth. 
(2)  It is listed as a Champion Big Tree, as designated by the State Division of Forest Resources. 
(3)  It has significant historic value to the community. 
(4)  It is a rare species, or provides a habitat for rare species of plants, animals or birds. 
(Ord. No. 0-97-75, 12-15-97)
