Enforcement of pretreatment violations will generally be in accordance with the city's enforcement response plan. However, the director of water resources may take other action against any user when the circumstances warrant. Further, the director of water resources is empowered to take more than one (1) enforcement action against any noncompliant user. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-71, § 1(Exh. A), 6-24-13) 
Sec. 21-41. - Affirmative defenses to discharge violations. 
Sec. 21-41.1. - Upset. 
(a)  An upset shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements of subsection (b) are met. 
(b)  A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or other relevant evidence that: 
(1)  An upset occurred and the user can identify the cause(s) of the upset; 
(2)  The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance procedures; and 
(3)  The user has submitted the following information to the director of water resources within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the upset (if this information is provided orally, a written submission must be provided within five (5) days): 
a.  A description of the indirect discharge and cause of noncompliance; 
b.  The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to continue; and 
c.  Steps being taken and/or planned to be taken to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of the noncompliance. 
(c)  In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof. 
(d)  Users will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards. 
(e)  Users shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility fails, or is reduced or lost. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-71, § 1(Exh. A), 6-24-13) 
Sec. 21-41.2. - Prohibited discharge standards defense. 
    A user shall have an affirmative defense to an enforcement action brought against it for noncompliance with the general prohibitions in subsection 21-30.1(a) or the specific prohibitions in subsections 21-30.1(b)(2), (3), (5)-(7) and (9)-(21) if it can prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, whether alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass through or interference and that either: 
(1)  A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged and the user was in compliance with each limit directly prior to and during the pass through or interference; or 
(2)  No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when city was regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit, and in the case of interference, was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal requirements. 
(3)  An upset means an exceptional incident in which there is an unintentional and temporary noncompliance with the limits contained in this ordinance or with permittee permit limits because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the permittee. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed or inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventative maintenance, or careless or improper operations. 
    An upset may constitute an affirmative defense for action brought for the noncompliance. The permittee has the burden of proof to provide evidence and demonstrate that none of the factors specifically listed above were responsible for the noncompliance. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-71, § 1(Exh. A), 6-24-13) 
Sec. 21-41.3. - Bypass. 
(a)  A user may allow any bypass to occur that does not cause pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it also is for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are not subject to the provision of subsections (b) and (c). 
(b)  Notice. 
(1)  If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall submit prior notice to the director of water resources, at least ten (10) days before the date of the bypass, if possible. 
(2)  A user shall submit oral notice to the director of water resources of an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within twenty-four (24) hours from the time it becomes aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also be provided within five (5) days of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The written submission shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The director of water resources may waive the written report on a case-by-case basis if the oral report has been received within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(c)  Prohibition of bypass. 
(1)  Bypass is prohibited, and the director of water resources may take an enforcement action against a user for a bypass, unless 
a.  Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage; 
b.  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not satisfied if adequate back-up equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass that occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventative maintenance; and 
c.  The user submitted notices as required under subsection (b). 
(2)  The director of water resources may approve an anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the director of water resources determines that it will meet the three (3) conditions listed in subsection (c)(1). 
(Ord. No. O-2013-71, § 1(Exh. A), 6-24-13) 
ARTICLE III. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY 

Sec. 21-42. - Purpose. 
    This article establishes a stormwater management utility as an identified fiscal and accounting fund for the purpose of addressing and funding the overall stormwater management needs of the city from a comprehensive approach to meet applicable state and federal stormwater regulations and shall include (a) stormwater management programs designed to protect water quality by controlling the level of pollutants in, and flow of, stormwater and (b) structural and natural stormwater and drainage systems of all types. 
(Ord. No. 0-01-83, § 1, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 21-43. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings given to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Credits shall mean on-going reductions in the stormwater service charge applicable to a given property in recognition of on-site or off-site systems, facilities, measures, or other actions taken by customers to reduce or mitigate the impact of their properties or actions on the quantity or quality of stormwater run off that would otherwise be managed in the public system. Credits shall be conditioned on the continuing performance of the systems, facilities, measures, or other actions in reference to standards adopted by the city council upon which the credits are granted, and may be revised or rescinded. In no case shall credits exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the amount of the annual stormwater service charge. 
    Detached single-family/duplex residential shall mean developed land containing one (1) structure which is not attached to another dwelling unit and which contains one (1) or more rooms with a bathroom and kitchen facilities designed for occupancy by one (1) family and shall include single family houses, individual duplex units designed for occupancy by one (1) family in each unit, and manufactured homes and mobile homes located on individual lots or parcels of land. Developed land may be classified as "detached single-family/duplex residential" despite the presence of incidental structures associated with residential uses such as garages, carports or small storage buildings. "Detached single-family/duplex residential" shall not include developed land containing: structures used primarily for non-residential purposes; manufactured homes and mobile homes located within manufactured home or mobile home parks; or other multiple unit properties. 
    Developed land shall mean property altered from a natural state that contains impervious or partially impervious cover, including buildings, pavement, gravel roads, recreation areas (e.g. tennis courts), etc. 
    Equivalent residential unit (ERU) shall mean two thousand, five hundred nineteen (2,519) square feet of impervious surface or any fraction thereof. Two thousand, five hundred nineteen (2,519) square feet is the statistical average for impervious area on a single-family lot in the City of Rocky Mount. 
    Impervious surface shall mean any built upon area that impedes the infiltration of water into the soil. This includes but is not limited to developed land areas covered by concrete, asphalt, rooftops, stone and other building materials. 
    Other properties shall mean any developed land not fitting the definition of detached single-family/duplex residential. "Other properties" shall include, but not be limited to, attached single-family houses with greater than two (2) units, townhouses and condominiums, apartments, boarding houses, hotels and motels, churches, commercial properties which include dwelling units, manufactured home or mobile home parks, commercial and office buildings, storage areas, parking lots and other impervious areas, parks, recreational properties, public and private schools and colleges, hospitals, nursing homes, assisted care homes, convalescent centers, office buildings, airports, agricultural uses involving impervious surfaces, and water and wastewater treatment plants. Real properties which are used for other than single-family residential use located in single-family residential structures or duplexes shall be deemed other properties for the purpose of calculating the stormwater service charge. The definition of "other properties" shall be broadly construed such that any property having areas of impervious coverage shall be subject to the stormwater service charge unless otherwise provided. 
    Service charge shall mean the stormwater service charges applicable to a parcel of developed land, which is generally reflective of a parcel's impact on the cost of providing services and facilities to properly control stormwater runoff quantity and/or quality. 
    Stormwater shall mean the runoff from precipitation that travels over natural or developed surfaces to the nearest stream, other conduit, or impoundment and appears in lakes, rivers, ponds, or other bodies of water. 
    Stormwater drainage system or storm sewer system shall mean the system of natural and constructed channels, swales, ditches, swamps, rivers, streams, creeks, branches, reservoirs, ponds, drainage ways, inlets, catch basins, pipes, headwalls, storm sewers, lakes, or other physical works, properties, and improvements which transfer, control, convey or otherwise influence the movement of stormwater runoff. 
    Stormwater management programs shall mean programs designed to protect water quality by monitoring and controlling the level of pollutants in, and the flow of, stormwater and shall include mapping, planning, review, construction, operation, cleaning, maintenance, inspection, regulation and administration of other programs related to structural and natural stormwater systems. 
    Stormwater utility shall mean a management structure that is responsible solely and specifically for the stormwater management program and system and that is supported through a rate structure that is based on the amount of stormwater generated by individual properties. 
    Undeveloped land shall mean land that does not meet the definition of developed lands. 
(Ord. No. 0-01-83, § 1, 11-12-01; Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 1, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 21-44. - Establishment of a stormwater management utility and enterprise fund. 
(a)  There is hereby established a stormwater management utility for the city which shall be responsible for stormwater management programs and which shall provide for the design, management, construction, protection, control, regulation, use, and enhancement of stormwater and drainage systems. 
(b)  There is hereby established a stormwater management enterprise fund for the city for the purpose of dedicating, protecting and accounting for all funding applicable to and used for the purposes and responsibilities of the stormwater utility including but not limited to such rents, rates, fees, charges, and penalties as may be established, after notice and public hearing, by city council and shall include such additional funds as may be transferred or allocated to the stormwater management utility. All revenues and receipts of the stormwater management utility shall be placed in the stormwater enterprise fund. Additional funds not in the stormwater enterprise fund may be applied to stormwater management programs and stormwater drainage systems as authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 0-01-83, § 1, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 21-45. - Jurisdiction. 
    The boundaries and jurisdiction of the stormwater management utility shall extend to and include the corporate limits of the city, including noncontiguous portions of the city and shall include all areas hereinafter annexed into the city and such other areas outside the corporate limits as shall be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 0-01-83, § 1, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 21-46. - Impervious coverage and rate unit. 
(a)  Impervious coverage. The amount of impervious coverage of real property is a key factor in the peak rate of stormwater runoff and the pollutant loadings of stormwater runoff discharged into the structural and natural drainage systems and facilities. Therefore, the amount of impervious coverage shall be the primary parameter for establishing the rate structure to distribute the cost of systems and facilities through a schedule of rates, fees, charges, and penalties related to the use and operation of the stormwater utility and public enterprise as established in section 21-44. 
(b)  Establishment of the equivalent residential unit. The area of two thousand, five hundred nineteen (2,519) square feet of impervious surface shall be the basis of one equivalent residential unit. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 2, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 21-47. - Schedule of fees and charges. 
(a)  Fee schedule adopted. The schedule of fees and charges set out in this section is hereby adopted and shall apply to all properties within the city except as altered by credits or exemptions. 
(1)  Detached single-family/duplex residential. Each developed detached single-family/duplex residential property shall be billed and shall pay the fee for one (1) equivalent residential unit per dwelling unit. There shall be no charge for detached single-family residential property with fewer than two hundred (200) square feet of impervious surface. 
(2)  Other properties. All other developed properties having impervious coverage, including but not limited to multi-family residential properties, commercial properties, industrial properties, public and institutional properties, church properties, public and private school properties, and publicly owned properties, unless specifically exempted, shall be billed for one (1) equivalent residential unit for each two thousand, five hundred nineteen (2,519) square feet or fraction thereof of impervious coverage on the subject property. There will be no service charge for other properties with fewer than two hundred (200) square feet of impervious surface. 
(b)  Monthly charge per equivalent residential unit (ERU). The monthly service charge per equivalent residential unit shall be the service charge set forth in the City of Rocky Mount Administrative Policy Manual, Fees and Charges Schedules. The monthly service charge per equivalent residential unit shall be set by the city council and may be amended by from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 2, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 21-48. - Billing and collection. 
(a)  Method of billing. Billing and collection of the stormwater service charge and any other rents, rates, fees, charges, and penalties for stormwater management services and facilities shall be accomplished in the manner approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Delinquencies. A stormwater utility service charge billing or other billing for rents, rates, fees, charges, and penalties associated with the stormwater utility is delinquent if not paid in accordance with the customer service policy as set forth in the City of Rocky Mount Administrative Policy Manual. A delinquent billing shall accumulate additional late payment charges and penalties in accordance with the administrative policy, customer service policy and stormwater utility rate schedule. 
(c)  Appeal of disputed bills, adjustments. If any customer disputes the stormwater utility service charge or any other rents, rates, fees, charges, or penalties adopted pursuant to this article, that customer must appeal the billing within twenty-one (21) days of the date of the bill, stating the reasons for the appeal, and providing information pertinent to the calculation of the bill. An appeal of a disputed bill shall be filed with the public works director, who may direct that the appeal be reviewed and resolved by the stormwater utility staff. If the customer is not satisfied with the disposition of the appeal, the customer may further appeal the disputed charge to the city manager or his designee who shall make the final ruling on the validity of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 2, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 21-49. - Disposition of service charges and fees. 
    Stormwater management utility service charge and fee revenues shall be assigned and dedicated solely to the stormwater management enterprise fund in the city budget and accounting system, which shall be and remain separate from other funds, and shall be used only to fund stormwater management programs and structural and natural stormwater and drainage systems. The services charges and fees paid to and collected by virtue of the provisions of this article shall not be used for general or other governmental or proprietary purposes of the city, except to pay for costs incurred by the city in rendering services to the stormwater management utility. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 2, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 21-50. - Credits and exemptions. 
(a)  Credit for mitigation measures. Credits against stormwater management utility service charges are an appropriate means of adjusting service charges, fees, rates, rentals, fines, and penalties in certain cases. Crediting mechanisms may be established by the city council and, when established, a credit manual shall be issued that will set forth the appropriate process and documentation to obtain such credits. No exception, credit, offset, or other reduction in stormwater service charges shall be granted based on age, race, tax status, economic status, or religion of the customer, or other condition unrelated to the stormwater utility's cost of providing stormwater services and facilities. 
(b)  Exemptions. Except as provided in this section, no public or private property shall be exempt from stormwater service charges. The following exemptions shall be allowed: 
(1)  Improved public road rights-of-way, which have been accepted for maintenance by the North Carolina Department of Transportation and are available for use in common for vehicular transportation by the general public, shall be exempt from stormwater service charge. 
(2)  Improved public road rights-of-way, which have been accepted for maintenance by the city and are available for use in common for vehicular transportation by the general public, shall be exempt from the stormwater service charge. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-51, § 2, 6-9-03) 
Chapter 22 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    In all matters relating to the administration of this chapter whenever and wherever the following terms are used they shall be construed and defined as follows: 
    Certificate of convenience and necessity means a certification by the city council prior to the issuance of a permit to operate a taxicab that public convenience and necessity requires or will be served by the operation of such taxicab. 
    Driver's permit means a permit issued after examination authorizing a person to drive a taxicab or limousine operating under this chapter. 
    Limousine certificate means a permit or license issued to an individual who owns a motor vehicle to be used for hire in a passenger limousine service. Issuance of such license certifies that the owner has met all ordinance requirements for the operation of a limousine in the city. 
    Owner means any individual operating one (1) or more taxicabs or limousines. 
    Owner's permit means a license issued to an individual who owns a motor vehicle or taxicab to be used for hire and transporting passengers within the city. Issuance of such license constitutes a certificate of convenience and necessity. 
    Taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire means a passenger motor vehicle, other than motor buses operating along regular routes and upon regular schedules, which shall be used for the purpose of carrying or transporting any person or persons from one place to another for which service a charge or a fee is made. 
    Taximeter means a mechanical instrument or device attached to a taxicab by which the charge for the hire of a taxicab and its corresponding waiting time at a predetermined rate is mechanically calculated and registered for the distance traveled and the period of time awaited and upon which such charges shall be identified by means of figures clearly visible for the passenger's information. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-1), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 1, 6-22-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Licensing required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab on the streets, alleys or highways of the city until the city council shall establish that the public convenience and necessity will be served by the operation of such taxicab. An application for such consideration shall be filed with the chief of police and shall contain the following: Full name and address of the owners, the place of business from which it will be operated and such other information as the chief of police, the city manager or the city council may direct. 
(b)  The chief of police shall make investigations as to the fitness of the applicant to operate a taxicab. If the results of the investigations are favorable to the applicant, he shall submit the application to the city manager or his designee. The burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish the existence of convenience and necessity to be served by the taxicab. 
    In determining whether or not public convenience and necessity requires or will be promoted by the operation of such taxicab, the city council shall among other things take into consideration the following factors: 
(a)  Whether or not the public convenience and necessity requires such proposed or additional taxicab service within the city. 
(b)  The financial responsibility of the applicant and the likelihood of the proposed service being permanent, responsible and satisfactory. 
(c)  The number and condition of equipment. 
(d)  The schedule of proposed rates to be charged. 
(e)  The number of taxicabs now operated and the demand for increased service, if any, and whether or not the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved, and whether or not adequate provision has been made for off-street parking of said taxicabs. 
(f)  The experience of applicant in the taxicab business. 
(g)  Location and method of dispatch. 
(h)  Such other relative facts as may be deemed necessary and advisable. 
    If, after such investigations, the city council is of the opinion that the applicant is a suitable person to operate such taxicab and will use due diligence in safeguarding and protecting its passengers and the interest of the public will be promoted by permitting its operation, the application shall be approved and the chief of police shall issue to the applicant an owner's permit which constitutes a certificate of convenience and necessity. 
    The council shall have the power and it shall be its duty to order certain certificates issued, or to refuse to issue certain certificates, or to issue certificates for a partial exercise only of the privileges sought, and may attach to the exercise of the rights granted only by such certificates such terms and conditions as in their judgment the public convenience and necessity may require. 
    If the council is of the opinion either that the applicant is not a suitable person to engage in the business of operating taxicabs in the city or that the public convenience and necessity does not require and will not be promoted by the licensing of an additional taxicab, the application shall be denied and one (1) or more of the following factors shall be deemed sufficient grounds: 
(1)  Failure of the applicant (owner) to comply with all the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Unpaid or unbonded judgments of record against the applicant (owner). 
(3)  The applicant, from a standpoint of experience and financial responsibility, is not sufficiently qualified and able to render satisfactory taxicab service to the public as the public safety, convenience, and welfare requires. 
(4)  The criminal record of the applicant, if any, is such that it would be against the public interest and welfare for such application to be granted. In addition to felony convictions, misdemeanors of a serious nature may be considered. 
(5)  The applicant has made false or misleading statements in his application. 
(6)  Noncitizenship in the United States; 
(7)  Habitual violation of traffic laws or ordinances. 
(c)  The chief of police may refuse to issue an owner's permit to any person who has been convicted of a felony, or of a violation of any federal or state statute relating to the use, possession, or sale of intoxicating liquors, or of any federal or state statute relating to the use, possession or sale of habit-forming drugs; or to any person who is an habitual user of intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs. 
    The applicant shall be notified when the application will be considered by the council and given an opportunity to attend and be heard. 
(d)  If approved, the applicant shall be granted sixty (60) days from the date of approval to obtain a vehicle to be used in the exercise of the permit, certificates of insurance as required by section 22-9, and a permanent means of twenty-four-hour radio dispatch. Proof that the above requirements have been met shall be submitted to the chief of police or his designee within the sixty-day period. The applicant shall submit, for approval, information on the vehicle to be used. The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority to approve such vehicle after considering age, type, mechanical condition, appearance and general suitability of the vehicle to be used as a taxicab. 
    The applicant may appeal disapproval of a vehicle to the city council for review within thirty (30) days of such disapproval. Any such appeal shall be in writing and set forth the reasons for the appeal. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a limousine on the streets or highways of the city until he shall have obtained a certificate for its operation approved by the city council. An application shall be filed with the chief of police and shall contain the following: Full name and address of the owner(s), the place of business from which it will be operated, and documentation of the attainment of public liability and property damage insurance. If the chief of police determines that the applicant is a suitable person to operate such limousine and will use due diligence in safeguarding and protecting its passengers and the interest of the public will be promoted by permitting its operation, he shall recommend to the city council issuance of the limousine certificate. Factors listed in the foregoing portions of section 22-2 shall be considered in making this determination. 
(f)  The issuance of an owner's permit shall constitute a franchise from the city subject to the provisions of this chapter for one (1) year ending on December 31 of each year unless a shorter period of time is specified. Each permit holder shall maintain vehicles, a regular place of business, and a radio dispatch location within the corporate limits of the City of Rocky Mount. Applications for renewal shall be filed annually prior to January 31. Failure to apply for renewal shall constitute surrender of the permit. 
(g)  A limousine certificate shall be valid for one (1) year ending December 31 of each year. Applications for renewal shall be filed annually prior to January 31. 
(h)  Permits are not transferable. 
(i)  In the event that a taxicab owner dies or becomes permanently disabled, the council, at its option, may give priority consideration for reissue of the permit to the spouse of such owner or a member of the owner's family; provided, however, such priority consideration shall not be given unless the spouse or family member has been actively involved with such owner in the taxi business for at least three (3) years prior to the reissuance. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-2), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 2, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 0-96-40, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 22-3. - Revocation and penalties. 
(a)  The required permit and certificate shall be subject to revocation by any court of competent jurisdiction or by the city council for violations of the conditions of issuance specified in this chapter. Pending action by the court or the city council, such permits and certificates shall be subject to revocation by the chief of police. The operator shall be notified when the revocation of his permit will be considered by the city council and he shall be given an opportunity to attend and be heard. 
    An owner's permit may be suspended or revoked by the council at any time the council finds and determines: 
(1)  That the past record of the holder of the owner's permit is unsatisfactory and that it is detrimental to and not in the public interest to permit the continued operation of a taxicab business by such person; or 
(2)  That the owner has failed to operate the taxicab or taxicabs in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; or 
(3)  That the taxicab or taxicabs of the owner have been operated at a rate of fare other than that provided by this chapter; or 
(4)  That the holder of a permit has failed to register properly with the state, in the correct and true owner's name, any taxicab covered by the owner's permit; or 
(5)  That the holder of an owner's permit has been convicted of a felony; or violation of any federal or state statute or city ordinance relating to the possession or sale of intoxicating liquors; or violation of any federal or state statute or city ordinance relating to prostitution; or any federal or state statute or city ordinance relating to the use, possession or sale of narcotic drugs; or repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances; or becomes a habitual user of intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs; or 
(6)  That the holder of any owner's permit has made a false or misleading statement on his application. 
    No owner's permit shall be suspended or revoked unless and until at least five (5) days' written notice of the time and place of a hearing shall have been given to the holder of such permit and such hearing by and before the council is duly had thereon. 
(b)  In addition to other remedies and sanctions imposed, there is hereby imposed a civil penalty of twenty dollars ($20.00) for failure to observe the standards established, and requirements and restrictions imposed, under this chapter. 
(1)  The levying of civil penalties shall be initiated by any police officer or the taxicab and limousine inspector giving written notice of the infraction committed to the owner or driver, along with a statement that a civil penalty is being imposed. The notice shall inform the owner or driver that he may appeal the civil penalty within ten (10) days to the taxicab inspector. If an appeal is made, a hearing shall be held before the chief of police or his designee, who, following the hearing, shall affirm or reverse the imposition of the penalty. 
(2)  For the second, and successive violations during a single calendar year, the civil penalty shall be double that imposed for the first violation. 
(3)  Civil penalties shall be paid within thirty (30) days to the office of the revenue collector. If not paid, the city may initiate a civil action to collect the unpaid penalties. 
(4)  Permits shall not be issued nor renewed for applicants or their employees having unpaid penalties for violations. 
(5)  In addition to the levying of civil penalties for violations of this chapter, violations shall also be punishable as a misdemeanor offense under section 14-4 of the General Statutes, each day's continuing violation constituting a separate offense. 
(c)  Any change in the ownership of a taxicab, in whole or in part, direct or indirect, regardless of how such change in ownership is effected, shall automatically terminate any owner's permit issued for such taxicab. In addition, a change of ownership shall be deemed to have taken place on the date that the owner of a taxicab enters into a lease, rental agreement, use agreement, option to purchase, or any other agreement, which grants to another the right to acquire the taxicab at some future date upon the payment of money or the providing of some other consideration to the taxicab owner or his designee. No person, regardless of how he acquires title to the vehicle, shall acquire any right to operate the taxicab in the city unless or until he has applied for and been granted an owner's permit in the manner provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-3), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 3, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 0-96-40, § 2, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 22-4. - Failure to operate with regularity. 
    Every person having obtained a permit to operate a taxicab shall be required to operate such taxicab in such business with reasonable regularity. Reasonable regularity shall be defined as a minimum of seventy-two (72) hours per week that the vehicle used in the operation of the permit must be available for service. The permit of every taxicab operator shall be subject to revocation if such operator fails to operate such taxicab with reasonable regularity. Every operator of a taxicab who fails to operate with reasonable regularity shall be given ten (10) days' notice to appear before the city council to show just cause why such permit should not be revoked. Such notice shall be made by certified mail to the permit holder. If delivery is refused, no further notice is required. The operator may request an automatic fourteen (14) day continuance before the matter is heard. If, upon such hearing, it shall appear that such taxicab is not being operated in the interest or the convenience and necessity of the public and not being operated with reasonable regularity the city council is authorized to revoke said permit. 
    Hours and days of operation of every valid permit shall be a consideration in the decision to issue or not issue additional certificates as provided in section 22-21. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-4), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-89-98, § 1, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 4, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 0-92-71, § 1, 9-14-92) 
Sec. 22-5. - Inspection of safety devices and taximeters. 
    Before any vehicle shall be operated as a taxicab or limousine in the city, the owner thereof shall submit the same to the chief of police or his designated assistant at a time and place to be fixed by the chief of police for the inspection of the taximeter and brakes, lights, horns, tires and all other features of said vehicle. If, upon examination of the vehicle by the chief of police or his designated assistant, it is found to be in proper condition, he shall approve the same and issue to the owner a certificate of approval and if found unsafe or unfit for operation or if the vehicle otherwise fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the chief of police shall notify the owner thereof and such vehicle shall not be operated thereafter until it has been put in safe and proper condition. Every taxicab and limousine shall be submitted to the chief of police or his designated assistant for an examination as herein set forth not less than once each ninety (90) days and at such other intervening periods as deemed necessary. Such inspections may be scheduled in advance or unannounced. It shall be the responsibility of each owner to regularly inspect the vehicle(s) for which he is permitted to ensure its safe and proper operating condition. Such inspections by each owner to be provided to the taxicab inspector upon request. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-5), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-6. - Ownership designation. 
    Every taxicab operated upon the streets of the city shall have the name of the owner and, at his option, the address and telephone number painted in letters at least two (2) inches in height upon each side of the main portion of the body in a manner plainly visible at all times, and in addition thereto the owner's identifying number shall be painted on each side of the body and on the rear in a conspicuous place in numerals at least three (3) inches high. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-6), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-7. - Substitution of vehicles. 
    The person to whom a certificate has been issued may, by appropriate endorsement thereon by the chief of police, or his designee, substitute other vehicles for the vehicles for which certificates were granted. In such instance, the liability insurance or bonds shall also be transferred to such substitute vehicles. Failure to responsibly and lawfully report and maintain liability insurance records and vehicle registrations may render a permit subject to revocation. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-7), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-8. - Appearance and cleanliness standards for vehicles and drivers. 
    Each taxicab and limousine owner shall at all times maintain the taxicab he is driving in a clean, sanitary and good mechanical condition to the standard determined by the taxi inspector to be satisfactory. Each taxicab driver shall adhere to the following code of dress and behavior which shall be considered by the taxi inspector at each inspection: 
(a)  T-shirts, shorts and sandals are not permitted attire. 
(b)  Shirts must have collars. 
(c)  Cigarette smoking is permitted only with the passenger's express permission; cigar smoking is never permitted. 
(d)  Daily personal hygiene is required. 
(e)  Hair must be combined neatly. 
(f)  Shirts must be buttoned and shirt tails tucked in. 
(g)  Socks must be worn with shoes. 
The following are recommended standards for taxi drivers: 
(a)  Offering patrons a friendly and courteous greeting and avoiding profanity or offensive language. 
(b)  Opening car doors for passengers when feasible and offering assistance to handicapped and elderly patrons. 
(c)  Playing radios and tape players only with the passenger's permission. 
(d)  Thanking patrons for their business. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-8), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-9. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  The owner of every bus, taxicab, limousine, or other motor vehicle engaged in the business of transporting passengers for hire over the public streets of the city shall furnish to the chief of police, to be filed by the city clerk, and keep in effect for each such bus, taxicab or other such vehicle so operated, a policy of insurance or surety bonds, in the forms and issued by such company or executed by such sureties as shall be approved by the city manager, to insure the payment of damages incurred in any one (1) accident for person injuries resulting from the negligent operation of said vehicle to any one person to the extent of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and to more than one (1) person to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and for property damage to the extent of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle for hire within the city and unlawful for the owner thereof to permit the same to be operated unless and until such a public liability insurance policy or surety bond is filed with the chief of police and unless such policy or surety bond is in full force and effect at the time of the operation of said motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-9), 8-28-89) 
State Law reference- Taxicabs proof of financial responsibility to be filed with city, G.S. § 20-280. 
Sec. 22-10. - Fare regulated. 
(a)  Effective June 30, 1992, all taxicabs shall be equipped with taximeters meeting the standards of section 22-18 of this chapter, and it shall be unlawful for an operator of any taxicab or vehicle for hire to charge for transporting any passenger from or to any place inside the corporate limits of the city, taxi fares in excess of the following rates determined by the taximeter, provided that drivers or operators may require payment in advance of the estimated cost of each trip prior to transport. 
(1)  For the first 1/6 th of a mile or fraction thereof ..... $ 2.00 
(2)  For each succeeding 1/6 th of a mile or fraction thereof ..... 0.35 
(3)  Waiting time, per minute ..... 0.30 
Waiting time, per hour ..... 18.00 
To be charged only as provided in subsection (e). 
(b)  In addition to the charges set forth in paragraph (a) of this section, the following handling charges may be charged to transport, load and unload the following if requested by the passenger: 
(1)  Each suitcase, traveling bag or bundles exceeding one in number ..... $ 0.25 
(2)  Each footlocker or other package or article of similar size ..... 0.50 
(3)  Each steamer trunk or other package of similar size ..... 1.00 
(4)  Groceries in bags in excess of one per passenger ..... 0.10 
(5)  Groceries in cartons, boxes or crates, each ..... 0.10 
(6)  Bulky items which weigh more than fifty pounds (such as, but not limited to, bags, cartons, boxes of coal, feed, fertilizer, rolls of paper) ..... 0.50 
(c)  There shall be no additional charge for groups whose trips originate at the same location and whose destination is the same. The maximum number of passengers which may be transported in a taxicab is five (5). 
(d)  For multiple passengers boarding at different locations and traveling to different destinations, the first passenger leaving the taxicab shall be chargeable for the amount of the fare shown on the taximeter and before proceeding to transport the remaining passenger(s), the flag shall again be placed in the earning position so as to designate the beginning of a new and separate trip as to the remaining passenger(s) in such taxicab and such process shall be repeated each time a passenger reaches his/her destination and alights from the taxicab so that the last passenger(s) leaving the taxicab shall be chargeable with such fare appearing upon the taximeter upon leaving the taxicab unless otherwise arranged between the taxicab operator and the passengers. Provided that for taxicabs equipped with taximeters capable of multiple flag drops so that each passenger's fare is calculated separately from the point of pickup to his/her destination, this method 
shall be employed to charge each passenger unless otherwise arranged between the taxicab operator and the passengers. 
    In no case, however, shall the fares charged exceed the amount as calculated by one (1) of the above methods or as provided in subsection (c). 
(e)  Waiting time shall be defined as the period of time consumed when a taxicab is not in motion at the direction of a passenger from the time of acceptance of a passenger(s) to the time of discharge and also the time consumed while a driver is waiting for a passenger after having responded to a call but does not include the time consumed by a premature response or for the first three (3) minutes following the timely arrival in response to a call or for delay caused by traffic interruption, the inefficiency of the taxicab or its driver or due to any cause other than the request, act or fault of the passenger(s). 
(f)  Although not regulated by this chapter, all fare schedules and related charges for limousine services must be submitted to the chief of police and updated as needed. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-10), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-89-98, § 2, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 0-90-75, § 1, 10-8-90; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 5, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 0-92-71, § 2, 9-14-92; Ord. No. 0-92-80, § 1, 11-9-92; Ord. No. 0-95-9, § 1, 2-13-95; Ord. No. 0-97-72, § 1, 12-1-97; Ord. No. 0-01-3, § 1, 1-8-01; Ord. No. O-2005-85, § 1, 09-12-05; Ord. No. O-08-106, § 1, 7-28-08) 
Sec. 22-11. - Display of rates and map. 
    A copy of the rates and charges authorized by this chapter shall be conspicuously displayed on the inside of the taxicab where the same can be clearly seen by occupants of the back seat on every taxicab operated in the city; and it shall be unlawful for any driver to operate a taxicab unless such rates are displayed therein. 
    If it is determined that an owner or driver charges a passenger in excess of the metered fare or attempts to overcharge in any manner, the permit for that cab is subject to revocation. In no event shall any operator take a longer route to the destination than necessary, unless so requested by the passenger or unless an alternate route is known by the driver to be the most efficient route due to traffic conditions, road construction, trains and similar obstacles. 
(Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 6, 6-22-92) 
Sec. 22-12. - Evasion of fare. 
    Any person who obtains transportation from a licensed taxicab or limousine driver without paying therefor with intent to defraud said driver, or who after obtaining said transportation refuses or knowingly and willfully fails to pay for same shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-12), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-13. - Soliciting taxi patronage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating or in charge of a taxicab or other public vehicle for hire to go upon the premises of any place of public accommodation to solicit patronage from travelers or other persons, or to take hold of any passenger's clothing, baggage or other property, unless requested to do so, or to, in any manner, disturb or annoy passengers or other persons on the premises or on the streets in the vicinity thereof; provided, that this section shall not be construed or forbid any person in charge of a taxi or other public vehicle from calling the word "taxi," or courteously soliciting patronage while the operator is standing near and not exceeding ten (10) feet from his taxi, nor to forbid any taxi operator in possession of a check for baggage from going upon the premises to secure the checked baggage. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-13), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-14. - Refusal of passengers restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab operator to refuse to carry or transport any orderly person anywhere in the city, unless previously engaged or unable to do so, or to select and reject fares by points of origination based on their comparative profit margins. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-14), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-15. - Acceptance of additional passengers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab or limousine operator, driver or owner of any vehicle carrying passengers for hire within the corporate limits to allow any person from the general public to ride when transporting in said vehicle for hire a paying passenger or passengers. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for additional passengers to be picked up if the original passenger is under sixteen (16) years of age. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for additional passenger(s) to be picked up without the prior permission of the first paying passenger(s). 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for additional passenger(s) to be picked up unknowing that the taxicab carries previous passengers. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-15), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 7, 6-22-92) 
Sec. 22-16. - Accident report. 
    It shall be the duty of any taxicab limousine operator, owner or driver to report any and all accidents of any taxicabs including incidents of passenger injury operated by him to the chief of police or his designee immediately after such accident. Failure to report as required within one (1) week shall constitute cause for revocation of the permit. If, following an investigation, a determination is made by the chief of police that the number of accidents for an owner or driver is excessive, he shall recommend to the city council that the owner or driver's permit be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-16), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-17. - Transporting persons for immoral or unlawful purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly drive any vehicle for hire or permit the same to be driven for the purpose of conveying any person to or from any place or point for the purpose of indulging in any act of illicit sexual intercourse or any other immoral or unlawful act. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-17), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-18. - Taximeter required; definition, specifications, operation, inspection. 
    Every taxicab shall have affixed thereto and must use a taximeter the size, design and contents of which have been approved by the chief of police or his designee and which conforms substantially to the following specifications: 
(a)  A taximeter is a mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated either for distance traveled or for waiting time or both and upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of legible figures which are electrically lighted each time the taximeter flag is thrown from nonearning to earning position. 
(b)  Each taximeter must be driven direct from the taxicab transmission (instead of merely connecting with the speedometer driving shaft) to the taximeter head itself, using a flexible shaft and a flexible housing so connected and sealed as to be nontamperable. 
(c)  No person shall use or permit to be used upon any taxicab a taximeter which shall be in such a condition as to be over five (5) percent incorrect to the prejudice of any passenger. 
(d)  No person shall use or permit to be used or driven for hire a taxicab equipped with a taximeter the case of which does not have its cover and gear intact. 
(e)  If demanded by the passenger, the driver in charge of a taxicab shall deliver to the person paying for the hiring of the same at the time of such payment a receipt therefor in legible type or writing containing the name of the owner, the city license number of the driver's city license number or the taximeter number and any items for which a charge if made, the total amount paid, and the day of payment. 
(f)  No person shall drive a taxicab equipped with a taximeter that has not been duly inspected and approved pursuant to section 22-5 of this chapter. It shall be unlawful to change the size of the wheels or tires of a taxicab or the gears operating the taximeter or to change a taximeter from one (1) taxicab to another unless the taximeter is retested and approved by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-18), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-89-98, § 3, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 0-90-75, § 2, 10-8-90; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 7, 6-22-92) 
Sec. 22-19. - Suspension of operating rights for failure to comply. 
    If the chief of police, or his designee, shall determine that any owner or driver has failed to comply with any provisions of this chapter, he is hereby authorized to temporarily suspend the owner's permit and require the vehicle to be taken out of service until the vehicle and/or owner is in compliance, with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-19), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 9, 6-22-92) 
Sec. 22-20. - Driver's manifests. 
(a)  Every driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which is recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip, the number of passengers and amount of fare, in the case of shared taxi service trips, time the request was made for the taxicabs, estimated time of arrival at origin, estimated time of arrival at destination, and whether any of the passengers were blind and/or handicapped and/or confined to a wheelchair and/or required assistance by the driver. All such completed manifests shall be returned to the owner by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The forms for such records shall be furnished to the driver by the owner and shall be of a character approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Every owner shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least one hundred eighty (180) days and the same shall be made available upon demand for inspection by the police department taxicab inspector, and as requested by the taxicab inspector, information on the driver's manifests shall be tabulated and forwarded to him. 
(c)  Enforcement of the above section shall be held in abeyance until such time as a request is made for an increase in the number of certificates of convenience and necessity allowed in the city. Accompanying such a request shall be a minimum of six (6) months of manifests for each cab for the preceding period kept in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-20), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-89-98, § 4, 12-18-89) 
Sec. 22-21. - Determination of increased need for certificates of convenience and necessity. 
    For the purpose of determining the need for increased taxi service, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The number of filled and unfilled telephone requests for taxi service made on average days; 
(2)  The average response time for cabs after being dispatched; 
(3)  The percentage of instances in which the time of arrival at origin followed the estimated time of arrival at origin by more than five (5) minutes; 
(4)  The average travel time for fares; 
(5)  The percentage of instances in which the time of arrival at destination followed the estimated time of arrival at destination by more than ten (10) minutes. 
(6)  The number of permits not being operated with reasonable regularity as defined in section 22-4. 
(7)  The extent to which the number of outstanding permits is less than one (1) per one thousand (1,000) population of the city. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-37), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-92-50, § 10(a), (b), 6-22-92; Ord. No. 0-96-40, § 3, 6-24-96) 
Secs. 22-22-22-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2]

Secs. 22-41-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 

Sec. 22-61. - Required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab or limousine in the city, nor shall any owner permit any person to drive a taxicab or limousine, until such person shall have been granted a driver's permit by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-46), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-62. - Application. 
    Application for a driver's permit shall be made in writing to the chief of police, which application shall contain the name, age and address of the applicant and the name of his employer, and shall contain a statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance rule or regulation. The application shall be signed by the owner who shall have made reasonable determination that the driver meets the requirements of this ordinance and is recommended for approval by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-47), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-63. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The chief of police shall make such investigation as he may deem necessary of the applicant to determine whether the applicant is of good character, morals, dependable, may be relied upon to transport passengers with reasonable safety and is knowledgeable of the ordinance regulating taxicabs. Refusal to grant or renew a permit shall be made for any person: 
(1)  Whose state driver's license or chauffeur's license has been suspended or revoked. 
(2)  Who has accumulated a sufficient number of points against his driving record to justify a suspension or revocation in accordance with Chapter 20 of the General Statutes. 
(3)  Who, within a period of five (5) years, has been convicted of a felony. 
(4)  Who, within a period of three (3) years, has been convicted of any crime involving the driving of an automobile resulting in death to any person. 
(5)  Who, within a period of three (3) years, has been convicted of driving a motor vehicle while impaired. 
(6)  Who, within a period of three (3) years, has been convicted of a violation of any city, county, state, or federal law relating to the use, possession, or sale of intoxicating liquors, alcoholic beverages, beer or wine, narcotic or barbituric or other habit-forming drugs. 
(7)  Who, within a period of three (3) years, has been convicted of any city, state, county, or federal law relating to prostitution or lotteries. 
(8)  Who, within a period of three (3) years has been a habitual user of intoxicating liquors, alcoholic beverages, narcotic, barbituric or other habit-forming drugs. 
(9)  Who, in the opinion of the chief of police, is a person of such character and reputation that it would clearly be contrary to the public interest, safety and welfare to permit such applicant to drive a vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-48), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-64. - Issuance. 
    If the result of the investigation is satisfactory, the chief of police shall issue to the applicant for a driver's permit an identification card which will bear the name, age and residence of the person to whom it is issued, the date of the issuance and the expiration date, and the name of the owner of the vehicle to be operated. A small photograph of the applicant shall be posted on the permit in a place to be provided therefor. A fee shall be required of the applicant for the permit. This fee shall be determined by the city council and published in the Manual of City Policies. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-49), 8-28-89; Ord. No. 0-90-18, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 22-65. - Appeal from denial. 
    In the event that the applicant is denied a driver's permit by the chief of police, the applicant may appeal such denial to the city council in accordance with the following: 
(a)  The applicant shall appeal, in writing, to the chief of police. If such appeal is denied by the chief of police, the applicant may then appeal in writing, within ten (10) days, to the city manager. 
(b)  Within ten (10) days after the refusal of the city manager he may appeal, in writing, to and be heard by the city council. 
(c)  The council's decision on the question of the granting or refusing the permit shall be final and conclusive. 
(d)  The council may attach conditions to any appeal it sustains. 
(e)  After refusal by the administration or council, the applicant shall make no new application within twelve (12) months from the date of the original application. 
(f)  During pendency of an appeal from a decision to revoke a driver's permit, it shall be unlawful for such applicant to drive a vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-50), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-66. - Duration and renewal. 
    Every permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for a period of one (1) year, except as noted. The applicant shall file with the chief of police a renewal application. Permits are renewable on January 1 of each year. Upon the expiration of any permit issued under the provisions of this article, the chief of police may, upon application filed in the form and giving the information required in the original application, renew and extend such permit for an additional period of twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-51), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-67. - Revocation. 
    The driver's permit shall be subject to revocation by the chief of police for the violation of provisions of this chapter, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation governing or regulating the operation of taxicabs or motor vehicles or relating to alcoholic beverages or prostitution. The permit may be revoked by the city council upon a finding by council that the driver is not a suitable person to operate a taxicab in the city. The driver shall be notified when the revocation of this permit will be considered by the city council and he shall be given an opportunity to attend and be heard. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-52), 8-28-89) 
Sec. 22-68. - Display. 
    The driver's permit shall be conspicuously displayed where the same may be seen by occupants of the rear seat in any taxicab operated by the permittee and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or for any owner to permit to be operated, any taxicab by any person other than the operator designated in the permit displayed in the taxicab. 
    Permits for limousine drivers must be available in the vehicle the driver is operating and be submitted for inspection upon request of any passenger or police official. Failure to have a valid permit in the vehicle shall constitute cause for suspension of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 0-89-74, § 1(18-53), 8-28-89) 
Secs. 22-69-22-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TAXICAB COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-90-14, § 1, adopted Feb. 26, 1990, amended former Ch. 22 by the addition to Art. II of Div. 4, §§ 22-94-22-96, and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as Art. IV, §§ 22-94-22-96. See editor's note to Ch. 22. 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, authorities, § 2-46 et seq. 

Sec. 22-94. - Established. 
    A seven-member advisory group known as the taxicab committee shall be created as an advisory body with authority only to make recommendations to the city council on taxicab matters. Members shall be appointed as follows: 
(a)  Two (2) representatives of the cab companies in Rocky Mount who shall be selected by the companies and appointed by the council. 
(b)  Two (2) members of the city council who shall be appointed by the council. 
(c)  One (1) citizen representative who shall be appointed by the council. 
(d)  One (1) representative of the police department who shall be appointed by the chief of police. 
(e)  One (1) representative of the city manager's office appointed by the city manager shall be designated as the staff committee member. 
(Ord. No. 0-90-14, § 1, 2-26-90; Ord. No. 0-95-42, § 1, 8-14-95) 
Sec. 22-95. - Term of appointment. 
    Each member shall be appointed for a two-year term commencing on July 1 and ending on June 30. The number of reappointments which can be made by an appointing body or individual shall be unlimited. 
(Ord. No. 0-90-14, § 1, 2-26-90; Ord. No. O-2005-104, § 1a, 11-14-05) 
Sec. 22-96. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  Any issue or problem concerning the taxicab industry in the city submitted by or to a committee member shall be considered appropriate for committee discussion. Items needing consideration shall be submitted to staff for research and placement on the agenda as specified in (e). 
(b)  Decisions shall be made by consensus, but failing that, each member shall have one (1) vote with a simple majority rule. 
(c)  The committee shall meet on an as needed basis, but at least one (1) time annually. The day and time of meetings shall be determined by the committee chairperson, and all members shall receive advance notice of all meetings in accordance with state law. 
(d)  At the annual meeting the committee shall select a chairperson to serve for one (1) year who shall retain voting rights. 
(e)  An agenda, with supporting information, shall be prepared by the staff committee member and distributed to the members prior to each scheduled meeting. The chairperson shall follow this agenda. Each agenda shall provide an opportunity for committee members to submit items for consideration at the next meeting. Such items shall not be discussed at the current meeting unless deemed an emergency by a majority vote of the committee. 
(f)  Minutes of each meeting shall be kept by the staff committee member and sent promptly to each committee member following meetings. 
(g)  Recommendations to the city council from the committee shall be prepared by staff and submitted to the city manager for consideration by the city council or a meeting of the committee of the whole if appropriate. Staff shall also prepare a minority opinion, if requested, which shall then be approved by the appropriate committee members and presented along with the recommendation of the majority. 
(Ord. No. 0-90-14, § 1, 2-26-90; Ord. No. O-2005-104, § 1b, 11-14-05) 
APPENDIX A - LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the Land Development Code of the City of Rocky Mount, Ordinance No. 0-2004-57, as adopted by the City Council on July 12, 2004. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, headings and catchlines have been made uniform and the same system of capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text as appears in the Code of Ordinances has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
Prior to enactment of Ord. No. 0-2004-57 Appendix A pertained to Subdivisions. Similar provisions are now included in this Appendix A-Land Development Code. 

CHAPTER 1. - DEFINITIONS AND CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 101. - Rules of construction. 
    For the purposes of interpreting this Land Development Code, certain terms and words are to be used and interpreted as defined in this appendix. Except as defined herein, all other words used in this LDC shall have their customary dictionary definition. Certain zoning categories and the uses encompassed therein shall be construed and interpreted as set forth herein. All words used in present terms [tense] include the future tense; words used in the plural number include the singular; the word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, corporation, trust and company, as well as an individual; the word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel"; the word "building" includes the word "structure" or "dwelling unit"; and the word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory; the words "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied"; the word "map," "zoning map" or "Rocky Mount Zoning Map" shall mean the "Official Zoning Map of the City of Rocky Mount, North Carolina." The position titles in this LDC are intended to be gender neutral; for example, the word his shall refer to either the male or the female gender. 
Sec. 102. - Terms and uses defined. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this appendix, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Abandoned. The intentional or unintentional cessation of use, or maintenance of a building, structure or lot. 
    Accessory. A use, building, structure, part of a building, or part of a structure which is subordinate to and the use of which is incidental to that of the main building, structure, or use on the same lot, including a private garage. If a building otherwise qualified as an accessory building is attached to the main building by a common wall or roof, such building shall be considered a part of the main building. 
    Accessory apartment. A self-contained apartment created either by converting part of or adding on to an existing detached single-family home, or by building a separate apartment into a new home on a single-family lot. Both the apartment and the principal residence must have a separate outside entrance or entrance off a common entryway. 
    Accelerated erosion. Any increase over the rate of natural erosion as a result of land-disturbing activity. 
    Addition (to an existing building). An extension or increase in the floor area or height of a building or structure. 
    Adequate erosion control measure, structure, or device. One which controls the soil material within the land area under responsible control of the person conducting the land-disturbing activity. 
    Adult bookstore. A commercial establishment which, as one of its principal purposes, offers for sale or rental for any form of consideration any one (1) of the following: books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, movies, video tapes, or photographs or other visual representations, offered in photographic, electronic, magnetic, digital, or other imaging medium, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Any of the following shall be indicia that an establishment has as one of its principal business purposes the sale and rental of publications, movies, or other visual representations which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this section: 
A.  The business advertises the sale and rental of adult publications and/or sexually oriented devices; 
B.  Access by persons under eighteen (18) years of age to the business establishment or portions of the business establishment is restricted; 
C.  Signs or notices are posted outside and/or inside the business establishment indicating that the material offered for sale or rental might be offensive; 
D.  The building or portion of the building containing the business establishment does not have windows or has windows that are screened or otherwise obstructed or are situated in a manner that restricts visual access from outside the building to materials displayed within for sale or rental. 
Such indicia shall be considered along with all other factors and available information. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a general circulation video store that does not offer for sale any sexually oriented devices shall not constitute an "adult bookstore" even though it offers for sale and/or rental video tapes which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on the depiction or description of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities, as defined in this section, so long as: 
A.  Such described video tapes are stocked and displayed in a room separate from the area of the business establishment where general circulation video tapes are stocked and displayed; 
B.  Access by persons under eighteen (18) years of age to the room where such described videotapes are stocked and displayed is restricted; 
C.  The square footage of the separate room where such described video tapes are stocked and displayed is no more than twenty (20) percent of the square footage of the area where general circulation video tapes are stocked and displayed; and 
D.  The general circulation video tape portion of the business establishment offers a quantity and selection of new release general circulation video tapes that is typical of a general circulation video store and offers a quantity and selection of other general circulation video tapes that are organized and displayed in a manner that is typical of a general circulation video store. 
A commercial establishment may have other principal business purposes that do not involve offering the sale or rental of material depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas and still be categorized as an adult bookstore. Such other business purposes will not serve to exempt such commercial establishments from being categorized as an adult bookstore so long as one of its principal business purposes is the offering for sale or rental for consideration the specified materials which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult cabaret. A retail business or private club as defined in N.C.G.S. § 18B-1000 which (a) serves food or beverages, or permits the consumption of food or beverages, and (b) regularly provides or has available for viewing by its patrons or members adult live entertainment. 
    Adult day center. Community-based group program designed to meet the needs of functionally and/or cognitively impaired adults. Adult day centers provide a caring, home-like setting for individuals who, for their own safety and well-being, can no longer be left at home alone. 
    Adult care (home occupation). A permitted home occupation meeting LDC requirements in which eight (8) or fewer adults requiring supervision. 
    Adult entertainer. Any person who requests or accepts payment, tips or other compensation to provide entertainment by dancing, posing or otherwise appearing within an adult cabaret with (i) a less than fully opaque covering over any part of the genitals, pubic region, buttocks or any part of the areola of the female breast, or (ii) the covered male organ in a visibly turgid state. 
    Adult establishment. An adult bookstore, adult motion picture theatre, adult mini motion picture theatre, adult cabaret, or clothing-modeling studio as defined in this LDC. 
    Adult live entertainment. Any performance of or involving the actual presence of real people which exhibits specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this LDC. 
    Adult mini motion picture theatre. An enclosed building with viewing booths designed to hold patrons which, for any form of consideration, regularly presents still or motion pictures, films, slides, or similar photographic reproductions, a preponderance of which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this LDC, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult motion picture theatre. An enclosed building or premises where, for any form of consideration, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown, a preponderance of which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, or describing, specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this LDC for observation by patrons therein. "Adult motion picture theatre" does not include any adult mini motion picture theatre as defined in this LDC. 
    Affiliate. A person that directly, or indirectly through one (1) or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by, or is under common control of another person. 
    Agricultural uses (bona fide farm exemption). Land used as pasture or in the commercial production of crops, horticultural products, fish hatcheries or aquaculture. Also for the purposes of this LDC, the keeping of livestock for commercial or noncommercial purposes is defined as an agricultural use. Livestock includes but is not limited to poultry and hoofed animals such as cattle, horses, swine, goats, and sheep. Also included in this definition of agricultural uses are agricultural accessory buildings, and sales of agricultural products grown or raised on the premises. Not included in this definition is the commercial slaughtering of animals for marketing and farm tenant dwellings. 
    Alley. A roadway easement which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property and is not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    Alter. To make any structural changes in the supporting or load-bearing portions of a building, such as bearing walls, columns, beams, girders or floor joists. 
    Apartment. See dwelling, apartment. 
    Architect. A registered architect licensed to practice in North Carolina. 
    Architectural feature. A prominent or significant part or element of a building, structure or site. 
    Area of shallow flooding. A designated AO zone on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM). The base flood depths range from one (1) to three (3) feet; a clearly defined channel does not exist; the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate; and, velocity flow may be evident. 
    Area of special flood hazard. Areas of special flood hazard means and include the land area located within the 100-year floodplain as shown on the flood boundary and floodway map prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    Assembly. The use of a building or a structure, or portion thereof, for the gathering together of persons for the purposes such as civic, social, recreation, food or drink consumption, or similar activities. 
    Attached dwelling unit for individual ownership. A dwelling unit having a common or party wall with another dwelling unit. Each attached dwelling unit is characterized by its own subdivided lot of record which is conveyed with the dwelling unit when purchased. 
    Automobile off-street parking (commercial lot). Any building or premises, except [a building or premises] described as a private garage, used for the storage of motor vehicles for the public or private business. 
    Automobile off-street parking (parking deck). A multilevel building/structure designed and used for the parking of motor vehicles. 
    Bar, tavern or nightclub. Any establishment that that has been issued a permit or permits to sell or possess alcoholic beverages by the North Carolina Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission and which has available for its patrons, guests, or members amusements or entertainment such as, by way of illustration and not limitation, live or recorded music, dancing, table games, pinball or video machines, or television and which has gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages that exceed its gross receipts from the sale of food. 
    Base district. The zoning district of a residential, commercial, or industrial nature applied to a property on the official zoning map of the city which provides for the permitted and special uses for which the property or structures thereon may be lawfully used.
